author: {'steamid': '76561198069180353', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1827, 'last_played': 1704577466}
review:
The only good part about this game is the combat mechanics. 10/10, nothing like it.

Community is dead, barely a handful of players at any given time. Most of the servers are outdated and unplayable, which means you'll play on the same 3 boring maps. Steam Workshop has plenty of weapon skins and one or two character skins for each class. Nobody uploads anything anymore since 2015 or so.

Got some new achievements recently but doesn't help much since nobody plays the official maps or team games anymore. Sometimes you get a minor lag spike in the heat of batlle the opponent lands 2-3 hits on you and you can't even react, sometimes you land them. I blame the host for this.

Probably the only game that was better in Early Access than full release. They were some fun times. It's going free to play this year. I hate to give it a thumb down.



But seriously fuccc anyone who plays Phalanx and spams jump attack. This is why all potential new players drop it after just a couple of matches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021604169', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1495924602}
review:
An excellent game for swordsman and swordswomen, it embodies the essence of blade-to-blade combat, you are granted a small but dissimilar variety of weapon classes and warriors.
Using Parkour, evasion, countering, feiting, baiting, and misdirection (along with swordplay itself, ofcourse) you have many methods to defeat you opponent with.

Be wary, as a heavy stance will leave you open to counter-attacks, and a fast stance has a weak parry...
By rolling beside your foe's attacks, you can grant an opening to grab them, or mearly slash them and dart out of reach!

Formal, real-life training does help with timing and distancing however.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005079239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1453845823}
review:
Last good swordfight sim I played was Bushido Blade for PS 1 and I really loved that game. Blade Symphony feels similar only downside is that it feels way more arcade.
I would love to have a realistic damage system disabling limbs, but I guess Bushido Blade was like nothing else.

I like...
...the 3 different stances that at least come a bit closer to actual swordfighting. (Even if most swordfighting techniques have more than just 3 stances.)
...the somewhat tactical swordplay in this game.
...the style of the characters and the modability of their appearance.(even if the mods out there are mostly retextures and nothing to breathtaking till now.)
...that the different swordtypes you have to unlock are purely cosmetic and you have the full arsenal at your disposal from the begining.
...you can see a hologram of how your sword will cut through the air in your current pose and the current direction of your swing. (Never seen that in another game before I think.)

I don't like...
...the arcady health bar, I would prefer a more deadly combat, maybe something with disabling limbs if hit.
...the look of most fighting places, they look somewhat cheap and packed together without much love for detail and looks.
...that there are way to less different gamemodes for this otherwise great game. There are only point capture, free for all and some duells availiable.
...the low player count.
...that some of the animations look awkward and unhuman.

For people who love swordplay/figthing this is well worth about 5 ‚Ç¨. and if you buy it with friends I'm sure you can have a lot of fun cutting eachother to pieces. Buy it in the humble weekly bundle as long as it is there!

I really like this combat game.

[*] Superb visual and audio quality
[*] Simple yet strategic game mechanics
[*] Very nice aesthetics and theme
[*] No unnecessary story inhibiting the actual gameplay

Also, the first server I joined had the most polite opponents I've seen/heard in a video game community in years.

I'll probably be playing this often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030764648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 29505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11739, 'last_played': 1585619975}
review:
Honestly? The game is awesome. The community is great, the gameplay is fun, and the characters are diverse.

The problems? 

There is a huge lack of players in Blade. New players are always welcomed, but they wont have an easy time. If you're new and trying to get into the game, you will be destroyed over and over, for hours on end, until you eventually start to get good enough to compete with the community that's left in the game. 

There are five different classes in the game to choose from:

The Judge
The Phalanx
The Ryoku
The Pure
The Vanguard

Each of them have their own pros and cons, and learning how to play your selected class will take a lot of time. There are a multitude of sword types in the game and they all offer their own benefits, so learning which one is best for you is key when working on your class. 

The game works off of a ranking system:

Oak
Iron
Steel
Diamond
Master

You get promoted through the leagues by beating opponents of your league. This isn't a great ranking system, as you could be an oak leaguer who consistently beats masters, yet gains no elo points so you dont progress; you would need to wait until an oak leaguer faces you and then defeat him to advance for instance.

The game will test your ability in every fight. You will have masters who have over a thousand hours and they will beat you over and over, but you'll take a lesson in each fight and those lessons will eventually shape how you play the game.

If you're willing to put in enough time to learn how to compete against the majority of the players who are still on Blade, then this game is very rewarding and very fun. There are a lot of players who are interested in teaching newcomers, and the community in general is very nice and are a lot of fun. However, if you don't want to lose over and over again whilst you learn the game, then this game isnt for you.

I give this game a solid 8/10. There are issues with the gameplay such as dodgy tracers sometimes and ping can play a large part in the combat, but the game has an amazing community and the game itself is a lot of fun if you invest enough time into it. I reccomend bringing in a friend with you if you want to buy the game to not be completely alone whilst you learn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024451265', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1428983301}
review:
[h1]Jump in for the technical, challenging facets // Stay for the civil community and rivalries[/h1]

[h1]According to Steam user Exige, inter-Steam invites are currently not working as intended, making multiplayer a possibly diminished experience. I have yet to confirm this myself, but please be forewarned that this may be a possibility.[/h1]

+ Relaxing, contemplative soundtrack; it's the kind of soft music that helps one to focus
+ Each selectable character has a different play-style that can be accentuated with the right weapons and use of fighting stances
+ Can chain various stances together for combos during combat; can be quite fluid and practiced after enough time in the ring
+ Dueling servers make for very focused, civil engagements between players; there is an overall atmosphere of respect surrounding the player-base
+ Heavily skill-dependent; gameplay is generally very well balanced and, save for practice and dedication, there is little that another player can do to hold a significant advantage over others
+ Exceptionally friendly and inviting in-game community
+ Very mod-friendly; this feature can actually supplement the act of unlocking in-game weapons and appearances
+ Character emotes (such as bowing) help to keep duels expressive; these are gratuitously used to show respect to other players, and this keeps the experiences generally positive
+ Combat mechanics feel solid and are well-implemented
+ Plenty of aesthetically pleasing unlockables available
+ No microtransactions
+ Crisp, minimalist UI
+ Throwing items, feints, and grab mechanics do well to keep gameplay feeling fresh
+ Game heavily rewards strategy, timing, and finesse
+ Interesting environmental designs and character models

- Some animation sets are stiff and awkward
- Moderately small active player base (only 2-3 active servers during the making of this review)
- Fairly steep (though rewarding) learning curve; while I don't necessarily consider this a bad thing, I recognize that it may be enough to turn away more casual players

[h1]LockeProposal's Big Day Out[/h1]

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/bigdayout#]Community Group[/url]
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/7611703/]Curator Page[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198084476467', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1477759749}
review: Blade Symphony reminds me so much of Star Wars: Jedi Academy. The fighting system reminds me of all the fun I used to have while playing the game. While not as well polished as Jedi Academy's system it is still a really good game. The hit boxs are pretty accurate while the fighting system shines. It might take you a while to learn to fight but my suggestion is ask people. The commuinty in this game is just amazing as well as the developers. Overall 8/10. A good game overall that can allow you to become a master swordsman.

review:
A quanto pare questo gioco √® poco giocato in Italia,comunque scriver√≤ una recensione per questo gioco:

Per cominciare, il gameplay √® molto particolare √® ampio come argomento in questo gioco, c'√® molto da dire.
Intanto per i nuovi giocatori consiglio assolutamente fare il TUTORIAL, perche se non lo fate non capirete nulla su come giocare.Anche se fatto il tutorial, il gameplay rimane comunque molto difficile e io stesso ancora so poco, e nel tutorial non √® diciamo assolutamente "completo", cio√®, per giocare al meglio a questo gioco servirebbero anche dei consigli diciamo "avanzati" che oltre alle basi che il tutorial offre, ti insegni a fare molto danno al nemico (nel video del gioco sembra piu semplice, non lo √®).

Come grafica non ho nulla da dire, √® discreta e posso dire anche carina.Purtroppo pero c'√® un bug che dura da mesi e non viene risolto, nelle morti dei personaggi.Se per esempio prendere il personaggio Pure, il personaggio femminile che vedete nel video del gioco, quando muore, nella maggior parte delle volte almeno, assume posizioni.....strane.....vedrete voi da soli nel gioco.Sarebbe un bug da risolvere.

Il resto del gioco sono delle aggiunte davvero interessanti, tipo il workshop dove puoi creare oggetti per il gioco, e se sei fortunato nella valutazione di quell oggetto verr√† messo in esposizione nel gioco stesso, disponibile per tutti i giocatori.

Voto finale: 8.4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198053891175', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1621233809}
review:
Blade Symphony is a complex sword fighting game with a friendly community that's not too big or too small, and is easy to learn, but hard to master.

PROS:
- Duel system built into the FFA mode
- 1v1, 2v1 and 2v2 duels
- a LOT of cool workshop items
- unique combo system
- Easy to use customization system

CONS:
- Not many servers
- No easy way to make your own workshop item

Get it its awesome
12/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198013141287', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1426631704}
review:
I'm rather torn about Blade Symphony. 

You probably already know by now that it's a pretty in-depth melee duelling game with a vaguely Asian theme. The game plays a lot closer to fighting games than other melee-heavy ones like Chivalry or Mount and Blade, which are mostly about directional control and that is where it lost me a little. I do prefer the more intuitive "what you see is what you get" type of directional attacks and Blade Symphony is instead heavily focused on learning combos and their animations. If you like fighting games you might be right at home but I'm mixed about it.

The mechanics though are deep, innovative and balanced. Combos here are built between strings which represent stances, fast, heavy, balanced & air. You can change stances at the touch of a key and a good deal of the gameplay is changing stances between attacks to be one step ahead of your opponent. Attacks unlock the next tier on any string so, for example, if you attack balanced once and then switch to heavy, you will use heavy attack tier 2, and thus you have a myriad of possibilities to reach your character's favorite and appropriate attack, thus creating the "symphony" of your blade. 

The game is quite deep and takes a lot of practice to withstand even bots. There are innovative mechanics such as two simultaneous attacks leading to swords clashing and the heavier stance wins the attack, recovering faster and opening the opponent, different attacks having different recovery rates etc. It is quite complex and whereas a fighting game has 2 control input parts, directional moves and attacks, here you have the extra input dimension of switching between strings. To my mind, this game would benefit from a slightly slower pace to gain a more tactical feel, yet I am a mere newb.

The content is also decent, there are currently 5 characters each with their own unique attacks and stance-biases, and 6 or so weapons that play very differently(katana, rapier, scimitar etc). If you want to play competitively, you will have to learn a character builds' every intricate combo, their precise animations, and then do this for each other character and weapon combination because you need to be able to discern what stance the opponent is in and what attacks they are trying to string. Again, very much like a fighting game.

As you can see, there is a lot of depth and flow to the combat, and overall it is a game that I would recommend to people showing an interest. The strongest point and also biggest weakness of Blade Symphony is not really about its quality, nor about the hard work of the devs. It is the fact that it has a small community of very talented and experienced players and not much for a new player. 

As a new player, you will play the tutorials, spend a few hours learning the movesets against bots and then search for a game and proceed to have someone mop the floor with you. You will have a hard time getting into it. Tis an unfortunate circumstance that befalls smaller online games with steep learning curves and past their popularity peak, through no fault of the developers or of the dedicated community.

If you truly think you might get into this tight-knit competitive scene and understand that it will take you possibly hundreds of hours to match these players who know the game with their eyes shut, I wholly recommend Blade Symphony. In truth, though it saddens me, I do not consider the majority of buyers or of my acquaintances would find satisfaction here unless they pour a lot of dedication in it. Myself, I do not think I have it in me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067557292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1422426717}
review:
A surprisingly fun sword fighting game that plays out through lightning fast strikes and careful quick thinking.  

Right now it's just a fighting game, though, so if you're looking for a campaign or a story, you're out of luck.

If you're looking for a cheap, tactical fighting game to challenge your sword hand, this is a darn good one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041837166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1431894580}
review:
First of all I'd just like to say that this game is amazing and a ton of fun. If you like competitive games similar to this then you have no excuse but to buy it; especially at such a reasonable price. From what I've played the community has been nice and very helpful, in fact someone volunteired to teach me some of the more advanced mechanics of the game. I've not gotten to an extremely high level within the game, but I can with reasonable confidence say that the game is skill based and has quite the skill ceiling. 

A warning however is that before you understand the game it could be frusterating for some people since you may not know what you did wrong. Actually I have one tip for people that are just getting into the game, keep in mind that there are three difference staces and an arial state for when you're jumping. Someone can break your stance with an attack from a superior stance, thus breaking through your attack and cancelling it. Fast stance beats arial, medium beats fast, heavy beats medium, and arial beats heavy. Though just because you're using a superior stance than the enemy doesn't mean that they might not hit you first or attack faster, so get used to timing your attacks just right.

One more thing about the game is that everyone seems to develop their own unique style of sword play, and by no means are any of them better or worse than others apart from the skill of the swordsman. Not only can you develop your own style of play, but you can compliment it by selecting what character/sword combination you want to use. If you want to be big and hard hitting character and slow but satisfying attacks you can pick Judgement with the Longsword as a devestating conbination. Or if you'd rather deal your damage with speed, then try Pure with the Scimitar. Either way the game will be super fun with lots of variety. (One last tip, I'd reccomend when you first start to pick Phalanx with the Longsword and once you get used to him try other characters with the Longsword. Once you feel ready and are starting to develop your style then try experimenting with differnent conbinations. This is how I was advised to learn and it worked out very well for me.)

Past that though, the game is a blast; especially with friends. I'd highly reccomend it to any hardcore or competitive gamer that thinks they'll be interested in the game, and even if you're a casual gamer I think it's worth a try on a sale. Otherwise you're only out 10 bucks (Not the deer).

***I apologize for any mispelling or improper grammar, but I hope that this review was a fun and helpful read reguardless.***

author: {'steamid': '76561198119217982', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 9059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9047, 'last_played': 1538110172}
review:
TL;DR version: don't buy this game, it's dead, not to mention bad.

	This game is about as balanced as the U.S. economy, that's bad. Not to mention that the community is filled with perverts who spray furry porn ALL OVER THE PLACE. This game had some good ideas behind it, which is probably why people have stuck with it for so long, but in no way is "some good ideas" worth the headache that this will give you. The final nail in the coffin, for me, though was when the devs shut down the official servers, now only a handful of people play at any given time on custom servers, that are FILLED with the aforementioned pervs.

Edit/update: So I came back to this game for nostalgia's sake and would you guess what? It's still trash, and not only did they not fix anything, but they neutered the mechanics (admittedly "classic" mode still exists) decided to make it so that none of the previous mods worked and instead add PAID MODS. That's right PAID MODS, except there are only 4 paid mods available. and it doesn't look like they're going to be adding more anytime soon. So basically they destroyed hundreds of mods, put up 4 "approved" mods and asked for a dollar each. Screw you too, devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1425241996}
review:
What a beautiful game. This is a highly competitive hack'n'slash beat'em'up. There is next to no singleplayer apart from the tutorials but that isn't a bad thing (at the moment) since the community is still strong. 

I was able to jump straight into a thirtytwo player match and start slashing and dueling people. It will take a few hours before you can even go toe to toe with anyone, and even then you probably will still get beaten. I have been playing for five hours now and I have only won about ten duels out of about a two hundred. 

The graphics are truely amazing, and sound effects fit perfectly. Pick this up if you enjoy PVP in any sense of the word.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983291252', 'num_games_owned': 4279, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 838, 'last_played': 1448591310}
review:
EDIT: The issue has been fixed since. The resulting achievement (the one added to temporarily fix it) was really unprofessional though if you ask me.

I only played this game for a few hours but it gave me over a year's worth of butthurt.

BTW, the game was good. I just want people who are reading this to be informed that this isn't a review based on gameplay but rather the way the developers and community managers have handled my (and others') particular issue.

Those of you who got the game very early on (early 2014) remember that there was a single achievement for B.S. called 'Initiate'. For some reason, the developers decided to remove this single, FULLY FUNCTIONAL, achievement with the excuse that it was simply a test achievement. This was a big mistake because   a) there's no benefit to removing something that works just fine and   b) it broke my achievement showcase. If you want an idea of how it's broken, either check out my profile or search the term 'achievements' in the Blade Symphony discussion board.

By doing something SOOO UNNECESSARY, Blade Symphony created a yearlong problem for people such as myself. The showcase's calculation of average game completion is also partly to blame but the game developers are easier to reach in order to obtain a quick fix.

With this in mind, I have been (for the last year) trying to suggest that Blade Symphony reincorporate any  single achievement so that we can get a bandaid solution for our profile issues (which they are partly to blame for). In response, the community manager/moderator has made several replies that have either been excuses, empty promises, more excuses, and other disappointments.

Recently (February 2015), a few other games have caused other players' profile showcases to become 0%. One of them was Midnight Mysteries. In less than a week, the developers of that game FIXED the issue with ease. This begs the question, why has Blade Symphony taken so long to provide assistance to those of us they have affected? I have come to the realization that all of the suggestions and points I made over the last year have fallen under deaf ears. The mod who has been replying to me this past year has not been paying close enough attention to take these concerns seriously. After a year of waiting around and being disappointed, I've finally given up on this game. Blade Symphony's developers should be ashamed that they are taking 52 times longer than MumboJumbo (the publisher) to respond to this issue -- that's only if they do anything about it.

TLDR = I give up on this game. Achievement-related concerns fall on deaf ears.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022402293', 'num_games_owned': 1191, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1431735560}
review:
Good sword fighting game. The fighting control and gameplay feel very solid though they could have some balancing tweaked I haven't seen anything that stands out that needs fixing. The only downside to the game is that the game lacks depth outside of the gameplay as more and more servers keep vanishing making it harder to find one with a suitable ping and even then with more than 1 or 2 players on.

The developers will need to do something to "reboot" the game or it will end up dying soon as it lacks in-depth content outside the gameplay.

I bought it for ¬£2 and I'd say it was worth it though I wouldn't pay more than ¬£5 for it.

Buy it if it's on sale and you want a sword fightining game with good sword mechanics similar to that from Jedi Knight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040332726', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1424481158}
review:
The way the game is advertised makes you think you can customize every aspect of your moveset. You can't. It's as simple as that. 
The game is based around 5 charters that are just different sword styles, and you get 5 types of swords with their class attributes. Everything else in the game is just aesthetic mods, which are strange because I can't seem to get the points to unlock those skins though battle and don't see a game store, so yeah.

Anyway, this game's not that good, the fighting's imprecise and the stun/parry system is buggy. Some weapons have useless specials like the Katana's Feint, which litterally only fakes an attack leaving you open to damage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021229458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1478676544}
review:
A great game of Mind-Games. My only complaint is the lack of players at certain times of day/night, which can be fixed by an influx of new players ^^

It's like chess. Or Tekken. or.... Ch....Chekken.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996714092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1424196604}
review:
Remember when you first got Jedi Academy and you jumped into the multiplayer and hit up a few servers and had a blast just whaling on dudes with your lightsaber and backflipping all over the place because WOW YOURE A JEDI NOW and you loved it? Remember that day when you finally got to play the swordfighting video game you had been dreaming of all your life? That was a good feeling.

Now you're in your mid thirties, unmarried and childless, with a career that isn't really going anywhere. It's Friday night and, if you were back in your college days, you'd be at a party, drinking cheap beer on the floor of your best friend's furnitureless apartment, maybe feeling up that chubby but cute girl whose been sending you messages on Friendster. But you're not back in college, you're middle-aged and sitting at your computer looking to download a goddamn video game to play because THIS IS WHAT YOUR LIFE HAS LED TO: FILLING YOUR MINUTES WITH DISTRACTIONS TO PAD OUT THE HOURS BETWEEN THE TIMES YOU GET TO SLEEP.

So you download Blade Symphony, thinking that you'll get to relive the awesomeness that you felt when you first became a Jedi in Star Wars: Jedi Warrior Jedi Academy. And you know what? You do relive that awesomeness.

For fifteen or twenty minutes, anyway. Then it dawns on you why first/third person swordfighting games always devolve into these super-serious multiplayer servers with very strict rules and Bushido codes where the admins kick anybody who doesn't stick to 1v1s. That reason is because only 15 year olds enjoy playing on a server where it's a free for all and everybody just runs around whaling on everybody else, and you can only be fifteen for so long. Eventually you have to either quit the game and play something more engaging, or you have to join one of these tryhard swordfighter servers to breathe fresh life into the game.

I give this game a thumbs up because for those first fifteen minutes I didn't feel like a middle-aged man playing fucking video games on a Friday night in my tiny loft apartment.

review: Fast paced and fun. Bit of advice... It's always better to hit first. author: {'steamid': '76561197988841080', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1539194076}
review:
Soy un antiguo veterano del jedi knight II y del academy , tambien jugue al movie battlers.
Llevaba mucho tiempo esperando un juego de duelos y la verdad esque este juego no decepciona nada.

El sistema de combate se basa en utilizar la guardia que sobrepasa a la de tu oponente.

Asi aerea>fuerte>balanceada>rapida (y rapida>aerea). Cuando las armas chocan ,quien tenga la guardia mejor ,atraviesa el ataque del otro y le impacta. Si son iguales se produce una parada.
Tambien puedes cubrirte ,cargar ataques (que le otorgan varias caracteristicas dependiendo de la guardia) ,rodar , o dar un par de pasos.

Las armas cambian mucho el estilo de juego.

Los estoques puede bloquear un ataque con el boton derecho (al segundo te rompen el bloqueo) no pueden atravesar guardias pero cuando paran con un ataque lateral se recuperan muy rapido ,pudiendo golpear al enemigo. Hacen da√±o extra con estocadas

Las espadas largas son versatiles y se trata de adaptarte al oponente.

Las katanas juegan mucho con el tema de atravesar guardias y en vez de bloquear ,pueden cancelar su animacion para hacerte un ataque desde una guardia distinta (fintar). Hacen da√±o extra cuando romper guardias y menor da√±o base. Un combate entre dos expertos de katana parece uno de samurais.

Las cimitarras ganan mucho de los ataques tipo corte pues son los que mas tiempo estan en contacto con el enemigo y si mueves al personaje para que eso pase ,ganas un monton. Como los ataques tipo corte son laterales ,puedes moverte por los lados y hacer mucho da√±o con un solo ataque sin necesidad de ir de frente.

Falta otro arma china ,el jian ,pero no lo he utilizado mucho.

Los personajes por otra parte ponen las animaciones: asi tienes un esgrimista ortodoxo ,un caballero con todo tipo de golpes lentos pero que llega bastante o un tipo con un sistema de lucha que recuerda a mugen de samurai champloo.

El sistema de lucha es muy satisfactorio y adictivo y la comunidad es muy buena gente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076657770', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1424033026}
review:
HUGE disappointment. The game looks great in videos, but feels terrible to play. 
The community is pretty dead, as it peaks at about ~110 members a day (compared to 3k+ months ago according to steam stats). 
The gameplay is really clunky for a sword fighting game. 
Cuts and slashes: 1/10 clunky as hell. An edgy emo tumblr teen could probably cut better.
"comboing": 0/10 Euro truck simulator probably has better comboing than this game.
Sword designs: 0/10  Edgy as hell, would not lather nutella on myself with any of these swords. 

I realize I have like 2 minutes on this game or something, maybe like 5, but there is nothing appealing to keep me into it. 
I can definitely see why the community is gone, and I really don't think it's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029554617', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1780, 'last_played': 1440854175}
review:
Perhaps not a game to start outside sales events because of lowish player count, but Blade Symphony is one of the more interesting fighting games I've played. It is more deliberate, slower, but also deadlier. A character with a moveset and sword dedicated to slow but damaging counter hits can kill you with a single blow if you screw up your offense. The round's outcome is not decided even if one player has 100% hp and the other has 1%.

The way the game controls is pretty unique, it's centered around a combo system with stances and utilizes kb+m so there's definitely a learning curve and it'll take a while before the feeling of jank wears off. But after enough training, you will understand the uses for all of the few dozen different swings your character can perform. Perhaps one move has a fake-out portion at the beginning that baits an attack only to counter it, perhaps it hits instantaneously at your side and catches the flanking opponent off-guard, maybe it makes you hop forward and thus extends your effective range, etc.

Because the game has a parry system that lets slower attacks deflect faster ones, the game is rather punishing against button mashing when you have even slightest skill difference between players. Mashing faster attacks is the same as almost begging your opponent to devour your HP bar with one decent counter, while slower attacks can leave you horribly vulnerable and are often not as good when your enemy is right within grabbing distance

If you got the patience to study a character's full moveset, it's definitely a game worth learning. It's the only fighting game I could call myself even remotely adept at thanks to the very different pacing

author: {'steamid': '76561198053032431', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1423129240}
review: Don't buy this game if you were looking for realistic sword play.  Don't buy this game if you wanted to duel a friend. It has an extremely dissapointing control system that caters more to button mashing and luck than any form of skill at all. There are limited not very appealing styles/skins to choose from at the start, and same goes for swords. I have not hated a game so much in an hours play since I can't remember when. There is not even many maps to play on. It lacks content and what it does have will leave a bad taste in your mouth. Lend me some thumbs because 2 thumbs down just ins't fair to other games that suck enough to get that rating.

Spend 10 minutes wandering around and looking at the scenery. Play hide and seek. Hide in a corner, a elevator, a ledge outside. Bacicly prop hunt with swords. Remember that I'm playing a sword dueling game. go to main hub to fight people. No one is fighting, instead eveyone is trying to achive a bug that lets you stay in air stance. Become Air bender. Spin around like a top swinging my sword. Killed by a shirken to the face. 

Skyrim with swords 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197971160250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1539287055}
review:
Blade Symphony is those games that have great idea, very original. But suffer heavily on the execution.

First of all, the game is multiplayer only. It isn't a bad thing in intself, but it's pretty bad when the netcoding isn't well made.  Any game with more than 50 ms is unplayable, you'll take damage without even seeing the attack animation. There were some pros and some cons I thought of this game, but what made my mind about not reccomending is this. Blade Symphony is a fighting game, like Tekken, Soul Calibur or Virtua Fighter. And even though it runs on completely different rules, reaction time is everything about these games. How quickly you dodge, defend or counter-attack is what defines most of the matches.

The second great sin of this game, it's terrible in explaining itself, and there's no matchmaking. Meaning you'll have to play to understand the game and you'll always end up in matches where your opponent plays the game for far longer than you, meaning you'll learn nothing and get perfected all the time. There IS a tutorial telling the game's commands, but that's not what we need to know to actually jump in multiplayer battles. Imagine if Street Fighter had a tutorial like this "this button punches, this button kickes, this one is used to move character". And playing with bots will warrant you no real experience of the game either. The bot will just run in a straight line and attack you.

So, TL;DR
The bad:
-Lag issues
-Lacking tutorial
-Very steep learning curve

It might be a good idea to get this game to play with friends only, maybe after a while you might learn something. Unfortunately it wasn't an opportunity I had, so I can't tell.

It'd be unfair to let out the good of this game though.
It has a great idea, of all games that advertised "swordfighting" as a selling point, I've never saw one that came this close before. It really feels fresh and original.
The community is pretty good for an online game. Although most of them will not actually give you a good help of understanding the game (90% percent of the time I got "playing is the best thing to do", the other 10% were gimmicks that didn't worked on higher level players), Blade Symphony isn't the kind of multiplayer experience that seems like a Tourette Syndrome training camp (or Coprolalia if you're nitpicky). The players are most of the times cordial, there's almost no one trying to troll around, and the user-created content is great (I've even had a Keyblade skin).

Maybe if this game had a Single-Player mode or mabe even the "coaching" option like TF2, I could recommend it, but in 4 hours of gameplay I've had 3 and a half of frustrations. Not exactly what I'm looking for when buying a game. Frankly speaking, Blade Symphony never really left Early Access. It's still unfinished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056049276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1462155069}
review:
ATTENZIONE, QUESTO GIOCO NON √® ALTRO CHE UN ARENA IN CUI COMBATTERE CON ARMI E ARMATURE PREDEFINITE O INSERITE TRAMITE MOD. 2VS2 O 1VS1. OGNI PERSONAGGIO HA UN SUO STILE DI COMBATTIMENTO, IL QUALE NON CAMBIA A SECONDA DELL'ARMA UTILIZZATA (come detto nella descrizione fornita dal negozio di steam), PERTANTO IL VOSTRO PERSONAGGIO potr√† TRANQUILLAMENTE USARE UNA SPADA A 2 MANI DI MEZZA TONNELLATA COME FOSSE UN FIORETTO E VICEVERSA.

(Tengo a precisare che dopo 5 minuti che giocate vi annoierete a morte)

author: {'steamid': '76561198039046257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1350, 'last_played': 1446982543}
review:
Blade Symphony is a difficult game. Even at 20+ hours, I wasn't even half decent.

When I played it in 2015, the community was already very small. I can't imagine that many people, if any, have stuck around.

The big problem with having such a small community is that the skill level of players varies wildly. If you manage to get a match, the likelihood of a stomp is high.

While the game had a lot of potential, it kinda felt a bit like a more advanced (and fiddly) version of Dark Souls multiplayer combat.

The reason I'm writing this review now is because I saw the game was on sale. If you intend to play alone, I don't recommend buying it. Maybe for 99c it's worth an hour of play, if you've got a friend or two who'll buy it as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068597052', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 374502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213507, 'last_played': 1708978388}
review:
1v1 swordfighting game, explains itself.

There are things that you might not know even if you search for it, that being the experience playing this game and meeting the community. But first as for the game itself it's pretty good, most people trying alternatives to this game like For Honor or Absolver end up coming back saying they were worse. This game does have problems like I just hinted, which mostly comes down to people thinking that the main competitive strategy is boring. Now it's actually not any more boring than a lot of other fighti/swordfighting games, meaning you use a very small set of attacks that are the best and play a safe defense. 

Some loadouts take this to an extreme like katana judgement, which pretty much only uses one attack sometimes for entire rounds and without ever adjusting what they're doing. But if you don't mind defense and just like fighting 1v1 in general this game still is good.

To get more specific about this game, what divides this from a lot of fighting/swordfighting games is that movement limitations are very absent, you move really quickly and freely and this puts range and timing more central to the game than options, making the game feel less technical at times. Other times it makes it feel very limiting because no matter what you choose you end up getting whiff punished by the same attack all over again, but that's because attack choice doesn't matter as much as positioning meaning you should look towards changing how you move.

This game is very unforgiving in the start and you can expect to get rolled a lot first few hundred hours, so if you aren't very committed to learning or winning at games in general either stay away or go on ffa servers and chat. Some people play this game just for the chill aspect so that is an idea to try.

Some people are toxic, don't mind them and if you do mind them don't play online games at all. Either that or accept that they exist and that they are not going anywhere. 

The game allows for different character and sword combos to work, with fewer ones being bad than good in my opinion.

This is the third time I edit this review to redo it entirely, hope I can live with it this time, have fun ingame =).

author: {'steamid': '76561198030204140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1509006749}
review:
Too high of a learning curve, the game is unbalanced, and some features don't work as expected. The game itself is nice, but requires too much of a patience that you don't need so much in, for example, Chivalry. The game is nice, yes, but has some work to do. Make more usable the parkour system is one. Improving hit detection is another, and adding a good tutorial is a third one. I won't mind either some kind of story in-game, either a PvP campaing or PvE one. Something else that helps here. As other people said, I wouldn't recommend it at is current state.

Pros:
Fun concept.
Rewarding fighting system.
High cap game with a difficult learning curve.

Cons:
- High cap game with a difficult learning curve. I know, is a positive point but a con aswell, since learning how to play can be really frustrating. The tutorial is nothing else but the basics.
- Unbalanced game, some of the tricks to win the opponent are based in the fact that the hit dettection is awkard, and some hits connect earliear than others. If you add to this the fact than when you start you have in mind just to hit the opponent but not which of those hits will connect or how they will connect, you have here a sword game based on knowing the combos more than a intuitive game. So you must learn all the combos first and then know how to use it against a rival... No, it's not a friendly game. You will not only fight opponents but the game itself and that is really frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062873191', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 26983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9488, 'last_played': 1688617016}
review:
[h1] What's Blade Symphony? [/h1]

Blade symphony is one of the most intense games i've ever played. It's 3D fighting game with 4 main attack styes: fast, balanced, heavy, and air, each of which can counter the one before it when the swords clash. These moves can be strung together to create a virtually infinite number of attack styles! Confusing, I know. This game frustrated me to no end when I bought it, and it still frustrates me today, but I've learned that when you push through the frustration and get used to the controls, you'll find [u] an amazing, in depth fighting game.[/u]

[h1] PROS: [/h1]

[list]
[*] Phenomenal, in depth fighting system
[*] Beautiful graphics
[*] Fantastic music
[*] (mostly) Great community!
[*] (slightly) Attentive dev team!
[/list]

[h1] CONS: [/h1]

[list]
[*] Tracers can be unpredictable when lag is strong (So pick non-laggy servers!)
[*] Tutorial is kind of crap
[*] Frustrating to get used to
[*] [b] EXTREMELY [/b] frustrating to get used to
[*] [b] GAHHHH [/b]
[/list]

[i]Summary: Blade Symphony is a great game if you're into ninjas, fighting, beautiful graphics, amazing battle music, super fast combat, intense gameplay, and lastly, a whole bunch of shurikens flying everywhere.[/i] 9/10

review: A very innovative swordfighting game that demands precision, prediction, and spacing. Also includes 2 vs 2 simultaneous fights as well as multi man free-for-alls. Weapons are divided into different classes, and each type is used differently by each of the playable swordsmen. However the game still feels somewhat unpolished, and at times unbalanced, making the game still feel like its still stuck in Early Access mode. Could just be the growing pains of developing an entirely new fighting system, but at the current price, it's too much of a gamble for my wallet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058771133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1567201903}
review:
It's good. The controls are smooth and I like it's pragmatic take on swordplay. Graphics are nice. Concept is genius. It also allows custom mods in Steam which are fun to take advantage of. This game also has really good potential. It's only drawback is it's lack of popularity. 

A lot of the progress you make is based off your online play, and it's rough to get a good community of online players in this game. My fix was getting a small group of friends and it's just something nice for compeitive swordplay. 

Overall it's worth getting and worth playing and exploring. It also has really good potential if it had it's own community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133425477', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 161747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142437, 'last_played': 1692316133}
review:
Alrighty, its about time edit my review from a long time ago. But first some things I wish to point out.
[list]
   [*] After 900 hours I can be a little biased in favor of this game
   [*] This is not a game where a person with 1 hour should be reviewing, this game takes much more time to understand and any reviews from these people should be ignored, if you like it or not.
[/list]

 Blade Symphony, released May 7, 2014 by Puny Human Games. This is a game that without a doubt I am addicted too, though idk if that is good or bad, probably bad. From my first day on Blade Symphony spamming with Jian Ryoku, to becoming almost top tier, my journey has been wonderful. I have met tons of people, most of them on my steam friends list and I dont regret anything. Though I feel like im a rare case, for many many players have stopped playing for multiple reasons that ill get too in second.

   Pros:
           [list]
           [*] Complex fighting mechanics (can be good or bad, but probably a good thing).
           [*] Good community, most of them you will talk to and get to know them a little bit.
           [*] Members of the community are taking an initiative to try and balance the game.
           [*] Awesome soundtrack.
           [*] Fun player-made events like Battlechess, Machine, King of the Hill, Fencing, Kendo etc.
           [*] Steam Workshop enabled, allowing you to choose from tons of player made swords.
           [/list]

  Cons:
           [list]
           [*] Bad retention rate.
           [*] Not much content.
           [*] Time between patches can get rather long.
           [*] Devs aren't as involved as they once were (though they are still here).
           [/list]

  This is one of those games that is not for everyone, and if you get this game you need to go in knowing that you will get stomped, beaten, and "lolgitgudfgtggnore"'ed by bad eggs, this is only a very small amount of players though, most of the players are actually very friendly and willing to help you. Time and practice will gain you skill, you will need to be patient. You dont know how many times ive seen new players come in and get mad because they cant win. Sorry, your not going to win against someone with houndreds of hours. As of right now their are two servers with teachers, "Sexy Food" US, and "Avalaon" EU.

   But this game isnt without flaws, because of the games retention rate (sorry cant remeber the exact figure), you will notice not very many play this game. Those that do play, have lots of hours. So if you are looking for a game with many players. Quit reading and find a new game. But because this is a fighting game, the most important thing is the balancing. Tbh this game has become less balanced than in the past. But im sure devs, and experienced players will work together to balance the game in time.

  If you are looking for a complex fighting game, and can handle being beaten up many times, I strongly recommend this game. As I said, this game isnt for everyone and you need patience. But after 900+ hours ive had my journey and it has been pleasant, and I wish to see more people. 
   
 I mentioned about me having most of my friends list ppl from Blade Symphony. Im going to take this moment to list every single one of them so you have an understanding of just how many people I have had the pleasure of meeting and having on my friends list.

  Lexxure, Blood Spartan, CanadaOP, Dr.untitled, Goobie, Matthiasa, Mike, Paco, RedBreadMcjagger, Redmund, Tea Time, Tork, Tyrone, Waifu, MTU, Nani, Narny, Norman, Pedro, R3D343, Raffle, Scal Forte, Septum Sonus, Skeleton, SSauce, Taz, Kmoney, Water, Xehanoth, Darknight, Vendetta, Vylli, R3D5n0w, Animas, Bready, Chipi, Codemonkey, Death, Dnoor, EatabagofDiks, Elmo The Grand Defiler of Soul, Famos, Frok-Vee, Fug4life, Hade, Imposter Snake, JESUS IN REHAB, Kevin, Kiinsy, Lostinei, Maconjr, ManofHonor, Paradox, Ricky, Rozie, Sazed, Sergeant Stoner, Milo, Stewy, The Fish, Greatest Black Karate Man, Zealum, Trolligy, ZeronKnight.
 
As you can see I have met many people from A-Z, and have enjoyed talking to each and every single one of them, or they wouldnt be on my friends list. Im at the point that I stay for the community, not the fighting itself. Once you start playing and you stay, you will see your friends list stack up with people you meet. And with that being said......I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109064566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1407562136}
review:
Recommend an afternoon of practice before playing against others.

The game is basically a sparing match between different swords. Each way to move, counter, roll, dodge or parry will alter your next swing and will alter how your enemy reacts to it.

Game has a learning curve and needs some understanding of the weapons before killing another person on the game with one.

7/10 - Not for New Gamers, or people that get bored easily

author: {'steamid': '76561198026719177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1449542639}
review: From how much I've played so far, It's been an enjoyable experience. The sword play is fun and intense. However, at least in my opinion, I don't feel as if the fighting has as much depth as the game claims to have. Every character has at least one move that can be exploited to a degree. Character balance is decent, but nearly everyone uses Ryoku and it gets slightly irritating. The workshop support is great with all kinds of swords and hats to choose from. There's not many people to play online with though, but when you find a good server, it's worth it. There's a lack of multiple game modes. The ones that are present however are done pretty well and are fun. I personally like Free for all because you can run around the entirity of a map. You can attack others in a big moshpit or do a private 1v1. There's wallrunning and things like that which are pretty cool, but they get boring pretty quick, at least for me. This is the kind of game that you would want to buy on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth 15 bucks unless you REALLY want to. Either way, it's not a bad purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998135402', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1486155457}
review:
Blade Symphony is 3D Duel Game (like 2D Beat em' Ups).

It offers 5 different Character each with its own Moveset. Those Moves are divided into following "Stances": Air, Light, Balanced and Heavy. Each Character can also be customised with different clothes and Swords

You can mix attacks in with every Stance. For Example: From the Heavy Stance you do an Attack, then switch to Balanced and make another 2 Attacks and then switch finally to Light for final Attack.

All the Characters has more or less Slots in the Stance, which determines in which way you can cross the Stances. For Example: Phalanx has only one Slot in Heavy, which means you can only do a Heavy Attack at the Beginning, after that switch to Balanced or Light.

Each Attack can also be charged for maximum Effectiveness, which is different for every Slot in the Stances.

You can also choose between 4 different Sword Types: Katana, Longsword, Jian and Scimitar. They have different Moves  and Properties which alters also the Moveset of the wielding Character. Training is recommended to get a feeling for each Sword.

Additionally other Swords can be purchased through the ingame Money "Notes". These Notes you can get after winning Duels

But there are at the moment negative Points which comes to my Review why i dont like it:

[b] Spamming Attacks [/b]:
Basically, in the Duels the Players spammed only Charged Attacks or the same attack and didnt rely too much on Tactics which is fundamental in Duels. This "Tactic" allows you to win almost every Time if you have the right Character and Timing. This Tactic is used by Beginners and Pros as much as i saw in my playing Hours

In one Fight i tried to rely on this Spamming Tactic without thinking on Defense. The Result was, that i won a fight with a "Pro" in less than 10 Seconds. Using Tactic or timed Attacks and Avoiding has slighter Winning Chances as this Spamming. There are no effective Counterattacks since Blocking (Only Longsword i think it was) doesnt block every Damage and you get "Chipp Damage" (Damage that surpasses the Block and damage a little the Health). Maybe other Pros use more Attacks and real Tactic, but as far i saw there was none of this.

[b] Realism [/b]:
The Moves are somewhat stylish and sometimes over the Top, which comes to the Point that the Developers should have thought in which Direction this has to be. My Problem imho is, that despite maintaining realistic feeling of Swords and Stances it doesnt cope well with the stylish Moves on some Characters (Ryo). As far as i known, they are not Cyborgs. This ruins for me the Atmoshpere since it doesnt decide which way it should take. 

For Example: You can throw Daggers/Axes/Shuriken/etc. on your Enemies but you have unlimited of these, so you can spam those infinitely which annoyed me on some Battles who Players throwed those at me all the time.

[b] Some Minor Points [/b]:

-You get pretty slow Notes for buying new Gear. After 5 Hours i had only 201 Notes. Some Swords cost over 5000! There is much grinding in this Game to get new Swords.

-Each official Map has only 3 Arenas, so if 12 or more are connecting you have to wait a while and wait in a Queue.   There are some custom Maps with 6 or more Arenas though, but arent really that pretty as the official


This concludes my Review. Hope this helps to someone out there

author: {'steamid': '76561198028395060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1427036566}
review:
Amazing swordfighting game. Quick dynami and satisfying. It isn't too hard to learn and hard to master - as it should be.
I think is worth its cost and I enjoyed every moment of it.

There might not be as meny players as I would hope but you can still find a good match quite easily.
The graphics are nice, I haven't encountered any bugs yet, its compatible with steam workshop for some vanity items or maps. 

The only thing that could be better I think are the animations. They don't look as good or realistic as in some games but they do their job. They aren't so game-breaking.

Over all I would give it 7/10 (quite good, does what it should).

author: {'steamid': '76561197987792526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1422198656}
review:
Im gonna list you my pros and cons, why i like this game so you can decide if you like it or not:

+solely skill based combat: no pay to win; different swords of the same type are only cosmetic
+relatively big and active community: you will nearly always find someone to fight on the official servers
+workshop content: costumizing your char is very easy and brings a lot af variety to the game
+many classes: though "only" 5 playable chars (of which one is currently dec. 2014 unbalanced) you get to choose your own playstyle with them
+5 sword types: each sword type has its own properties and gives you even more possible styles (25 different char+sword combos, though not all make sense ;D)
- from time to time you will run across some elitist players, who are cursing at you for beeing a noob, but wont tell you how to get better (yet still better than in many other games....)
- only "singleplayer" option is either the tutorial or the duel-training bots, so no FFA, Hero or capture mode when youre all alone :(

so in total a really good game, which still has a few small edges and therefore an absolute recommendation!

review:
well....

it's an online game.
wich make me a rather dissapointed. it's not that i dont play online game, 
but i feel rather cheated with the reviews (mostly positive) and yet
there is no single explanation that this is an ONLINE PVP GAME ONLY.
or i might just lost in translation.

so, this game goes to list of  unplayable games  i bought on steam. well, there are other games i bought that is not enjoyable for me. but this is the first game i found over praised by many reviews. 

the game mechanic is promising, but, with only other users as your opponent. it just feel that the game is in unfinished state...
so much thing can be develope within the game mechanic. yet, its just throw a pvp only?

i migth not be fair to the developer, but if the game is an online game, please state so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964636674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1096, 'last_played': 1419991152}
review:
Parry, parry. Thrust, thrust. Good! 

Unique game all about dueling. 

Combat is effectively rock-paper-scissors with timing and placement involved, but, well, with swords! It's a lot of fun, especially if you like to learn new strategies to finally beat that one guy/gal who seems unbeatable. Chances are, you will get pummeled now and then, but if you stick with it and practice a bit, Blade Symphony can be a different experience and quite enjoyable game. 

There are currently 5 different characters with whom you can use 5 different weapon types. Moves are determined by the characters, while weapon types adjust effects, strength, recovery speed, and the defensive action. Roughly, each character has around probably 50+ different attacks (including charge tiers). 

The game uses Steam Workshop and so there are many cosmetic options in game, not only for weapons, but for armor as well. You can toggle workshop items visibility for yourself and for what you see on other players. Fight with twigs or a giant fork if you'd like. 

There are three map modes, Free-for-All, Control Point, and Duel. In FFA, everyone can run around the map and issue duel challenges, like an open lobby, CP maps are a little silly, but fun, team based matches, and Duel maps players take turns to duel, one pair at a time. Presently, one of the maps does seem to have a memory leak in it, and so if you're on that map you may need to restart your client occassionly. 

Blade Symphony is definitely worth checking out if you're interested in competitive 1v1 games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095712914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1470878155}
review: love this game! Really relies on skill and looking for faults in your opponent's attack. Many different playstyles as well, which can really increase the amount of depth and strategy that goes into your loadout. The music, different maps, and characters really bring out the game's uniqueness and kung fu vibe. Character customization is also really cool, with steam workshop items making it even more fun. Only problem that I have with steam workshop is that there simply isn't enough things to download from there, I want more!! Also, my notes (which is the currency) reset from time to time, which does get annoying (I heard that they are being restored). Overall though, an extremely fun game with an immervsive atmosphere that anyone can learn to love.

review: Blade Symphony has a truly unique combat system whose innovative design makes every battle tangibly different, so the game never gets old. Additionally, the passionate and competitive community really fuels one's desire to hone their skills and rank up. This, combined with a ton of purely cosmetic unlockables including steam workshop content (meaning you have to rely on skill and not equipment) makes Blade Symphony's hour-value massive, well worth it's price. If you're looking for an innovative, competitive fighting game, look no further than Blade Symphony. :)

Can't stop playing, 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046140796', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1538390638}
review:
-Log In
-Try to find active server.
-Lower standards.
-Try to find active server....and find one.
-Server is laggy. Complain about lag.
-Finally find someone to fight.
-Challenge them.
-Dance around and think about trying complex combos and beautiful movesets.
-Use only two moves the entire fight because it's not worth it.
-Lower significant amount of opponent's health.
-Lose anyway because of sudden frames drop and high ping.
-------------
To me, this is [what should've been] Dark Souls meets Souls Calibur. That's the common comparison.
Every attack should be strategic and thought out, but due to several moves being broken, terrible and sudden latency issues or frame drops, and overall terrible hitbox detection....you're going to end up using maybe 1/5 of those moves instead just so you can finally hit your opponent.

5.5/10
Amazing idea. Terrible execution.
If you want a game that plays like Dark Souls and Soul Calibur, go get Dark Souls or Soul Calibur instead.
Or Chivalry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964737001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1419280386}
review:
I was quite skeptical with this game after having played Chivalry, but I must say I was quite impressed. It feels good and fair (although sometimes you're not quite sure what's going on), it's highly tactical and the community is very decent. There's quite a few characters and weapons to choose from depending on your play style, so iit's quite adaptative, too.

Recommended if you're tired of every other rehash of a rehash and you want to try something different!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003836545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 2081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1604787687}
review:
This is not  a game I could ever recommend, especially to a new player.
The community is pretty much dead (and there is a reason for that, but I feel like other reviewers have explained it way better than me as to why that is the case) and the people who are left are veteran players who are not the people you'd want to spend your afternoon with.

It would have been a fun game if it had single player, but in it's current state it feels like you are playing Street Fighter 4 online against top tier players who keep telling you that you should quit.

EDIT: Read this if you want to see some examples http://steamcommunity.com/app/225600/discussions/0/598198356194639372/#p1

author: {'steamid': '76561197988817117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1413589760}
review: POssibly the worst sword fighting game I have ever played. Basically billed a s a new way of sword fighting but i 've seen eveything here before. Its controls very sluggishly, basic counters and blocks are close to impossible to time. There is a strange rock paper scissors system in place which turns the game into a fight style cycling arms race.  Basically I am glad I got to try it for free, had I paid money I would have been pretty pissed!.   If you want sword fighting on PC you have three options at the moment.Chivalry is fun but simple. MOunt and blade is fun but simple or Bushido Blade 2 on a PSX emulator. SO far Bushido Blade 2 is still the best. Why is it better than Blade Symphony?  Its flows. In a real sword fight fighters do not stop start. They do not combo, the attack and defend, parry and counter fluidly. In Blade Symphony there is no fluid motion. Its all good having a workshop full of swords but if your core mechanics are broken, whats the point. No go download a PSX emulator, get hold of Bushido Blade 2 and give it a go.   YOu have two buttuns two attack. And the whole game is about timing but unlike Blade Symphony where you have either success or fail, you have different levels of success and fail. ANd as you can respond instantly what you end up with in Bushido Blade2 is a realistic back and forth sword fight that can end instanly and suddenly. BB2 takes a while to master but it is worth your effort, unlike Blade Symphony..

author: {'steamid': '76561198048554394', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1414358715}
review:
[h1] A Beautiful Game with Okay Fighting Mechanics [/h1]

[b] Blade Symphony [/b] isn't a bad game by any means. It's got a unique and likeable visual style, and the fighting mechanics are a sort of easy to learn, difficult to master thing, but it just doesn't draw me in like other sword fighting games. The actual fighting itself focuses around switching styles in combat to make different combos (or at least thats what I could gather from it) and while thats an interesting system, it just isn't that satisfying in my opinion. From a majority of the reviews I've read say that the fighting mechanics are similar to that of [b] Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy [/b] which isn't necessarily wrong, but I wouldn't say that its 100% correct either. Base Jedi Academy's saber system was fun, but had quite a few issues. It got to the point where it became more about hack n' slashing than actual combos, which is where this game strikes up the resemblance. You [I] can [/I] do combos, but it is by no means required. Now, a mod for Jedi Academy called [b] MovieBattles II [/b] refines the system and makes it a lot less hack n' slash and makes it a lot more combo focused. Meaning that the premise is to basically drains the opponents BP (Block Points) by hitting them more than they hit you, which requires precision and a lot of practice. Blade Symphony starts off looking promising but starts to trail off into the sort of, "It's okay. Not great, but okay." area. Which isn't a bad thing. While I don't think that $14.99 is exactly what this game is worth, considering you can get Jedi Academy for $9.99 and download the MoveBattles II mod and get a lot more mechanically sound system. From what I can tell a lot of people enjoy this game a lot, but I conclude my judgment of the game with a very content [b] meh [/b]. The game is okay, and you might be into it's fighting system, I for one, am not. The game itself isn't bad, and is worth the buy if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102103384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1425754431}
review:
This game is a 1v1 / 2v2 duel-type sword game. Since the update the framerate has been choppy as heck. There are numerous swords and characters with different fighting style but in the end it doensn't matter. 

Do you like getting destroyed online? Play this game then.  You finish the tutorial which is a good walkthrough of the basics and then you say to yourself : Let's play against other new players right?!   WRONG. DEAD WRONG.  This game has NO matchmaking of any sort from what I can tell and you're pitted against people who have hundreds upon hundreds of hours played. Most of the time they will destroy you without you damaging them and then insult and ridicule you because they're better. 

The community in this game is utter s***. Most players I've come across were quite younger than me and frankly their parents did a cruddy job raising them.  Think of it as playing CS:GO and your first competitive match ever you play against Legendary Eagles. Not Fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998364426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 19357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12037, 'last_played': 1552018902}
review:
I like blade symphony with 10 people or 100 people, there I said it, what are you going to do shoot me?

Aight let me lay down this thick dish of sweet and sour soup for you boys, blade symphony is a 3D fighting game, it means you got a lot more directions than a 2D one.

The game doesn't really mater to be honest, the reason it is fun is because of the players you fight, it's the competitive nature that makes you want to play blade symphony which is the reason why people snap at you, the only reason they play is to win. The game is really well built, its a solid game what can I say, sure the animations could use more work but it is very structurally sound, meaning it's perfect for a fighting game.

Its pretty damn balanced, meaning people will always find different things to bitch about rather than uniteing over something being over-powered. Yeah people will agree that vanguard and longsword is overpowered, but after that it seems like free reign.

So what's  my point? Well my point is, if you don't like a hardcore competitive nature in a game, then this is not for you. Hell at first I didn't like blade symphony untill I invested 10 hours into it, then it became like crack cocaine. It is not a game where you can cheese your way to victory over the best players, you have to actually improve at the game meaning that something that works again lesser skilled players doesn't work against the best.

The game has a pretty weird learning curve, I feel like at first it is not steep at all because your like "O boy this oak doesn't know what's comeing with my N1 heavy left and right phalanx play" but after that it is very steep once you realise that playstyle isn't a very viable way to play the game. So listen here buddy boy it gets harder, but I know you can pull through it, just like you pulled through reading this much bull-crap that doesn't matter. After you get over that and you realise that judge is the best charecter obviously and every other one is for shitlords, then you start haveing some real fun and you can dish out your e-peen among skeleton and zeo and watch them strip you bare and cold in the russian winter.

So what is my actual point, well, it's a game for people who want to be competitive in a pretty balanced game. You have to roll with the punches baby boy.

The reason I'm not reviewing the game so much as reviewing you is because this is simply one of the best games I have ever have the pleasure of playing, it is a gem covered in dirt in the middle of a secret ravine full of bipolar neckbeards. There are flaws but they are only apparent when you just start playing, as you play more and more you start to see it as this holy image of a perfect game.

The reason I see it like this is because it is just so damn solid overall, you have different ways of playing different charecters and you can try and make your way work. It is rage enduseing but in the good kind of way I guess. There are different sword types, attack paterns, since it's 3D you have different ways people manuver creating very interesting gameplay.

So to conclude this great speech of nothingness I guess it's up to you if you want to buy this game or not, hell I don't know if you will like it. You can take my word but I'm probably wrong maybe, if you tried this game and didn't like it, come back and give it a second chance please, it truly is a game that the community makes, and even with a small community it still is fun. Buy the game if you havn't right now its 9$, 200 hours is worth that money any day.

tl;dr: Me and zeo are actually secret lovers in a alternate reality

review:
This game is a great amount of fun. Nice visuals, soothing soundtrack, good community, AI isn't completely stupid. It's truly a great game.
I would recommend this to anyone who doesn't hate fun to be honest. The only complaints I have for this game are that it's a multiplayer-focused game, but that's alright because it's fun and the bots are actually OK, and the multiplayer community is very small. There are plenty of servers but only a few have people who are ever on.
So if you are thinking of picking up this game, absolutely do it and tell your friends to as well. This is a great game and needs more publicity. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055936225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1421189171}
review:
I enjoy this game alot.  I was a big jedi knight 2 and jedi academy player, and was looking for something similar.  When it comes to sword play thats more than hack and slash there isnt alot out there.  I found blade symphony and gave it a shot.  I think its a very inovative and well done combat system.  I spent some time(an afternoon) offline fighting an ai opponent and then 2 ai opponents untill I felt I had mastered enough of it, then went online.  I can see what some people are saying about this game being hard to break into for new player, but I havnt had much trouble.  The bigest things to remember are distance and timing, which the game assists you with a lot via the blue line that projects the path of your swing.  I was running into players ranging in rank from 200 to 30000, and was able to hold my own against them all.  I still may not know the finer points but I wasnt experiancing these one sided battles Ive read about.  

I would like to see the devs start to expand on the game more, or expand on the creation tools the players ahve so its a bit easier to create custom skins.  SOme additional game types would be good too, but at its heart its a 1v1 fighter so I can see how that oculd be hard.  

For me 7/10 Compared to jk2s 9/10

review:
This game is not like any I've played. I'm not used to playing third-person sword wielding games, so playing the training was frustrating at times and I've cheeted a few hits in just to get past the training. also, there are many hit forms - too much for my taste.

 It felt too complicated for me. I'm not used to this kind of gaming style with so much options to defeat your enemy. I think it should have a demo so people can get a first hand impression (maybe the training or one hour of free play).

 It is CS but with sword ( If I understand it correctly) - you learn how to fight and then go against others to win

bottom line - It is an interesting concept, not for me, but maybe for others, So I vote [b]Yes[/b]
