author: {'steamid': '76561198074426610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2334, 'last_played': 1448589348}
review:
When I first saw Blade Symphony on the Steam Store‚Äôs featured page, it was an Early Access title. It looked interesting to me, and I thought about purchasing it. But at the time, I spent that money on DayZ instead, also an Early Access title. DayZ held much more interest to me than Blade Symphony. However, now that this game has been fully released with an Original Soundtrack, and after playing it for a while, I regret I didn't spend that money on Blade Symphony. Some, probably most, will find it unfair since this is the full release of Blade Symphony and DayZ is still in Early Access. But the truth is, you can barely compare the two games because they share very few things in common anyway.

Blade Symphony is a third-person PVP melee combat game, with skill-orientated swordfighting. It takes place in a universe called Berimbau, its history stretches back ‚Äúthousands of years, to a handful of warring clans that ultimately came to peace terms and unified under a single flag: The Black Rose." There‚Äôs more story, which is why I‚Äôm hoping for a possible campaign down the road. If you want to know more story look it up or buy the game with the OST.

The player has four stances during combat: Fast, Balanced, Heavy, and Air (when one jumps). Each stance has different types of attacks/sword strokes, and one can use even more using the movement keys while attacking at the same time, like slashing to the sides. There is also a Rock-Paper-Scissors system for parrying (parrying occurs when blades collide as they‚Äôre both being swung at the same time), Heavy stance is beat in parry by the Air stance, Balanced stance is beat in parry by Heavy stance, Fast stance is beat in parry by Balanced stance, and Air stance is beat in parry by Fast stance. If both stances are the same, they both cancel out. You can switch stances mid-combo and produce a unique combination of attacks as well. The character can run, strafe, dash (includes power-dash), roll, and wall-walking/wall flips (parkour). With all this combined, the game requires skill and tactical thought. It is not an easy game to play, and there are very good players out there. You need to pay attention and you need to be quick, timing is everything. The four classes at your disposal all have unique traits and moves, choose wisely: Phalanx, the one who lunges and thrusts, fencing style. He can close in quickly and has great reach. Judgement, the one who has thick metal armour and prefers big swings. He is slow, but can take hits that would normally greatly damage other classes and he hits harder than a bulldoser. Ryoku, the one who uses rhythm and breakdancing to fight in a unique way. He moves around erratically confusing his opponents, and hits fast and quickly (pretty strong hits too). And last but surely not least, Pure, the one who is heavily influenced by Chinese Wushu, an acrobatic exhibition and full-contact sport derived from traditional martial arts. She can make use of her acrobatics to move past an enemy‚Äôs defense and strike fluidly.

Now let‚Äôs talk graphics. This game is [b]extremely[/b] beautiful. The sword models were the first thing that caught my eye after launching the game, with awesome shots of swords and swordsmen up close and wide all over the home screen. I am satisfied with the texture‚Äôs resolutions on everything in the game. The character models are also very well modeled. The maps are rendered wonderfully, some being fairly big and mildly-explorable in their own right. The particle effects while fighting are bright, but subtle, and they fade away as fast as they appear which makes the fights look nicer and better overall. The developers did a good job optimizing the game as well, I can max out the graphical settings on my humble gaming laptop and it runs perfectly. Oh btw, spectating on a duel is a sight to behold.

Then there is the game‚Äôs Original Soundtrack, which is, in my opinion, one of the better video game soundtracks I‚Äôve heard. It has a traditional Japanese/Chinese mood to it, but there is hints of western influence in there, as well as more modern sounds like EDM. The OST comes with a text file that expresses the fact that the game‚Äôs story is not told through the gameplay, ‚ÄúWho are these sword-wielding badasses and why are they killing each other through Asian temples, European courtyards, or city-streets?‚Äù says the credits and thanks.txt file, the album implicitly tells this story, which I briefly explained in the second paragraph.

The game also offers its share of customization, with unlockable cosmetics such as masks and capes. One can also change the default colours of the character model. The game is also a part of Steam Workshop, so people can make their own swords and add to the 25+ swords that the game already has in store for you to use. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a lack of variety at all, you‚Äôre able to customize a character enough to make it your own. And if one is part of a private server, the customization to the whole game is nearly endless.

The game is fun, challenging, and beautiful.
[h1]It's also dead.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198076423917', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1619, 'last_played': 1538283786}
review:
I would love to recommend this game! The combat is really unique and feels fun to play. The visuals are also very appealing, even for a game that was released 4 years ago. The music can also be very atmospheric. All in all, this game is very good.

Unfortunately, no one plays this game anymore, and there's no real single player content to help practice.

All in all, how can a fighting game be good when there's no one to play with?

author: {'steamid': '76561198012638504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1400170393}
review:
So this game was like 15% off a while ago and i like swordfighting etc so i bought it.
I am afraid i can't recommend the game YET.
So far, my experience with the game is very lineair: The gameplay is hack n slash.
You can choose between different classes, but every fight always ends up in a "who can mash LMB the fastest".
Then there's the combat system which allows you to do fast, balanced and heavy slashes. This was in fact a good gameplay mechanic, just not executed very well.
It's a game i have started up maybe twice, then never got back to it because it just wasn't what i wanted.
However, i believe the game has potential to be a good swordfighting game in the future.
What i think should change:
- Make combat less animation based and more efficient
- Make the game an actual skill-based fighter, not a hack n slash
- More gamemodes

Thanks for reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025188158', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1552516791}
review:
This game is awesome. As of now there are 4 classes with extremely unique fighting styles. You duel in beautifully designed arenas using super sweet swords. Combat is clean and interesting. It's a little tricky to get used to at first but getting used to chaining moves is very interesting. 
Cosmetics clothing and weapons can be purchased with points slowly earned in game over time (no pay to win!) but who cares when the steam workshop is pouring out your favorite video game and anime weapons for free download (it's super easy too)!

This game is still young and it's updating regularly, but it's already an amazing game. Seriously, check out the workshop and get all the awesome weaponry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045117443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1400385239}
review:
When i saw blade i was so happy to get it, but it just fell flat and was terrible in general. the hit animation are terrible and do not register when it clearly looks like u hit your enemy. It fail to deliver a fighting game its more like a hack and slash and just spamming your mouse and hopping around until u just get bored which brings me to another topic its to boring, first few hours yea its fun and after that. CONGRATULATIONS you pretty muched did everything you can do in this game. I also just find this game unfair in many ways when all classes are unbalanced, most of the time u either spam with a fast guy or charge your heavy stance and hop around, thats the only tatics ive been seeing the whole time. and the combos and animations are exploited and abused by quote on quote veterans of the game. For example u see a master or diamond rank guy all they usually do is spam the crap out of the attacks over and over.It also can be the other way around anyone can spam the crap out of there enemy or just hop around and smack there enemy around.  also once again the hit animations dont register most of the time when u for sure smakced your enemy but it doesnt register. honestly the customization i ok or average, and thats about the only thing good about it. 


In short this game fails to be a fighting game and only proves to be a hack n slash and a terrible one at that. 


1. the game fighting animation is broken and clunky
2.its boring only good for an hour
3.Quote on quote veterans and or new comers just spam which anyone can do
4.Customization is ok to average
5.all classes are unbalanced and prove no fairness or diversity to this game 
6.alot of ppl abuse the hit box animation once they figure it out 
7. the community is in general bad and making the game worse and hard to enjoy
8.this game doesnt act to be a fighting game more of a hack n slash and a bad one 
9.why isnt this game free with all the bugs and cons it has 
10.waste of time to even having a good time most of the time 
11. clunky and just dull

I honestly just dont recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039577189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1400385134}
review: When i saw this game i was hyped for the cool sword play and community that i thought it would have but it all falls flat. The games fighting mechanic is the easiest to exploit. The hit registration is bad to the point where i cant even land one hit on my opponent. This game tries to add in different fighting stances for a different play style each time but only two of the three are useful. You're also able to cancel animations which all the veterans take advantage of in order to beat their opponent and doing so will give the new players a fun time fo being stun locked and not being able to swing their weapon at all. Now the community of this game seemed cool with the addition of the workshop to get cool new weapons but thats the only good part about it. the community so far is a bunch of cocky 12 year olds that refuse to get off the game calling you bad for not being able to lay a hit on them with the bad hit detection and the animation canceling. This game is not worth $15, not even for the price of $10 like it was during the sale. This game should be free to play but even then the game will still not be worth the hard drive space. Basically what im trying to say is the game tries its best to be a fighting game but it is one poorly executed hack and slash.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024017743', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1448609326}
review: THis is a little similar to Mortal combat and injustice game but a little more "ninja like". I honsetly think this game is better than some other fighter games cause it has combos that you can do to destroy your enemy and 10 people fighting each other! It is great over all

author: {'steamid': '76561198013590029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1268, 'last_played': 1432748969}
review: This is the first sword play pvp game that I have found fun from the get go. It has a variety of weapons to use. Each with their ups and downs and all of them are customizable via steam workshop as well as the mask. The play style as of right now is very balanced and fluid. Everything depends on your timing and skill once you learn the game's tips and tricks. Definitely a must try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960956246', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 2213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2154, 'last_played': 1402471259}
review:
Pros: A fun and somewhat-realistic sword fighting game, from what I can tell. I don't really know much about swordplay but the sword arts seem pretty realistic. Nice workshop support. Regional servers to choose from, frequent events, VAC secured.

Cons: Not a very good fighting game. Predictable opponents are still very difficult to defeat despite a built in rock-paper-scissors counter system. Many attacks have a deceptively small range while others have an equally deceptive and explosive range. Attacks seem to sometimes go straight through your opponent. Hit and block stun are well off at times, leaving you vulnerable when you hit your opponent and unable to counter when you block. All of this makes for a highly frustrating experience.

There's also a very limited number of fighters to choose from, as well as weapon types. They're not very well balanced either making for some false choices on the customize/character select screen.

Mixed: Rather undecided about how I feel about the community. Very loyal, sometimes helpful, sometimes respectful... other times not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045910264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1490196603}
review: A 3D fighting game that takes place in a 3D environment involving sword play, controls are easy to learn and it is a very rewarding feeling when you kill a guy. Things to unlock and good workshop support make this a fun game to play, bear in mind this is a multilayer game and I would not recommend if you do not wish to play online.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022711313', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1418491954}
review:
I originally bought Blade Symphony based on the trailer alone (and it was on sale) back when it was in an early development stage. The combat system looked really cool and different and it is. The combat is very easy to pick up. Complete noobs could just point and click like crazy and look like they know what they're doing; however, they'll probably lose, because the talent in the combat besides the combos and cool jumping tricks is knowing when to attack which is more important in this game that other fighting games I've played.

And that's probably all people need. But there's absolutely no single player experience at all and the last time I played, lag was somewhat of an issue still. I also didn't notice too much different between the current version and the version I played when it was still in early development other than the AI opponents were added (and I'm assuming that a lot of glitches were fixed, but tell me what else I‚Äôm missing). The AI opponents are laughable since they won't really help you get better being that you can beat them by doing the noob strategy I mentioned earlier.

Overall, if all you want is a competitive online multiplayer game then you should be fine. But if you wanted something more than this isn‚Äôt for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042140467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1635055242}
review: Ok let's write a review. I bought this game completely on a whim. The main reason for that was because it said blade and I thought.. why the hell not right? I booted it up and thought to myself, this game probably wont turn out to be what I thought it was. Wrong. This game is more than I thought it was. If you have ever played the game The Deadliest Warrior it plays like that but with a lot more skill involved, and its also a hell lot more fun. The controls are quite simple.. Strafe, move, roll, jump, swing and attack. However, the complexity comes when fighting skilled opponents. Parrying, blocking, and counters are all neccessary to win a battle and I find myself keeping a close eye on my enemy's stance throughout the match. Oh, stances by the way are different attacking styles.. Fast, Balanced, and Heavy.. I'm sure you can understand what each means. Comboing attacks between different stances is part of why I enjoy it. Go it fast, but then turn into a heavy swing to throw them off guard. No fight is the same really. Each person has their tactic, playstyle, character, weapon of choice and so on. In conclusion, this game is great and worth the penny. I do wish there were some more gamemodes.. FFA, Duel, and Hero seem to be the only ones i think or at least the only ones i've played and seen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089359892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1439417836}

author: {'steamid': '76561197961904441', 'num_games_owned': 2066, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1430886585}
review: This game has really hammered home for me that I don't get on with 3D fighting games. I played with a controller and had to constantly baby the camera and overal my experience was pretty poor. A friend enjoyed it better using a keyboard and mouse so your mileage may vary. The game as it stands feels very loose, it appears any attack can parry any attack so why do anything but attack? I may be skimming over the finer points, and missing out on the deeper sections of this figthing game but until I see some decent instruction on how to play this game effectively I don't think I shall bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982576939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1434893662}
review:
Blade Symphony is what I'd call enjoyable, because it has a pretty interesting way of allowing people to swordfight. Currently not much can be said about the game rather than it being unfinished. While this isn't unusual for early access games, the progress the developers have been making seems remarkably slow.

The community isn't particularly big and it can be a challenge to find a low ping server, as most the community seems to be American at the time of writing.

While it is a fun game, I wouldn't recommend buying it simply because I don't see it being finished anytime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039973118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1434724484}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062323770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1529261367}
review:
You've got two options: either you buttonmash or you kick some buttonmasher ass. It's all about getting your perfect character-sword combination to match your playing type and then studying your opponent to see which of your attacks work best with him. 

This game was very well made considering the diferent playing style each player has. You want a powerful heavy blow with good bombo formations? It's Judgment with a longsword. You like direct hits and like having a well set out plan for attack? Hook yourself up with a Phalanx wielding a Rapier. You're not too good with strategies but like fast and quite strong attacks? That's a Ryoku holding a Scmitar you need. 

Wall riding plus dash and roll make your movements appeal to your playing style as well. You can become very powerful if you master your movements and use them propperly. 

This game makes swordfighting something beautiful and stylish. And don't even get me started on the designs. They are beautiful considering the actual game they are used in. 

The workshop, while still small, gives you a lot of options to choose from. Uploading to the workshop is very easy as well. You can go with a serious style or you can always pop in a TV head.

I give it a 9/10. It could go higer with further updates. It could go lower when I finally realize how biased this oppinion might be because, I must admit, i'm in quite a hype after buying this game. If you like swords over guns, strategy over violence and third person over first person, then, my friend, this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125830461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1401563310}
review:
This recommendation is not a yes, it's a HELL YES

One thing before this, devs, make a replay system with a more engaging offline system like tournaments. Ooooo! And try to have a replay system to spectate, this battles really need to be taken by pictures.

But to start it off, I have played this game for 4 hours, only four hours, I got it just two days ago on steam sales. Getting this game for 5 dollars less makes me depress only because this game NEEDS more respect and money. This thing deserves every penny put into the price.  That sale was a steal man, but the looks are not the only thing, (Beside the running on invisible walls when outside on a specific map) the acrobatics are phenomenal, when you get pushed back to a wall, run up and jump off to turn the tables. This system is different that any traditional fighting game I have ever seen besides the best two of three. Your class is not in any way more superior, it's only what fits you the most. Would you like to duel it out with an enemy? Or would you like to go on an FFA server to challange enemies to show your superiority? And I'm positive that more content will be put in the game as it progresses, get it while you can.

The game came out pretty smooth, not BF4 bad, never has crashed or done something out of the blue except for front flip corpes which only are funny and don't really do anything annoying. Other than that it's clean, but this is only for my four hours of gameplay, and hell yes I'm going to play some more.

I truly believe if this game continues on its trails, it could be a new bar for fighting games out there. 100-- wait no 200% recommendation because it's a HELL YES, not a.....yes.....

author: {'steamid': '76561197981714624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1556984431}
review:
To begin with, I bought and started playing Blade Symphony because of the multiple 'Recommended' reviews given to the game. I honestly have to say that so far it is money worth spent.

The game has incredible, deep combat mechanics which allow you to attack your opponent basically however you want. You choose the angle, direction and type of attack, depending on the one of three stances you are using. Even more, you can dynamically combine attacks specific to each stance into new, unique combos.

The audio-video aspect of the game is also very fitting. Graphics are futuristic and top-notch with all of the flashy effects one would expect from current gaming titles, still not requiring that much from your rig. Your fights are accompanied by delicate tunes of various Asian instruments, setting a proper mood.

The game itself is completely skill-based. You cannot buy yourself victory by equipping glowing swords and armors or powering yourself up with cash-shop boosts. No such things exist here! The additions you can buy with in-game currency are purely cosmetic and define your look and style more than combat prowess.

In all honesty I hope this title will get the acclaim and popularity it deserves and will become an e-sport in the future. It trully touched the honorable swordsman in me :).

author: {'steamid': '76561198089776149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1438423954}
review:
On the whole this game is okay, but initial impressions, I nearly chose to uninstalled. I dunno if it's just that I sucked in the beginning or if you're NOT SUPPOSED to win cos I've had it for a while now and I have just had my first victory online. And that's real frustrating cos without wins you can't upgrade your character. 
The combat moves look pretty cool and slick and there's definitely some skills to be proud of, but only if the moves are actually done correctly to the nanosecond. If not, you can expect to die pretty quickly in the duals (in training or online).
First impressions on the online game lobby were that it was just a mess of numbers and titles. Took me ages to work it all out, so I would not call it new-user friendly. 
Until a couple of my friends joined, I was losing dual after dual which was a real downer cos I felt terrible. 
In the training, I can't find a dificulty setting. For some people, this might mean a choice of either: hard, hard or impossible which doesn't really help, unless you got friends who are kind enough to 'train' you in a private dual online. 
Customization options are pretty decent, leveling up with currency to 'buy' new gear seems fair in most games like this. But if you're like me and suck at the beginning you gonna need a LOT of patience. 
Tutorials can be a bit misleading; yes, they do teach you how to swing a sword but there's more that had to be learnt outside of the tutorials if you want to stand a chance online. AKA learning the hard way. 

Suggestion for Improvement:
What would make this game a touch more attractive is if at the end of dual, the game played a badass slow-mo of the killing strike, like they do in Skyrim or LOTR: War in the North.
Another would be just liven up the online lobby a little bit, when you first enter, it can be like looking at a psuedo-code programming. Black and white, parenthesis and anacronyms everywhere. Just jargon that had to be researched to make sense of.

Bottom line: for the adept rpg "swordsy" gamer, this game would be awesome. But if you're like me and a newby, patience is key. And if you don't have that, don't waste your shinies on this game cos there are way better ones out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043891125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1426399996}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013095772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1445390462}
review:
Pros-
+Great Graphics
+Fluid combat
+Many combos
+Different playstyles with swords/fighters
+Many different gamemodes (dual, 2v2, freefight)

Cons-
-Small network problems can really break immersion
-Steep learning curve
-Not many dedicated servers

author: {'steamid': '76561198092188754', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1400733572}
review:
With an awesome combat system and large amount of community support this game could have a long life ahead of it. Could, not does. The life expectancy of this game will drop off dramatically when the community for it drops and mod development progress no longer exists. Seeing the community so far this could begin to grow into a great game, but we'll have to wait and see.
As for everything the game offers outside of the mod support, a great combat system, fun and intense PvP and the possible addition of more characters and other content in the future.
Final verdict: Should you buy this game? If you like pvp fighting games then absolutley yes. If not so much then you can wait until the game at least goes on sale again or more content gets added in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040294072', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1844, 'last_played': 1460292028}
review:
First review I have done for a game. 

While I like the idea, and do belive this game does a good job at execution, I strongly hope the developers are working on the competitive aspect of this game. When you play games like this, you want to become skilled, you want a stats that show you how well you are doing compared to others. While this game does offer that, it offers it in a very lackluster way. To a new player it is very hard to know what server is ranked and what isn't, causing most people to have a bad w/l ratio from the begining. Past that you can ONLY get elo from people in your divison, which is ridiculos. You can lose to someone 3 divions below you, or in return beat someone 3 divions above you and get nothing. Second off your rank is based on your world chart rank. Diamond is the top 2-10%, and master is the top 1%. This means that the longer the ladder is up, the harder it is to get division promotions, what sound like a good thing is acctualy a very horrible thing, as the game does something very stupid to help new players get diamond/master.

When you win/lose a game, you gain/lose mmr bassed on your "expected" performence against that player. Lots of variables are used, their w/l, your w/l, their elo, your elo, and worse of all... time. If you play ranked constantly you will start gaining little to no elo, making it impossible to rank up.

The ranked system is complete trash, you can go from oak-iron-diamond-master-oak all in one day, and it fels extremly unrewarding. It needs a massive improvment, along with a better matchmaking system. Overall its a solid game, but the ranked system is in DIRE need of work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026837461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1904, 'last_played': 1400100003}
review:
Blade symphony is a bad game with an identical community. Why the game is bad results in the characters, the duels, and the ranks/ladder. The characters are bland, and can be even claimed as "generic". All of them have the ability spam their fast combo, which is what 75% of the community does anyway.

 All the characters have different play styles, which might sound good but they're all just awfully cheap. Pure is all about strafing their attacks in a sideways direction to hit. Ryouko is spin/spam to win. Phalnax is pure fast combo poking spam with a little bit of timing. Judge is timing, and heavy damage spamming with the balanced combo. Each is used in a cheap way, which makes the experience of the game unrealistic and frustrating. 

The Duels are not smooth at all, considering the cheesy animations and the constant spam. To win, its basically who can spam faster. All duesl are the same, as no one uses wall jumping or parkour in general for an advantage, and you're even looked down on by the annoying community.

The ranks and ladder system is sad after this new update. I have gotten to a master rank after 24 hours of gameplay. Tells you how easy it is to get to the top, and when you get there it would probably lead to boredom. You dont gain a sense of achievement, as many other players just aren't good, and they somehow gain high ranks (possibly through spamming)

To end off, all talk about the community. Generally, most people will cry when a fight is won, or the claim "gg" which is completely fine. Its a 50 - 50 ratio between the two, which is not too bad. The worst part of the community is their maturity. I generally go on and theres plenty of mic spammers, and people who cry about it and don't realize theres a mute button, which might be the only useful thing on the interface. Another person you will find, is, "The Master". These people roleplay as a super good samurai otaku weeaboo, or they'll act rude and type during a match things like "kek did you think that would work" and then spam you to death with a pure strafing move. Overall, it's a circlejerk of scrub-tard roleplayers and spammers.

TL;DR: Dont buy the game, unless on sale. Bad community, bad characters, bad game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975901751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1422249240}
review: Very fun. Takes a bit of getting used to, but once you get the hang of the systems, it's a very delicate balance of timing and tactics. Also swords. It's a multiplayer swordfighting game, what more do you need?

author: {'steamid': '76561197982445442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1134, 'last_played': 1388373302}
review:
Blade Symphony started out with huge potential and the developers quickly destroyed that. 

When i first played Blade Symphony you could think of it as a 3D fighting game. It revolved around movement, spacing and combos. The developers apparently didn't want the game to go in that direction. With each patch they've ruined the gameplay more and more. The movement options are now terrible, moves that should combo, do not, and the balancing of the game is awful. Defensive options are too strong and which makes offense too much of a chore. This makes the game slow and boring, unlike the quick, technical oriented style pre-alpha gameplay had. 

I definitely wouldn't recommend this game to any of my friends. The developers have no idea what they're doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027663819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1400043142}
review:
Blade Symphony promises a fun deep sword combat game, and instead delivers:

- An extremely poor tutorial that tosses you into a bunch of situations without fully explaining them or your controls, giving incomplete instructions, and humiliating you with "simple" stuff that is too hard to do.
- Terrible, illogical naming and documentation. Why does "block" not block on half the swords, and which swords do what? What in the name of all that is good is a "string" and why do I care?  
- Poor, laggy control scheme. Expected better out of a game where timing is everything.
- Bad clipboxes
- Bad event detection (parry happening well after one player finished swinging, swings going through one another)

It feels like an extremely gimmicky game to be played only by its devs, or the few people determined enough to find out all the quirks making gameplay difficult. For the rest of us, it's an experiment in futile button mashing hoping you get the ever so elusive "timing" right. Count this sword hobbyist and gamer disappointed in this utter waste of money (even at its sale price)

author: {'steamid': '76561198066549056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1400198096}
review:
This game is great for people like me that love swords, but don't have the cash to go out and buy a bunch, or learn proper swordsmanship. This fighting game feels like a swordsmanship simulator. The main emphasis of the game is upon blocking and parrying. The more skilled you are at blocking, parrying, or feinting an attack, the better you will be at this game. This is a game about skill, and it is definitely not a button masher. Also, the community for this game is highly supportive with new mods constantly coming out. This game helps me get out my need to just want to swing a weapon around like a maniac! Truly an amazing game.

It's true that some of the characters have swordsmanship styles that are unconventional, and probably wouldn't work in real life, it's still an amazing game to play when you wanna lay a beatdown on someone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052316785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1437440759}
review:
Really awesome game! Definitely recommended to sword-fighting enthusiasts.

You will definitely have some questions about how the gameplay works after watching the trailer, so allow me to explain. There are three stances to choose from. You must select your stances in real time by pressing the buttons '1', '2', and '3'. The stances are fast, balanced, and heavy. In the beginning, you'll have to figure out which stance you're most comfortable with, but as you play, you'll grow to gain experience in all three stances (experience as in "personal" experience. There's no "leveling up" or anything). My personal favorite style is a slow-paced reactive control style using balanced with sudden spurs of heavy every now and then. The strategy that usually beats me is a well-timed aggressive fast stance.

There are several different styles of swords you can use, and several different classes. If my math is correct, I believe there are 20 unique core loudouts, with a lot of customization imbetween (including Steam Workshop gear, which is very user-friendly and easy to use). I am currently using a lightsaber that I found in the Workshop. :)

This is very much a game of skill, and very much a PvP game. There is no storyline or campaign. There are a very small number of maps, but the maps are well-designed for 1v1 duels. In Free For All mode, this game becomes very relaxing and satisfying. It can either be a chatroom for you and your friends, or you can private duel people. Even though the room title is FFA, it's not really treated like an FFA in most situations. Everyone usually prefers the 1v1 fair fights, which is a primary feature of this game. In FFA mode, you can challenge anyone you see in the room, and if they respond affirmatively, then you get locked into a best 2 out of 3 duel where no one else in the room is able to interrupt. Since everyone else on the map becomes these ghost-like figures that can't interact with you, multiple duels can be happening in the same area of the map at once. These 1v1 duels are definitely the primary appeal to this kind of game, which is why players in FFA don't usually attack each other except if they're in a duel, but it is possible to do so.

While I don't have a lot of hours in this game yet, it is definitely one I can see myself spending a lot of time on. It's a game without storyline-commitment. You don't have to set aside a certain amount of time, or read up on what the best line of play is to take etc... zero commitment, 100% log in, relax, and kill time with some juicy sword-fighting goodness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043895356', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1663769017}
review:
When I first saw the trailer for this game, I knew it was gonna be awesome. The ideas the developers put into this game are very creative and innovative towards the online fighting genre. It's not just a boring repetitive fight every time, the free roam you're given makes each match different and exciting. Four different types of warriors, each with their own unique skills and downfalls, along with different kinds of swords, each with their own mechanics. This game has just been released and theres already a great online community for this game and lots of different content on it's Workshop. Did I mention you can download custom swords and masks to customize your character with?
I thought this game was so good, I bought copies for 2 of my friends and they love it!

Some downfalls to this game are it's still a bit buggy, some of the character's sword range are a bit OP, and it's missing a chunk of content the game promised, like capes n such.  Nothing that hurts the game too bad, but I bet they'll update the game very soon.

Still, this game is awesome and I can't wait for what it has in store for it's community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041144202', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1400407128}
review:
This game has possibly the best challenge system that I've ever seen in its FFA mode. It's great for newcomers to be able to choose their opponents, and friendly training servers exist for you to get the hang of it with other people your skill level. There is great steam workshop integration to allow you to mess around with all the swords and masks that are player made easily and in game.

The combat system is awesome, I never really felt overwhelmed by it and after a few losses I learned all I needed to go on winning streaks. Easy to pick up yet still has some key secrets that you have to master.

This is a really enjoyable game, my only complaints would be about the low map variety.
Wait for a sale and pick this game up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998292632', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1408, 'last_played': 1402970041}
review: I love this game. I'm not big on fighting games, but this feels just right. Complex enough that it is going to require a good amount of skill and strategy to be very good at, but it's not too complicated. You don't have 50 different moves to memorize per character. The emphasis is not so much on which skill you use, but how you string those skills together. It places a great deal on timing and aim. If you're looking for an in-depth sword fighting game, checkity check this out. It also runs very smoothly on my slightly dated rig, but still looks pretty damn nice.

review: This game is quite hard but fun. Once you get used to a character and their movements it becomes a bit easier. This game requires a magnificient amount of skill and patience, as if you were actually a swordsman dueling another. It lacks a true single-player mode but a game like this thrives on multiplayer. Definitely a must-but if you want a game that's fun, challenging, and makes you feel like a badass. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198044364138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1430693609}
review:
They advertise "Tactical sword fighting," and they bring it.  There is no "right class" to play with and playing this game you do not feel like left clicking rapidly will be more effective than thinking.
This is the experience: you go in a server, join one of three rooms, and fight people.  If there are 3 people in a room, one watches while the other two fight and then plays the winner.  So if one guy is beating you repeatedly, you usually get to sit out and watch his moves as he beats another guy before it's your turn again.  And eventually you figure out what he's doing and put up a good fight--every fight with another player is like a boss battle.  Everybody fights differently and instead of getting mad at dying a lot I learned to figure out what my opponent was doing and try to counter his ways.
Very fun game, not necessarily a game for everybody but it definitely does what it advertises and that's what counts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015841151', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1383, 'last_played': 1434872650}
review: I bought this game while Pure was still in early development, and despite he radically unfinished nature, she was instantly my favorite character to play as. This game has an amazingly wide variety of attacks/combos and most of the community is well mannered and use the proper battle etiquette of bowing before and after a battle. I greatly appreciate all the work that has gone into this game and look forward to seeing it grow even more now that it's been officially released!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987239370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1399964343}
review:
Damn fine piece of work. Fun to just play, obviously will take some time to master. Rapiers are a bit op but overall the art style, the animation and the game dynamics all blend together nicely to make this a fine piece of work for poking someone else with a sword repeatedly til they die. Duel mode servers are awesome...community seems largely very cool as well.

This is definitely a game you can lose a lot of hours in, the action is fast, tactical and you can win or lose in an instant if you make the right or wrong move.

Fantastic job by Puny Human Studios and the pricetag for it is fantastic especially on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042613358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 6248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5685, 'last_played': 1403525330}
review:
Even though this game isn't in early access mode anymore, I'm pretty sure it isn't 100% finished yet. At least, I hope so. If you're really, really into sword fighting games, you might like this game, otherwise I wouldn't recommend it. So far, this game kept getting slower and slower. For example, you used to be able to jump high into the air and, even though it wasn't very polished yet, it did have a lot of potential. But now they made it so that you're barely able to jump over a curb anymore.

Okay, I get that that's just one of my preferences and there are probably some people who actually prefer jumping to be almost completely removed, except for triggering Air attacks, but there's a better reason for not playing this game: It has NO singleplayer mode (nor multiplayer PvE of any kind), which means that it's exclusively PvP. The problem is that there's just barely anybody to actually play against. You can literally run this game, check the server list, and see a maximum of about 11 people playing. On the same server. Which might be an American server too. Which isn't a very good thing if you're in Europe yourself. This game just doesn't get advertised, enough. It sometimes does have a small amount of people playing it, like right after the game goes on sale, but eventually people keep leaving and leaving until it's just the same handful of people who still play it consistently.


My conclusion:

If you're really into a game that exclusively offers you PvP sword fighting (with a little bit of dress up) and you don't care about any additional content, you might enjoy playing it for a while.

If you're just "curious" or think it "might be interesting" to you, I wouldn't recommend it, even if it's solely because of the almost non-existent player base.

(On a side note: I don't hate the developers of this game. I don't know that much about them, but they appear to be friendly people who really do care about their small playerbase, and even host small, official tournaments every now and then, with a unique item reward. I just don't think every update has been for the best.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198015466047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1412030596}
review:
I wish I could say I enjoyed this game, but that would be a lie.  I'm a fencer in real-life, so that coupled with the screenshots and trailer led me to have some high expectations for Blade Symphony.  The premise is strong, but it's executed very poorly, surprisingly.

The servers are usually unpopulated, and lag is persistent.  Yes, I've tried all the usual tricks to negate as much lag time as possible.  It did not change the result.  What follows is spotty hit detection and unexpected deaths.

The combat isn't simply hack'n'slash; it's more profund than that.  However, I learned the best path to vicotry involved that line of strategy....

The game is also very unforgiving to beginners.  I understand I'm a noob, but after ~100 duels, I can count on one hand how many of them I've won. I "am" going to blame the lag here, because I "know" I'm not THAT bad.  The customization doesn't come to the rescue because you have to win to attain a decent amount of points to unlock anything of value.  In my four hours of recorded playtime, I unlocked only one thing with my accumulation of the game's currency.

Overall, this adds up to playing the same people, getting your tail handed to you repeatedly, usually in a very inexplicable manner, and rarely changing your outfit to fit your playstyle.  It looks and sounds pretty, but that's not enough to have me recommend Blade Symphony to you.  And that hurts more than the unfair defeats. :-(

author: {'steamid': '76561198045931594', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1404332770}
review:
i went into this game not expecting too much, but i was surprised, its a fun fast paced game in which 1v1 versus with sword play
i liked it for the main reason. it feels like you have to be accurate, with your weapons rather then just bashing the hit button, you can parry, counter grab, its quite tactical having multiple stances which could give you an advantage over your enemy. There are also different weapons and customization for your characters which is a bonus. i recommend this to people that like hack and slash, fighting games. or anyone that justs wants to try something new.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056306288', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1147, 'last_played': 1409382590}
review:
I hated fighting games until now... Beautiful visuals and mechanics, If your a fan of Mount and Blade, Chivalry or the War Of series you will love this game, If your a fan of fighting games you will love this game. Also the community has been awesome so far, very mature and friendly comparable to the Americas Army community.

+1 for playing with a Dev

author: {'steamid': '76561197960405870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1399873548}
review:
I'd recommend this game, if it weren't for the broken combat. It advertises different weapons, which is great, but really it boils down to button mashing. Only certain weapons can block, while others have a "feint" (such as the katana). Feinting seems like a good premise... But it's has no leverage in a fight. The only thing it will do from my experience is cancel your attack, and let your opponent hit you. 

Besides the 1v1 duels, the game doesn't have much else going for it. With a gameplay design with light/med/heavy attacks, reminescent of Jedi Academy, I'd rather play that game from ages ago than this one. Least then I have force powers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997306951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1523316917}
review:
I bought this game thinking it'll be great to have a pure melee game, no guns, just ninjas and the like, and I only got it when I saw the 'partial controller support'
Well theres nothing 'Partial' other than it shows unmapped config of a joypad, and theres nothing joyfull about having No response whatsoever from the controller. I've followed tips and tricks and console commands to remap the controller triggers and buttons and sticks and still nothing.

This is a great game, if you can pass the learning curve and play with keyboard and mouse; Hands that can palm a basketball were not ment to hit, ctrl, w, 1, s, alt, q, e, etc, all the while franticly using the mouse to block and attack and look around.

This game needs controller support for the half that can only play with controllers, having the option for keyboard and mouse or controller usage would allow Anyone the chance to bring their best to this game and have a chance at finding the fun in it, otherwise they are cutting off their own nose with a blade ctrl thats lackluster if you are not pro at keyboard mouse gaming that requires you know how to keyboard/mouse thousands of combos of keys to win.

For me, the controller using combo wolf, its a no Until they fix the controller option, but I'm gonna put yes here just incase I can't edit this review later, because this is a great game, just released too soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033807841', 'num_games_owned': 935, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1399783389}
review:
In Early Access: Incredibly underpolished game.

Hopefully this game will be better when it comes out of Early Access. But as it is now? Not worth $10, at all.

I understand and acknowledge that some people enjoy this game, and I don't fault you for it, but this game has some major drawbacks, and it's only fair to include them.

Are they based on opinion? Yes, what review isn't. Freedom of speech is a thing, guys. The internet would be rather boring if you were only permitted to post positive outlooks.

Graphics:
Graphics in this game, are decent, with polished textures. However, the animations can be a little underdevelopped, such as running, but what do you expect from an Early Access game? I'm sure they'll tweak it once the game's fully prepared. However, in terms of graphics in general? They're not too bad, and are acceptably merciful to a system to allow some pretty nice eye-candy, without the crushing frame rates.

Mechanics/Game Play
This game has a very innovative, good, and interesting concept, and it is definitely a reason for it being so popular. A game which is entirely about duelling with swords, combining styles and stances to create your own personal sword fighting technique, and testing it out against other players' own fighting styles. The concept was a sell to me, and after watching the preview on the store page? I had to give it a shot.
But it is really painful, to see that the execution of the concept, is sorely lacking ;~;
I hope, yet again, that I can just slap the 'EARLY ACCESS!' sticker on it, and expect it to get refined in the future. Don't get me wrong. I 'want' it to get refined. I 'like' this style of game, truly, why else would I have it!? But right now, the mechanics are bulky at best, and require some intensely impressive keyboard sorcery to manage the wrist breaking controls effectively.
Stances are options to increase the level of customization you can do with your technique, enabling you to pick and choose what attacks work for you, and which don't. Something I personally have trouble with, is the way you change stances. Considering how they expect you to change stances 4-7 times depending on the level of difficulty you're trying to master, and that you either change stances by the 1,2,3 buttons, or scrolling your mouse wheel? When you have to move around to keep yourself out of your opponents reach, it can become difficult to both manage WASD as well as 1 2 3.
They have also added some eye-candy features to the combat styles which, I think, are honestly not neccesary, such as flashy dance-type animations that makes it take longer to actually strike. The female character in the game, appears to be dancing more than fighting, and it quickly gets frustrating when your 'to the point' opponent strikes 5 times where you strike 3 times.

The choice of swords you can use here is actually pretty awesome. No 2 swords are identical, and to add some extra customization options to your style, you have around 4-5 different types of sword to choose from, such as standard medieval long swords, to japanese katanas, to central european rapiers, and more. I actually like this idea, but what I don't understand, is how they've decided to base the general 'combat style' (how your character moves) on what character you choose, not what weapon.
For example: I like the look of the female character, but I don't really like the way she fights, her spinning and jumping etc. It blocks the view, and makes it less enjoyable, and harder, for me personally. I much prefer the combat style of one of the male characters, who does dashes, and super quick forward attacks. I wish the attack patterns were based on the sword type you use (Slashing for Katanas, thrusting for rapiers, and a jack of all trades for the longsword). I personally think that'd make the game more fair, and add another element of customization.
Instead, you're forced to choose your physical appearance based on the character's fighting style. I don't like this too much.

Lore/Storyline
Far as I know? There is none. I havn't seen any evidence yet of a storyline to explain the appearance of the characters, why they're fighting, or what the ultimate goal is, nor what their pasts are. I may be wrong, and simply missed it(I plan to give this game some more time to redeem itself to me), but black on white, I can't find it. As an RPG/Lore fan, I like when my game has an answer to the worlds simplest question, the first question a child asks after grasping the basics of speech: Why? A game that cannot answer this question, or won't answer it, cause it considers it redundant, or pointless to the bigger picture, is not a game I'm very interested in. A game where you're given an armor, a sword, a place, and an opponent, and expected to simply raise your sword and strike them down, because that's just the goal of the game? I apologise, but to me, that's just shallow, as I like to know 'why' I'm raising my sword to strike them down, before I actually do it.

Overall?
I won't recommend this game, RIGHT NOW! Since it's in early access, changes are bound to happen, and just like with Warframe, the much desired melee combat rework was done in combat 2.0 recently, which made the game far more desirable, and true to its nature. This game? In my opinion it needs alot of work, both in balance, concept reconsideration, and immersion. As it is now, the game is trying to do too many things, much too quick, and it makes the game appear as if trying to be made of gold, when it's honestly just a really fancy brass.
As is, I can't claim it to be worth it's pricetag. Perhaps if it was free? I'd say its worth a shot. But if you want a game with fun combat, and customization oppertunities? I'd rather recommend Warframe for you. Somewhat the same concept...Samurai in full body armors that're customizable, who can pick and choose weapons. Except Warframe is primarily Co-op player(s) vs. AI, whilst this is kind of like Warframe's PvP brother, Player vs. Player, little to no A.I.

Hopefully, I can make this a thumbs up in the near future. \o

author: {'steamid': '76561198042225203', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1400540798}
review:
Blade Symphony
Everyone loves swords. There is just something appealing about being a master swordsman able to slice through enemies like paper. It might just be my fascination with weaponry; it might be that I'm currently watching a lot of sword related TV; it might just be that swords are universally appealing. Whatever the reason, I have desired a way to legally satisfy my urges. The practical output of this is that I will buy almost any game which features a sword as a weapon. In some cases this leads to me purchasing the mediocre/dregs of gaming (Shadow Warrior), but sometimes I end up with a game in which I truly feel like the mighty warrior I am (Mount & Blade). Thankfully, Blade Symphony falls into the second category.
At its heart, Blade Symphony is a fully 3D sword fighting game. Its low-key release hides a game which has a startlingly deep combat system. The beauty of the game is in how many options are available to you, and finding your own particular style within that. While the game only offers 5 sword styles and 4 characters, each offers a unique playing style and combination. The longsword for instance is a heavy hitting blade, with strong but fairly predictable attacks. When combined with the character Phalanx, it makes for a long range, but slow jab. Combine it with Pure however and it becomes a whirlwind of attacks, but with less power and versatility. Finding your own style of play really is the crux of this game.
The combat will feel familiar to anyone whose played games like Jedi Academy, Mount and Blade etc. Attacks are controlled by movement of your character as well as the style or stance you are in. Light attacks are fast and easy to chain, with heavy attacks taking a long time to wind up, but capable of taking enemies down in seconds. While this may seem simple, stances can be changed mid combo, leading to attacks of varying speed. Thankfully, button mashing is heavily punished, and instead timing and bluffing is the order of the day. Characters warily circle each other before hitting out with a few choice attacks, before backing off and reassessing the situation. This makes fights tense and efficient; with neither player wanting to risk an attack which may leave them open.
I say player in this context because currently there is no single player option for the game. Aside from a brief 20 minute training mission, which covers the basic controls and not a lot more, the entirety of the game is online only. There are a number of game modes ranging from the traditional 1v1 duel to my personal favourite the free for all. In this mode, up to 12 players can all enter one arena and battle it out. While this does sometimes happen, what usually occurs is that players group off and challenge each other to 1 on 1 duels while others watch. The beauty of this is it enables you to watch and learn from other players and also use the excellent arenas to form impromptu viewing galleries.
The game does have some glitches, mostly with some slight lag and dodgy wall running. While not game breakers they do detract from the overall polish of the product. The wall running in particular seems to have no real use other than being able to climb around some of the maps, but they don't really seem geared to making use of this in any way. It mostly seems to be in place to add a cool parkour edge to the game, but this falls flat on its face. Every time I attempted it in a fight, my opponent would deliver a swift counter and id be dead before I hit the ground. Two of the fighting styles also seem slightly redundant; relying on one set of spins and flips which just gets endlessly repeated. This tends to take the skill out of the game slightly, and is the one area where button mashing can take a slight foothold.
As a budget game, Blade Symphony offers a surprisingly robust experience with the potential to become a cult classic. The community are great ambassadors for the game, and show respect to new players, with very little bad mouthing or aggressive posturing. For someone looking to sate their need for swordplay, or someone who has grown tired of the usual COD shooters, it represents a worthy alternative.

www.gameaether.com

author: {'steamid': '76561197970829601', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1548716497}
review: Did you play Jedi Outcast as much as me?  Do you remember no force powers, in Bespin, lightsaber only duels, bowing, and fighting for hours on end?  This is what this game is.  This game is about melee combat, one on one, and no game out there right now does it as well as this one.  Trust me.  This game has potential to be something big, and owing to the fact they never make a Jedi Knight 3 game (JKA is not JK3...), I'll still be playing this just for the nostalgia of reliving my JK2 days of dueling.  The crazy thing is this though:  People still play JK2!  Theres just something about the one on one nature of duels that keeps people coming back.  Anyway!  One last thing:  Keyboard and mouse.  You'll need them.  The controller is a nice touch, but playing with it feels pretty sloppy and inaccurate... (think JK2 on Gamecube ahem) but I don't got my mouse on me at the moment.  This game is the spiritual successor to JK2 with a hint of Metal Gear Rising and the stylistic nature of Samurai Champloo.  Light, medium, and strong styles are here.  Highly recommended especially at $ 9.74.  :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198110073193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1399828032}
review:
This is the only game in my Steam account that I wish I could have returned for a refund.  It's not the type of (sword) fighting game that I had expected or hoped for.  The game does not force players to face each other and fight like traditional fighting games do. Instead it gives you free range of movement around the environment like a FPS game. And because it controls like a FPS and not a fighting game I have to spend more time trying to keep my opponent in my feild of view than I do actually fighting him. It makes me dizzy and frustrated. I am a fan of fighting games, and third-person perspective action games, but I think this game would only really appeal to fans of competitive FPS games.  I really wish there was a demo of this game available, or at least a more in-depth description of how it's played. I was looking forward to this game, and I really wanted to like it, but it's not a game that will appeal to fans of traditional 2D or 3D fighting games, and ultimately I feel disappointed.

I'm sure this game will appeal to many people, unfortunately I am not one of them.

What else can I say about this game....
The graphics and animations are fairly good, but the ability to customize and individualize your character are very limited. You can use an xbox 360 gamepad to play the game, but you'll be at a disadvantage to the keyboard/mouse players.

EDIT - In conclusion:
call it what you want, but it's NOT a fighting game.  It's a bunch of people running around in circles hoping to slash an opponent as they go by. The actual gameplay looks very little like the videos on the store page, and it does not resemble a real fight in any way. Its not tactical sword fighting, it's a frenzied arcade hack-n-slash with frustratingly wild camera movements to go along with odd hit-detection and unintuitive controls. The four playable characters are as lame as they are limited, and the different skins available do not do much to help individualize your character. The servers are filled with identical characters running around in circles like flies hovering around a turd.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056279413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1518, 'last_played': 1462712868}

author: {'steamid': '76561198126701401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1447038369}
review:
Great game and definitely worth the price, I would recommend buying while its on sale if you have the chance. The fighting is very fluid and only becomes more so when you get a better handle on the mechanics (parry, block, timing, combos). There are 4 different fighters with distinct styles and different sword types to augment the style of each fighter, so fighting can vary quite a bit from player to player. 

This game gets more and more fun as you learn to fight effectively, with matches becoming very entertaining to play or even watch in spectator mode. I'm looking forward to any add-on's that are in the future for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047747013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3694, 'last_played': 1441519551}
review:
Coming from one of the many people that grabbed one of the dev's during a match surrounded by many witnesses this game is worth its full price, hell I'd say its worth 60 bucks but then again I grabbed a dev back in the day! That's when these people called the Crosses existed. Sure there are gonna be a lot of people who talk trash but what else do you expect from a mulitplayer game? You don't play Killer Instinct to get 100 combo ultra-ed, you also don't play archeblade to get on the laggest server that has people playing on there to...well play it.

This is worth your money, though you may say "then why is your play time so low?". Cuz I'm a whimp that's why. Yeah you'll see me losing most of the time but that's the fun of this game, to get better and not become such a cry baby like some people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016003614', 'num_games_owned': 830, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1399582022}
review:
I have a hard time recomending it now, because there is likely a meta here that could make a good game, but currently it feels very stupid. Unfortunately, in order to discover that meta, we need more people playing the game.

As a fighting game player, I'm a traditionalist, but at the same time, I like seeing experiments like this. I just hope that one day this can be more than an experiment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995276154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1423453636}
review: This is the most fun I've had from a fighting game in a long time. The game is completely skill based, You don't get an item or skill that makes you better than everybody else, and the numurous ways you can play means there's always something new to learn. Everything you buy with in-game currency is cosmetic, not game-changing, which really works in it's favor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026902497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1480136212}
review: It is really fun, until some douche comes in with like 400 ping.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002871405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1399606626}
review:
I could talk about a thousand good and bad things in this game. I could talk about how cheap it is right now and compare the fighting to the old Jedi Knight games. I could complain about how much having a low ping punishes you. I could talk about how incomplete the tutorial is and rant about early access games that "release" still being in early access. I could praise the game for its FFA multiplayer mode, which is a really fun and relaxed way to experience the game.

But none of that really matters all that much, because this is a fighting game without local multiplayer. There's no way I can recommend that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034586374', 'num_games_owned': 602, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1429313991}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016728254', 'num_games_owned': 787, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1399775695}
review: Fun interesting with some swordplay stratgy to it and even the workshop is a nice touch. Yet it seems to need some more work with weapons and modes. It does have a nice duel and collision to it though. But as for tactical goes its far from that its not even tactical the game only has certain attacks and a range that is barely useful. There is only 1-on-1 fights no 2-on-2 fights in the game. You can free for all yet the whole game is not even worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082290322', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1463545216}
review: at the moment it isn't 100% recommendable but its pretty cool nonetheless. also i don't know if im the only one that gets this problem but my mouse pointer dissappears whenever i start up the game

author: {'steamid': '76561197964699828', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1399859231}
review: This is the best sword fighting game that I have ever played. I love the attention put into all the different fighting styles. I like that it is kept simple. There are different fighting styles, and different swords. You can try to make your character fit your play style with these two options, and that's it. Of course the game has yet to be finished so all the polish, optimization and features have not been finished yet. I also feel like this game has made the best use of the Steam work shop. It was awesome to just pick out swords on the workshop and then they were just instantly available in game. It was also ridiculously fun to pick the swords from my favorite anime and play with those online with my friends. The game is realy solid and fun to play even with it not being finished yet. I hope this game gets big.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040097496', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1545929674}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014380855', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1241, 'last_played': 1493308611}
review:
As a gamer who is notoriously bad at fighting games, I was hesitant on purchasing Blade Symphony. 

After sinking 6 hours into it in two days, I feel I can say that whether or not you play fighters every day, or you suck at them as bad as I do, this game can be for you.

I think a better way to judge if this game is for you is to ask a simple question:
"When you were a kid did you ever use a paper towel tube as a sword?"
If yes, this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982092050', 'num_games_owned': 932, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2019, 'last_played': 1410528516}
review:
Blade symphony es un juego de esgrima (o lucha de espadas). 1 vs 1. Aunque tambien tiene modos de juegos como 2 vs 2 o FFA, ademas de muchos hechos por la comunidad.

Lo primero. Es un juego 100% competitivo y pensado para competitivo y torneos. 

Graficamente es bastante bonito y vistoso, usa el motor source asi que se puede esperar una calidad a la altura de Portal 2 o CS:GO.

Y ahora lo realmente importante en este juego, el gameplay. El juego al principio y para los nuevos, es muy dificil, tiene una curva de dificultad muy, y creo que demasiado alta. ¬øEs eso malo? No del todo, pero puede echar para atras a mucha que quiera empezar. 

Sobre las luchas, se pueden clasificar en 2 tipos: Quienes saben jugar y quienes no. Me explico. Para los que no saben y los que empiezan, el juego parece un spam de click izquierdo mas. Para los que saben jugar, el juego tiene una profundidad increible, lleno de golpes, contraataques, contrarrestar al otro, parrys, combos, Air/sides cancels, posicionamiento, rangos de ataque. Es decir cuando aprendes a jugar es un juego totalmente distinto (y muy muy muy divertido y adictivo).

Otra parte muy importante y buena del juego es que ver combates, de gente que sabe, es muy divertido e interesante de ver. Ver un master (equivalente a challenger en LOL) jugar no tiene punto de comparacion con uno de ligas baja, ademas, te motiva a jugar y mejorar para llegar a ese nivel, dado que el juego cobra una profundidad increible.

Como ultima nota, la comunidad es muy buena, sobre todo los master y ligas altas, suelen ayudar bastante y dar consejos.

Como ultima nota y sobre mi. Tengo el juego desde hace meses, cuando solo habian 3 personajes, en ese momento el juego me aburria y me parecia muy aburrido. Pero despues de darle 1 oportunidad y aprender realmente del juego, me he dado cuenta de que es muy divertido, adictivo y de que realmente puede ser un referente en el eSport

author: {'steamid': '76561198022923709', 'num_games_owned': 574, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1414187127}
review:
Fairly decent in it's current state. I won't go too in depth, but I will say this:


The tutorial needs to cover more. It's simply too lackluster as is.

The Steam workshop needs support for bodies. There's already support for Masks and Weapons, so why can't there be for bodies? it will certainly only enhance the user community and customization level.

There needs to be a bit mroe bang to it. As much as I like the game, there's simply not too much to do. I feel as if the combat system needs to be a bit rebalanced and added onto. For example, having different styles of attack appart from just grabs and the left-click: maybe like abilities or different types of attacks. Also, based on what i've found, the fast combat style is waaaaaaaaay too overpowered compared to balanced and heavy, when you take latency into consideration.


It really is a fun game, in my opinion. It just needs to be built upon and updated, in my opinion.

review:
I wholeheartedly recomend this game. The fighting is fun and energetic, and can change from fast paced dueling to a staredown at a moments notice. The choice of charecters gives a range of fighting styles, from steady and powerful to quick and eratic.

The soundtrack is quite fantastic as well. And the customization with steam store intergration just makes it better.

The only thing that bugs me is the sparse singleplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990992620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1410668571}
review: I love thise game for these reasons- 1. The community is very nice and supportive of new players a lot of the time unlike a lot of online games I've played. 2. The gameplay isn't so hard that you want to rip your hair out [It is still difficult though don't get me wrong because one wrong move and you're dead.] And it's super fun when you meet people who challenge your skills! 3. The Workshop stuff is really cool and I enjoy it a lot. 4. They only have a few gamemodes but even just the one on one can turn into a two on two battle and that's really fun. But here's the stuff I'm not to fond of. [But probably is going to change] 1. Not a whole lot of charater choice at all or skin choice. That's my only thing about the game I don't like. Other then that it's very well done and very enjoyable and I can't wait to see what they add to this game if they add anymore.
