author: {'steamid': '76561198036212216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1457618669}
review:
Aside from the (What I personally find irritating) lobby system and the 'spectate till it's your turn' method of playing online...well, the combats nice, does what it sets out to do, variety of swords which actually make a difference (ranging from damage to defensive moves) the only downside, is that it suffers from 'crutch' classes, much like Warframe does with Rhino. I've seen an abundance of Knight players, purely because he's the 'easy' one, which punishes beginners (Myself included, but not alone) experimenting with classes.

All in all, I'd rate it AS IT STANDS at a 7/10, few tweaks to matchmaking, possibly few more characters, and that would easily go up to an 8.5

review:
Ive been in since beta, its a solid game and probably the best looking of the new Source games.

I can not stress how polished this game is, its absolutely gorgeous. The tracers, ~50 ping teleporting and ghost hits are a problem but not game breaking. The workshop implementation is the best ive seen, and this game has a lot of room for growth.

It is a solid item to add to your collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980412272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1399618542}
review:
If you like fighting games and had a good time playing Bushido Blade back on the Playstation, this is a pretty good game in that lineage. It takes a little bit to get a hang of how the various swords interact so you can learn which attacks will work at the right time. Once I had that down and found a sword I was comfortable with I had a lot of fun dueling with a guy online for countless matches.

It would be nice if there were a bit more variation in the character customizations but hopefully that will be expanded. Unfortunately its really hard to get most of the gaming public interested in these minimalistic multiplayer-only games. Hopefully Blade Symphony will have a bright future as it is a really nice looking game and plays very smoothly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033098868', 'num_games_owned': 1887, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1399742437}
review:
Fighting feels pretty damn good and is fun to experiment with, community is great and it is a very relaxing yet engaging experience.

I'm not a great fighting game player (I sound like my grandma...). I suck at Street Fighter, Tekken and MvC.
But this is something I got into quickly and easily. 
It's very easy to learn, but hard to master. 
So even if you don't think you'll do well, I suggest trying it out regardless.

It's very "opened up". For example you can actually create dedicated servers (GASP!) and customize your character with workshop items and unlockables.
I'm pretty sure it's moddable as well. 
Basically, it's "opened up" in the sense that the original Counter Strike was.

It's a very refreshing game that works well and has very solid gameplay with a lot of potential.
I hope the playerbase grows a lot more, because it really deserves it.

And, damn, the price tag is pretty good.

Go GET!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021989963', 'num_games_owned': 1084, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1401752129}
review:
8/10

There is enough gameplay videos online to explain what the game is like and if you're reading this review you have probably already watched the intro video and probably don't need me to explain it to you. So i'll just get right into it

Really well done game in a competitive sense. The community is very helpful and alot of fun to play against. The variety in each different character style makes every encounter unique and really challanges you to attempt different combinations and learn your opponents movements to properly counter their playstyle and weapon choice.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a completely skill based close quarters combat game that requires a good combination of skill, reflexes and stratagy.

Buy and enjoy! We'd all love to see the community grow and florish.

See ya in the arena!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961694383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4972, 'last_played': 1538245469}
review: If you're persistent enough you can get good at this game, but there will come a time where you will find that whoever spams or glitches the best wins most fights due to glitchy tracers and poor netcode (lower ping usually always wins encounters). Also, the game is slow and most of the animations lock you down, making for very boring to watch fights since mobility can only be achieved by jumping and rolling short distances. Can't really recommend it because there is practically no freedom to develop your own playstyle, you either copy what works or eventually lose out to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979904119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1467320230}
review: This game came a very very long  way, Ever since it was first named Berimbau on moddb, I was simply fascinated with the game. I even became one of there testers when it was first named berimbau, than they got a huge support from puny games made the progression for the game even faster and better than expected. I was a JKA academy player as well, so this game is solid but don't expect it to be the exact same combat feel of other well known melee games, Blade Symphony has its own style of swordplay. I would rate this game 7.5/10 but thats only through my experience of watching this game grow from a simple moddb game to a now complete game that I would have never expected it to become.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017211295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1468114414}
review:
I rarely find PVP games that interesting. They tend to be fun in the first, generously, day or two, but then they start looking like just a reskinned copy of some other PVP game and that's it. Novelty worn off. 
Blade symphony is something unique from the ground up, and due to being based around duels in the first place, and while some sort of singleplayer or co-op mode with story would definitely add positively to the experience, it is not designed to need one to be fun. 
The defense is pretty active, so you don't have a lot of people turtling up with a block button making no attacks safe. you really have to judge your distance so you can both parry and attack in the same sequence. If you just go wild, you may get in a lucky win, but you'll lose most of the time, because the game requires you to actually fence. This isn't a fighting game, its a fencing game. 
The combinations of the weapon types and the character mechanics works well, I could only hope that they might add more in the near future though its got a solid basis now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011397066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1399546692}
review:
The game itself is quite beautiful and all, but that's it.

Movement are clumsy and actually not as refined as you might guess from gameplay videos. Great design ideas, bad implementations. The challenge is pretty much the same as a fighting game (distance, pressing, parry, etc), but you can only see the battle from a third person point of view, which is absolutly NOT the best way to show the action, especially for the distance look and feel.

Hence, every hit feels wrong, or doesn't even hit at all, action is chaotic at best, nothing happens as expected (even in tutorial). War of the roses simplified this gameplay and nailed it, Blade Symphony complexified it and might even find players to walk this way, but both games can't compare in terms of learning curve and delay for fun.

Another bad sword fighting game (with very nice visuals, still).

author: {'steamid': '76561198045149740', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 451, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1418337247}
review: This is the best Swordplaying game I have played so far, you really do need to read your opponents moves and think about what your moves will be to counter. I have only played this for about an hour and had a blast. Gotta play more to see if it wears off but i really wanted to play this game when it was first put in early access. But i don't buy early acess games. Glad to see it get released. Got it 50% off at the Humble Bundle store the day before it came out as well. So overall this game is a must for if you want to play around with swords with some skill behind it, not just hit a button to swing and win all the time

author: {'steamid': '76561198043579969', 'num_games_owned': 952, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1538263437}
review:
Blade Symphony √® un simulatore all'arma biancha in terza persona, con una forte base tattica e un richiesto gioco di dita tra mouse e tastiera; ottime musiche, tante ambientazioni, supporta il Workshop, si pu√≤ correre sui muri e...beh, gli manca solo da crescere ancora, dato che mentre scrivo √® il 7 maggio, quindi appena uscito dall' Early Access.

Vorrei soffermarmi sulla parte "non ludica" del gioco; mi spiego meglio:

parlando degli stili, avremo una scelta tra 4 tipologie cos√¨ riassumibili:
Spada italo-francese ( o "Scherma occidentale moderna" per i pi√π )
Spada cinese "Jian" ( questo stile prevede varie acrobazie prese dal Tai e dal Wushu )
Kenjutsu ( Arte della Spada Giapponese, da non confondere col Kendo )
Ninjutsu ( Arte della Furtivit√†, caratterizzata da proiezioni e salti )

A questi 4 stili, seguoco 5 differenti tipi di arma: stocco, spada lunga, scimitarra, jian e la katana.
Queste 5 armi hanno pregi e difetti in attacco, difesa, mobilit√† e quant'altro; scelto il personaggio col suo stile, noi potremo equipaggiare una qualsiasi delle 5 armi, in modo da comprendere e studiare, come un ninja possa usare uno stocco, o come un samurai possa usare una scimitarra; in pratica lo stile rimane quello, ma il cambio dell'arma ci impone un adattamento verso di essa, in modo da sfruttarne a pieno le potenzialit√†...ed ovviamente, ci sono combinazioni meno proponibili ( ma non per questo non efficaci ), come ad esempio il moschettiere che cerca di usare una spada lunga che, normalmente, si maneggia a 2 mani, non con una mano sola...

Lascio a voi il resto della comprensione...questo si che √® un bel simulatore di scherma ;)

review:
Blade Symphony is one of my favourite fighting games. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a worthy opponent to clash swords with. I absolutly love this game because of its concept and epic gameplay. I am proud that I got to contribute to greenlight this game and now it is getting big.

In my opinion, this game has the potiental to be played with the aniciapated steam controller. I am very excited to see more stuff coming from this game since it is still in early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053507496', 'num_games_owned': 808, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1451008265}
review: This is an excellent game for hardcore skill junkies. It takes concentration, technique, strategie, precision, and calm thinking. Other than the fact that it requires more skill than just about every other game ever, it acts just like a brawler game. Customize you character, jump around the arena (I forgot to mention you can run on walls), and reduce your opponent to 0 HP. Each of the 4 playable characters have their own strengths and weaknesses. Judgement hits like a truck, but is very slow and easy to dodge. Phalanx hits hard and fast, but most of his attacks take hella accuracy. Pure and Ryoku are similar in the sense they both use kicks and flips in their basic attacks. Ryoku's attacks are very short range, making it easy for a decent Phalanx or Judgement to pick him off. Pure so far I've noticed has no downsides. Huge range, impossible to hit, lots of DPS. OP need nerf. Other than the fact that she's too strong, the game is well balanced, beautifully rendered, and very smooth to play. Absolutely worth the 15$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023701268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1456530609}
review:
If I didn't already think this was a cool game, the community is just what caps it off to being a great game.

While i haven't recently been playing it much i still have played 23 hours of it (give or take some) and I've had a lot of fun doing so. 

I bought this game off a bleach (anime) obsession and loved the mechanics and swordfighting complexity. It goes past the whole fighting game genre and adds a whole new dimension to it.

I have a really bad PC and so i was hesitant to buy it but it runs fine on a system thats like 5 years out of date.

review: Great game with a large amount of potential growth (although it's a bit unwieldy in its current beta state). However, I am definitely not willing to recommend this game to people. This game is ruined by its community; imagine the maturity of anti-social teenagers mixed with the emotional intelligence of youtube comments -- that is what this game's community is. You will not enjoy this game's community. As a visual aid to envision the type of people I'm talking about here, imagine some kid on a forum posting in all caps with a hentai avatar. Congratulations, that is this community. I mean, quality discussions such as [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/225600/discussions/0/558752450742745687/][this thread][/url] are quite standard. Do not buy this game; it is something good ruined by the people playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074372300', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 12863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7490, 'last_played': 1538888922}
review:
Okay, so I may have not played Blade Symphony as long as Sader or some of the other people in the game with Master rank.  However, I do think I have a decent-enough understanding of the game to recommend it.  

I began playing Blade Symphony when it was on sale for $3.  For the price, I thought "what the heck, it's cheap."  I fell in love with the game!  However, there are a few issues.  I'll list the pros and cons as I currently see them.

Pros: 
-The combat system in wonderful.  It reminds one of the old Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast combat system, except much more complex and fluid.  
-Good community (sort of).  There are a lot of really great people that play Blade Symphony and love to help new people learn the ropes.  Also, there are community-driven tournaments that provide some extra excitement to the game.  I'll hit on the "sort of" in the cons.
-Steam Workshop integration.  The fact that anyone can make weapons/masks/maybe eventually capes for this game is extremely satisfying and provides a level of personlization that many other games do not have.  I, for one, enjoy beating people with a Candy-Cane Wielding Batman every once in a while.  The Steam Workshop integration makes that possible.
-Open Developers.  The developers of Blade Symphony are very open with the community regarding what they are working on with the game.  They have been hosting developer hangouts every Saturday night to provide updates, and I personally enjoy them.

Cons:
-Some balancing still needs to be done to a few attacks, but it's minor.
-Large learning curve.  It took me quite a long time and many, many losses to get somewhat decent at this game.  This is not necessarily a bad thing but I just want people to recognize that this game requires some time to learn and they should not just play for a couple of hours, get frustrated and never play again.
-Some dedicated players are jerks.  Now, this will be the case with ANY competitive game.  So please- if you run into someone that is a jerk, do not think that person is representative of the whole community.
-The pricetag of $15 dollars seems excessive to me.  I would think it should be more like $10.

All things considered, I would recommend this game.  $15 dollars may be a bit much, but it is a very enjoyable and fun competitive swordfighting game, the likes of which I have not seen before now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022674997', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 139218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 19, 'playtime_at_review': 41059, 'last_played': 1709923794}
review:
[b]TL;DR: Game not worth $15 for the average joe. Save your money and wait till its on sale for $7 - $3[/b]

As you can tell by my playtime, I‚Äôve played a lot of this game. Hundreds and hundreds of hours and thousands of duel matches. At the time of writing this my current ranked game number stands at 2594 Wins, and 1298 losses for a total of 3892 matches which is 11,676 individual ranked fights. 

Eleven thousands individual fights, and for some reason I find myself warning you dear reader that this is not a $15 game. I purchased Blade Symphony back in December 2013 for around $7 dollars; my brother purchased the game for $3, and I can tell you right now based on the current game I overpaid.

So let‚Äôs start with the good: If I‚Äôm writing a negative review, then what is keeping me playing.

[b]The Good[/b]

Workshop Integration:

The current game allows me to create (using various modeling and texturing programs) my own weapons and items. I am one of the more active and prolific workshop creators in this game. This is one of the main reasons I have continued to play this game, as I love to create custom items for people to use. Without this workshop Integration I would have quit the game a long, long time ago.

Deep Combat System:

This game has the framework for a fantastic combat system, giving you a true feeling of skill when you defeat an opponent. There is a lot of depth here.

And‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs it for the good.

[b]The Bad[/b]

This game has a severe lack of content in the form of game modes as well as characters. I personally have played only one of the four characters in nearly all of my 11,000 matches. The character I chose was unfinished as of December 2013, and is now being released unfinished in May 2014 (the game‚Äôs current release date). You heard me: This game is releasing an UNFINISHED character and charging you $15 for it. 

There are currently only four characters in this game (or 3.5 considering the unfinished/unbalanced character I play. There is also only one way to play the game: 1v1 duel. This is the only game mode you will be able to play at launch and unless you have a competitive streak like me; you will eventually grow bored of this, as 99.98% of the current community has. This game currently has over 30,000 people who OWN the game, yet at peak times US East you will barely find 30 people playing. 

The asking price for this game is $15, I urge you not to buy until it is at least HALF this price, or even a quarter of this price; because the vast majority of you will not be able to play this nearly as long as I have and you will likely quit within the first 5 to 10 hours once you‚Äôve seen all this game has to offer. I want to reiterate; it was my Workshop projects that have kept me here so long, not just my competitive dueling.

review:
(2017)
Editing my review for one reason.
Negetive reviews DO NOT make people buy game. They see the Downthumb and they wont bother. Problem with steams way of reviewing is that people dont go past the front. They see mixed they think its bad so please. If you see any down post Actually read them. Most of them are actually reccomendation. But because of the lack of players They rate down which DOES NOT HELP AND ONLY KEEPS POTENTIAL PLAYERS AWAY








(2014)
Is it a good game. Yes. Is it Flawed. Yes.

Still For it's price i would recomment this game. It's Fun and the combat does not have a extremlly high learning curve. The animation could use some tweaking as they seem quite stiff right now. But as long as the game keeps up with updates and patches, it would be on the right track to becoming a worthey addition to the fighter genre. You dont even have to wait for the developers to really make anything in ways of customization It Has steam workshop suppot which is great and already has some cool stuff in there. 

Overall is a good game and is a worthwhile addition to your game collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102930568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1406945373}
review:
Blade Symphony is an easy game to play, and difficult to master. With four character based sword-fighting techniques, mixed with multiple sword choices, and charater personalization options, this game is a must have for 3D Brawler fans. Theres a free roam option, as well as 1v1 and 2v2 duals, allowing you to show your skill against another opponent, or team up with your friends to see if you can work as a team.

Pros:
- Great Graphics even on lowest setting.
- Beautiful Music.
- Smooth Gameplay (for the stage that it's at in it's development.
- Steam Workshop Content is sure to have something you will use for character personalization.

Cons:
- Servers are desolate.
- Most Sword Choices are based around the katana sword.
- Default Button Layout is strenuous and non-sesoned PC players will stuggle with learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990586206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4902, 'last_played': 1428260785}
review:
Blade symphony. A game with simple tags like "fighter". In my honest opinion, this game has gone beyond that, it is a new genre, the "duel" genre, in it's own rights.

Blade symphony is a thirdperson swordplay/fighter with incredible depth. Tracers in the air indicates what route your next attack is going to take, which changes depending on movment and what stance you have (light balanced heavy) and if you charge the attacks. You string these toghether to create "combos". 

The community is very helpful and active, but as of now it is a bit small. Some things definitly need tweeking, ranking system, balancing and so on, but it is early accses, but honestly it looks like a finsihed game, and they disprove it is by constantly patching it. But right now, it's ofcourse playeble with a few gamemodes here and there but mostly focuses on 1v1. There are also tournaments arranged. It's also very easy to get in toucth with developers, and they are very responsive!

This is the kind of game were you wont even hit the best players.

A gamewere people can TRULY get good!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028020795', 'num_games_owned': 6523, 'num_reviews': 501, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1478413674}
review:
First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/blade-symphony-first-impressions/

Aww yeah, Blade Symphony! I've played this game far too much over the past few weeks, and I've gotta share my thoughts.

Blade Symphony is alright on its own. You can jump in and enjoy yourself, dueling against others and all, but the real fun is when you get a couple of friends to play it with you. I happen to have three other friends who also picked up the game, and boy is it fun. The true way to play the game is in a dueling fashion. You go up against another player in a one-on-one duel, which are very fun to do. There are three stances to take: fast, medium, and heavy. The heavier the attack, the more damage. I start off my fights with a heavy attack, quickly switching to fast attacks afterwards, then back to heavy after I've backed up a bit.

The sword fighting is excellently crafted, huge props to the work that went into it. We had a lot of fun stabbing each other for a good hour or two. After that, we took the game in a very different direction. The game has two modes: FFA and duel. You already know what duel is, but FFA is a bit different. FFA will take any of the duel maps and make it a large, open-world map for you and some buddies to mess around in. In this mode. you're able to parkour around the level, wall-running and such.

Due to the various parkour features, we ended up playing hide-and-seek for several hours. It sounds ridiculous, sure, but it was so good. Specifically, there was one map we spent a ton of time on. This map resembled a mall, and it was HUGE, much larger than any of the other maps. The parkour features allowed us to find some pretty interesting spots to camp out at, one of my favorites being the very top of the mall, higher than the top floor. The best spot, discovered by a friend of mine, happened to be above the elevator in this map. It was a small, black room that a few of us hid in whilst playing.

Blade Symphony is a fantastic game. It's still in development too, so there's much more to come, even in its already glorious state. I look forward to future additions to the game and highly recommend it.

I recommend giving this a go as it does need popularity in order to make this a good game. It needs players so get it and have a crack!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024493934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 37680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35850, 'last_played': 1530446059}
review:
Great game here, have a lot learning curve.
If you're looking for some fighting games that's more tactical then this is the game for you.
New player might find this game hard to play and unfair, it's ok, I used to think so too.

Oh and the community is very friendly and polite.

Edit: After some what decline in the community due to reasons in the community the game now have pretty small and by small I mean around 20-40 players average per day.

Mostly what you refer to "venteran" or "elitist" so don't expect a friendly welome in a ranked duel server.
If you want to start learning the game go to free for all servers.

I would only recommend this game at this moment at discount with 50% off or more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026977588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1392600787}
review:
I found blade symphony surprisingly enjoyable. a small-league early access game about pure, unabridged swordfighting. i figured that it was infinitely better than torchlight (I was right) and tried it out
my first impresions were bad because the game was laggy, and had more bugs than a starship troopers movie. it was in its infant stages though.
I picked it back up so see if it improved and did it?
it has its own workshop, if thats not testament enough, I don't know what is.
The game has a really simplistic art style and theme that is more or less a combo of cyber-martial arts in a modern setting, not much to scream about but thats because its background. Blade symphony's main call is gameplay.
its a multiplayer only game where two or more people must duel with swords until one wins [strike]and gets eaten by the Nidhogg[/strike]. there is no simpler way to explain, no story, no war, just simple, one on one sparring with swords.
the selection of swords is satisfactory, with the player being able to choose between four styles of blade, each with their own attributes and styles, and to then extend that, a selection of four characters who again, have their own fighting style, making for 16 different combos of ways players can fight.
the best thing about the game, however, is that there is no overruling tactic. every style has a weakness (several, in fact), and every sword has a counter. its all up to player skill to beat the other guy in pure unbridled sword combat.
should you buy it?
Yes. it really tests your wit and is quite fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071153880', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1504238945}
review: This game is an in-depth fast paced fighting game like nothing anyone has ever made before. It introduces a fluid combat system that can changes battles in a instant through tactical thinking. This is a great game and I recommend it to all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089304043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1471558498}
review:
Awesome REALLY fun fast action sword fighting game. I would recommend this absolutely 100%.

Although there are a few things this game really needs:

[1] The fast class is too underpowered, and the stabbing class is too overpowered.

[2] Needs some sort of single player playthrough mode, like a story mode.

[3] Have servers too, but it would be good if the game automatically added you to the best server when clicking "Play multiplayer", because then there wouldn't be full servers because it would generate a new one.

review: It's good looking, stylish and varied enough to keep you interested. Little buggy at beta but still perfectly playable. Definitely worth buying although go to the website rather than Steam to save $5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047275175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1406684762}
review: A really great sword fighting with great depth and variety to combat.  The community has also done a great job in creating custom swords that can be implemented into the game with ease.  Overall, a great 3rd person sword fighting game that has a better combat system than War of the Roses.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993491585', 'num_games_owned': 876, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1441570986}
review:
Blade Symphony is still a young project, with lots of growing to do, but it's already a refreshing change of pace for weapon-based fighting games. 

Not since Severance/Blade Of Darkness has a third person action melee title worked so hard to build strategic swordplay into a rewarding gameplay experience. Every encounter is uncertain but winnable, and the multilpe fighting styles are tuned for balance in very interesting and, to my knowledge, original ways.

There are a few games (Blade Symphony, Clang by Subatai and Sui Generis by Bare Mettle come to mind) currently in development that are seriously concerned about getting melee fighting RIGHT. I urge anyone who is interested in seeing interface breakthroughs from these projects make their way into larger titles (Elder Scrolls looms large in my mind) to support all of these specialist games as much as possible in order to enrich the landscape for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993787239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2023, 'last_played': 1420688507}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997801929', 'num_games_owned': 2899, 'num_reviews': 405, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1477358746}
review:
This game is fun.  Sure, it's incomplete, but it already has workshop support for weapon models.  It also has a very interesting fighting mechanic ala Bushido Blade: fight sword versus sword.  The game's community is pretty low, meaning there aren't many players at the moment, but then again, there are enough to keep the game interesting for a while.  Most people will probably prefer 1v1 matches to group fights, anyway!

I will update this review later, whenever I get more familiar with it or the game has changed.  For now, just know that the game is a lot of fun and very challenging.  I just wish jumping and wall-running was as useful in this game as it is in Forge.  Oh well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000388770', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 20851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3698, 'last_played': 1554028783}
review:
Incredibly fun sword fighting game. It's like a more fun, better refined version of that combat that existed in Jedi Academy, minus force powers and ridiculous jumping of course :P.

Although, this game is not easy to pick up, and it is incredibly hard to master, so I won't recommend it to any casual gamers.

review: I bought street fighter for 60$. I was ahasmed of my self after playing this game. Best dueling game I've played since Tekken bloodline at the arcade. I can't say it has a lot of content at the moment, but it's early access so I'm sure they will add more maps or something.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979038347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1391826825}
review:
Fatastic fun once you figure out the basics. The tutorial might not be the best due to being unfinished for the time being, but it does give you the tools to figure things out on your own. 

Multiplayer seems to have its shit together, netcode does not cause any lag that isn't logical due to someone's high ping. Fights feel good for the most part and are lots of fun. 

Workshop adds to the character customization in a nice way, hopfully more content will fill it soon, though there is a nice little selection for now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019602537', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1419019037}
review:
I would defianetly not recommend buying this game. The movement is very hard to get used to, it has no sense of flow. For instance the roll works like a normal roll during the roll itself, but instead of transitioning into a standing position in front of where the roll stops, you just stop immediately and in a flash of the eye you are sudenly standing up. It is hard to explain, but it defianetly does not feel rigth at all.
       Another problem is that it does not give you a lot of features. I do understand that the game is in a pre-launch state, but I can't see what they can add. With what they have there is nowhere to expand, except for bug fixes, adding new cosmetics, and more weapons (which will most likely just be skins of already existant ones). This game has little replayablility because it lacks diversity of strategies. I honestly don't see why they allow each character to use the swords not meant for their play style, it never works out. 
       Another problem with the weapons is that you only have one sword for each type of play style, making it so there is basically nothing to unlock. I mean some of the skins seem to be worth unlocking beacause they are joke weapons and it is funny to see them in combat, but they are not a driving force to keep playing the game. There is honestly no reason not to have unlockable weapons with different stats. Each play style has so much room to expand, the current set of swords only are the tip of the iceberg of what is possible.
       I also have a problem with the maps, they are all the exact same. Which is really disappointing, because I could imagine a lot of things that you could achieve with different levels. I think the main reason the maps aren't more than just a flat plain is because the jumping in the game is very flat and hard to control. By flat I mean that it doesn't do a good job at getting you anywhere, and you feel extremely heavy when you preform it. WARNING: IF YOU ARE A SELF-CONSCIOUS WHITE TEENAGE GIRL DO NOT JUMP! My biggest gripe with the levels is that I thought there would be a lot of diversity amongst them when I saw on the store page that there was a level editor. There is absolutely no point in a level editor when all of the levels are the same thing with different backgrounds. Most games don't have level editors when they probably should, but I never even imagined that the opposite would ever happen. Why would you put time and effort into making a level editor for this game!
       Overall this game needs HUGE improvements. The biggest problem is defianetly the lack of different swords. This not only limits the action in-game, but also the replayability of entirety of the game. The next most important thing that needs to be fixed is the movement needs to be fixed, it always feels like the gravity is twenty times stronger then normal. Once the the movement is fixed I assume that the community would start making more creative maps for this game, and possibly even the developers. So if you intend to buy this game I would hold of until they fix the problems I have mentioned.

review:
This is actually really good game. You can tell that the dev actually spent a lot of time on this game. I would actually spend my time and good get at this game. Its a very good investment of your time and money. There are many different combos and class to choose from. Many possiblities.  However, no one plays this game anymore. This game needs to get big, and once it does, this will be a good game. This game is still in beta, and if you are debating whether to buy it or not, i would suggest to buy it with a friend, so you can play with them. There are probably no one else to play with in the server. If there are, they would be the same people you play over and over again.  

I would give this game a 4/5, This will earn my last star if there are actual bots to practice against, when no one else is playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971092458', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 4295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1075, 'last_played': 1416880252}
review: An amazing free-form fighting game.  There are elements of a traditional fighting game like frame traps, positioning, and combos, combined with the freedom and nuance of Jedi Academy.  I played a LOT of Jedi Academy back in the day and although I had a lot of fun with it, I can't honestly say that there wasn't a lot of randomness in how some fights played out.  Saber clashes weren't always consistent, and sometimes you just got lucky.  There's very little if any of that here.  The Fast/Balanced/Heavy stance system creates a very logical rock-paper-scissors type system to sword clashes.  In this game I can almost always say exactly things turned out the way they did and there's a logical way to combat different strategies.  It really does a great job of capturing the "easy to learn, hard to master" environment that most competitive games strive for.  Speaking as both a traditional fighting game fan and a fan of Jedi Academy back in the day, this is a fantastic sword fighting game that I'm going to be putting a lot more hours into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016859256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1403323778}
review:
Blade Symphony is a 3d fighting game that ditches the classic "you're always locked onto your opponent" movement of most traditional 2d and 3d fighting games in favor of simply moving with the arrow keys/your controllers directional pad and aiming attacks with the mouse/your controllers analog sticks.

Though I can see that it seems to be shaping up to be a solid game, and I appreciate more experimental fighting games that don't necessarily stick to Street Fighter styled controls, I'm not quite fond of the "stance" system. Basically, instead of having light/medium/heavy attacks, you instead have to switch between 3 different stances which alter your entire moveset. 1 is "light/fast", 2 is "medium/medium" and 3 is "heavy/slow". Each of these stances is designed to be strong and weak against the other two stances in a classic rock/paper/scissors weapon triangle. While that's all well and good, I still feel that having to roll over the mouse wheel to select from 3 stances in the heat of combat in order to get the move you want feels clunky and convoluted. I would have much preferred just having light/medium/heavy buttons. I mean seriously, imagine if in Street Fighter you had to roll over a damn mouse wheel or reach over to the number keys on your keyboard and than do a movement sensitive input every time you wanted to throw a damn sweep as Ryu.

There are a few other nitpicks with the combat, though I assume these will be tweaked out and refined with time. At the moment blocking seems to be pretty useless, and since blocking sucks, throws also suck. The game is basically all about hitting buttons right now.

Anyway, as for content, the game has a small roster of characters at the moment (about 5 or so), but each of them has a huge variety of weapons to choose from which alter their movesets and abilities pretty heavily. The game also has 2 on 2 matches along with 1 on 1 matches and various lobby settings, so it's pretty decent for online play. Though the netcode is bad.

I like most of the music also. The aesthetic is pretty cool too, though Pure has way too much junk in the trunk and her random cyborg ninja fanservice feels really out of place IMO.

Seems like a solid game, and one I might return to from time to time, but I really don't like the convoluted design of the stance system. Personally I think Max Anarchy/Anarchy Reigns on Ps3/Xbox360 does pretty much the same thing much better, so I'd honestly recommend picking that up instead if you have either console.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993203343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 32689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9827, 'last_played': 1673758742}
review:
Blade Symphony harkens back to the classic Jedi Knight series, focusing on 1 on 1 sword duels.  If you were a fan of lightsaber duels in those games, you'll feel right at home here.  For the uninitiated, this is a rather unorthodox and very unforgiving fighting game, with a steep learning curve.  You will struggle over the nuances of the controls.  You will lose a lot of duels.

However, once you can get past the initial bumpiness, you'll find that there's a lot of depth.  What seemed random at first actually requires quite a bit of technique and timing.  The veteran players can be very friendly, and will be more than happy to provide advice.  Some servers will even hold impromptu classes for players who ask.

As for the Early Access Beta, the game is adequately playable.  There is one character that is still a work in progress, but the other characters have fully realized movesets.  There aren't a lot of game modes, but when the focus is on 1v1, this isn't a big issue at this time.

Post-release edit:  The gameplay itself is much more refined after several fixes and balance changes.  Pure's moveset has filled out nicely.  This is still a lean, mean fighting game; perhaps not the most feature filled (for now), but it certainly isn't lacking in depth.  Jedi Knight/Academy fans will be chuffed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040495167', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2559, 'last_played': 1389294505}
review:
Still in beta, but that doesn't excuse a combat system entirely based on exploiting animation cancelling. The development team seems far to small for the task of building a balanced fighting game with mechanics tight enough force players to duel within the rules.

If you don't believe me, just go watch the video by the game's top ranked player WhoArts, who demonstrates 5 of his favorite advanced tricks, most of which are good ways to exploit animation canceling for better range and timing than the developers intended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027871223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3029, 'last_played': 1484015791}
review:
Decent game all around.

Has the same issue as does every other game that needs perfect timing.

Ping is a huge factor, and alot of servers are EU hosted.

Balancing has been going slow and mechanics that seem very "un-needed" such a being able to get hit while in the air, and still attack back with a stronger attack.

All around worth the money, and not a dime more.

EDIT: Game was forsaken by devs and ruined, a real shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961327976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1388618572}
review:
The controls are just horrible.  You have to spend a bunch of time practicing by yourself just to understand where your characters attacks are going to go, because they're completely unpredictable and nonsensical otherwise.  For example, your character might have an 8-hit combo for their 'Fast' combat stance, but even if you stand still and just hold down attack, only two of those attacks will actually place in front of you.  The others will have you rolling and cartwheeling around, attacking to the sides and stuff.  Now factor in that these attacks are modified by directional movement, and every character has different attack patterns for three different stances.  How the hell is the player supposed to get this under control?  Hit detection feels really strange on top of that, and the game gives you very little feedback to indicate what's happening.  

As a result, fights feel like a bunch of spamming that has your characters flying all over the place, and you just hope that you're going to connect with something before the other person does.  Not a very satisfying combat system, and the combat system is the entire game.

I'm sure it could get interesting between people who have spent hundreds of hours memorizing the attack patterns of various character/weapon combinations, to have some chance of matching them effectively, but I'm definitely not the type who cares to do that.

I understand that it's early access, and I'll give it a chance when closer to a finished product.  Sadly, I'm not expecting much.  They need to deeply rework the basic functioning of their combat system to be playable, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095930407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1413172717}
review:
Fun game although it is still in development, a few server lag bugs and some fun things. best thing about it, no bullshit "pay for better stuff" its all skill based, and you earn customizations for characters, its completely free in game, all you gotta do is buy the initial game and your done. Earn your keep, and what you earn are customizations. Open to Steam Workshop, so you can get awesome designs, even if your a newb. very tricky game, but awesome once you get control of your character.

Few downsides is that they need to work on adding more classes and have better servers up to reduce lag. lag is bad when over 80 ping. They need to allow for more types of weapons, because its called Blade Symphony, Jians, Katanas, Foils, Longswords, and Symitars arent enough on their own. Maybe even a suicide system is needed to admit defeat

author: {'steamid': '76561198031680300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1753, 'last_played': 1389364606}
review:
Blade symphony is a game pitting a drinking samurai, a fencer, a breakdancing yakuza and a sexy cyborg in swordfights with the choice of 5 swords. If you think this is awesome already, well you can go ahead and buy it. For the others, I'll shed some more light on how this game plays. Note that I won't go into graphics, nor the early access pasted on the front page. 

So, the game is purely PvP. The training mode, at the time of writing, is just you in an empty room. Which isn't all that bad. You might want to practice here after the tutorial. Because you will lose a lot of times, before you get how to play the game. The advertisement isn't joking about this game being about precision and timing. There are still mindgames involved mind you, but they are all different, depending on the playstyle of whoever is fighting.

The fighting feels good. Even if they tell me one of the characters isn't quite finished, she still plays quite solidly. The sound assets do feel more squishy than meaty, but that's to be expected. IT's sword fighting, and the sounds work really well. And when you do hit, especially a hit with judgement, it just feels good. Flames from your sword, the opponent being knocked back quite a large distance... It just works. And the music just tops it all off.

Anyway, for those of you looking for a sword fighting game, if you remember bushido blade(note, never played it myself), then this game is just straight up your alley. Even if it isn't truly one hit kills, fights are still deadly enough to be a concern for the player you're facing off against.

But, I left something unsaid, didn't I? Well, the game seems easy enough to grasp, but is still tough to understand. You see, timing and precision comes with practice, and isn't easily gained. I lost a lot of fights before I grasped how it actually all fits together. But now, I'm doing pretty well. I still have my faults, but I play far more solidly than I did starting the game. So, if you don't mind being beat on at first for quite a large chunk of time(it could even happen 5-10 hours in, though Your Mileage May Vary).

But, there is another downside I have noticed... The tutorial doesn't explain everything. I don't remember if they explained that charged attacks can have different attacks, but I do remember not seeing the avoid commands in the game: Roll and step. Both are done with ctrl and shift, respectively. Incidentally, stepping can be done by double tapping the direction you wanna go.

despite that, I can definitely recommend this game, especially when you love going at it in PvP. The game just works very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040098220', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1437078769}

author: {'steamid': '76561198101908030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1388003757}
review:
Try not to get too fooled by the trailer, this game is basically Soul Caliber with a slightly worse hit detection system.

The graphics are well done, and the sword control and movement control are also very tight.  Beyond that, however, it instantly begins to feel like an imitation of soul caliber without the deep combo system. 

Fights in this game currently amount to a matter of which character has a further reach on their opening attacks along with quite a bit of what you see in other games of this type (people using the most broken attacks repeatedly to win). 

If you enjoy games like Soul Caliber or Dead or Alive you will probably like this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968402771', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 12762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1675384489}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008598176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1542534082}
review:
Blade symphony has a simple to learn combat system, and a competitive, but honorable community. Simple courtesies like bowing before duels, and not interupting 1 on 1 fights are commonplace.

Each of the four characters (A samurai, a fencer, a ninja, and an acrobat) has three combat styles (fast, balanced, and strong) that you'll switch between mid-combo to confuse and outwit your opponents. There are four weapon types that each play differently (For example, a foil wielder can move and block at the same time, as well as getting a damage bonus from thrusting attacks).

Once you find your playstyle, you'll start winning duels. This only took me a couple of hours.

This game is pure PVP, so don't expect a campaign mode aside from a quick tutorial.

Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993765973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1387597441}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983902216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1446909838}
review:
This game reminds me of GunZ - it's one of those games that you can jump on and have some fun. 

That being said, it requires alot of skill to play and has a rather steep learning curve when you're playing against ranked opponents. The more time you put in, the more you can see your skill improve - fights become more satisfying.

Overall, a fun game to play, but you will need to put in the hours if you want to climb the rankings!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057178809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1452712606}
review: I had some fun in this game, met a few cool friends, and had my enjoyment, now it is more of a dead game. It has a unique system, but after a while you after to figure the combos and all out, then all the counters and it can be a lot to remember. I can't say I recommend this to most people anymore, but if you want to play and have a few friends that want to join you and if you can remember most things about it and learn or find someone that will teach you, I say get this ame, but if you expect to find matches easily and be able to spam your way through most of those few matches your find, I must say find another game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045152105', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1440247269}
review:
Blade Symphony is a pure PVP multiplayer game where you challenge other players to see who has the superior swordsmanship. This game brings what most games failed to do. 

Positive: Skill Based Combat. In this game you won't see some 80 lvl Swordmaster who will obliterate you with his mind. You won't see a man (or a woman) with Legendary sword of DESTRUCTION that will kill you even when you look at it. No Such Thing. And that is the best part. Player that just started playing has just as much chance of winning the game as the one that created the game. Only your skill matters nothing more. Every item, skin, mask or anything else is just cosmetic. You like big swords like in final fantasy? Here you go, buy that longsword for ingame money but don't expect it to be better or more damaging thatn the one you have right now.

Negative: This game is in early access stage, that means that there will be some problems. Like occasional lags, bugs and other annoying things. Currently there are only 4 classes and 5 weapon styles. Game doesn't have working AI for practice match (actually there is no AI for practice match). Matchmaking is non-existent. Some class balance issues. Automatic draw when time runs out etc.

Overall: I would give this game solid 8/10. Only 8 because it is still in early stage and lacks some crucial things. But it's not 6/10 because it has great potential and has innovative ideas of skill based combat. It is essentially what I look in games where wallet-warriors don't exist, or at least don't matter. Where every player plays at the best of his abbility. There are no sure-way fool-proof tactics to win the duel. This game will be a MUST BUY in a few months time. Right now it is good but mark my words, it will get exponentially better

author: {'steamid': '76561198053252712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1403354396}
review:
The idea is brilliant. The graphics is good. But the main part - the sword fighting is terrible. It seems authors never held a sword in their arms yet read a lot of manga. 
Just a few points (my own list of disapointments is much longer):
- Style depends not on sword but on character so there are a lot of slahing moves for a foil and a lot of thrusting for katana.
- All swords have the same reach and speed.
- There are a lot of acrobatic moves which are not possible (or even if possible - fatal) in practice.

In result instead of sword fighting simulator - another click-fast-enough slasher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037345158', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1590311135}
review: The game is still missing quite a bit of features but even as it is now it's incredibly fun. In depth sword battles are truly enjoyable and every duel is so action-packed it's amazing. This is purely multiplayer game, no single player exists, at least for now, but community is large and there're never shortage of oponents, just make sure to find servers with low latiency laggy connections really screws up any enjoyment. Absolutely recommending this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007104822', 'num_games_owned': 783, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1403945747}
review:
Blade Symphony

To me, a solid sword fighting game that focuses on tactics was a breath of fresh air to me. Where you either charge in or bait your opponent into a false sense of security and superiority then you hit them with the cold, hard and unforgiving edge of reality via the blade you wield in your very capable hands.

You see that this game feels like other games but it still has its own identity. 
Its not just some mindless hack and slash game. You gotta think, you gotta bait your opponent, you gotta find an opening before you strike or you could be on the receiving end of a painful and or deadly blow.
Its a fighting game that has you thinking about the next swing you make before you make it. 
It forces you to be defensive when fighting a quick opponent and forces you to keep up momentum against a slower opponent. It punishes you with a swift and bitter defeat if you rush in too quick or too  carelessly. It gives you a quick win if you time your strikes just right and hit that massive tier 3 charge attack. 

I love how Steam Workshop adds a variety of swords that you can use in combat as well as character personalization. You can actually wield an oversized pencil in combat. Think of how humiliating it would be for your opponent to lose to you. They wield badass swords, you wield a massive pencil and you dominate them. Just wow.
 
All in all this indie game is worth the money you put into it. If you still feel hesitant, pick it up during a sale. Beat up some swordsmen, customize your own and play. Download some new swords, practice those combos, charges and learn to parry.

 
Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561198021955114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 996, 'last_played': 1445971840}
review:
I was saving a 25$ gift card for the winter steam sale and when this game popped up I was instantly mesmerized. So I bought it and had some duels with a friend of mine for the first day. Everything was peachy, we enjoyed it. The next day we join a random server with a Phalanx (Fencer) in the lead, and nobody can beat him. Huh, we think to ourselves, and then move on to a different server. Oh, a Phalanx is in the lead. Oh, look, another Phalanx. And another Phalanx. We head to the forums and, loe and behold, this game all about skill happens to have a god class. Suddenly this game just got a lot less fun.
  Other than that, holy s**t is this game Early Access. Hitboxes are beyond broken. Gamebreaking lag is apparent in every server, and you'll watch your weapon fly through someone time and time again to no avail. Do not spend money on this game.

review:
I'm glad I bought this game on sale at more than %50 off.

The combat is refreshing once you first start playing it. But you'll learn more and more that the hit boxes are completely off and it's a complete lag fest hack'n'slash.

Your players moves do not change with weapons. You use the same attacks over and over with different weapons.

You'll enjoy it...for a little while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972653852', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1388082638}
review:
This game CAN be fun, but it's absolute crap.
The hit box is all wrong, you can't seem to actually land a hit when your opponent is directly facing you, you think you've parried when you've actually taken a full blow right to the face.
The side strolls are sort of useful, but not that much as the hit box is slower than your actual body. So when you've sidestepped, you'll be hit.
When you do a roll, you'll be hit.
But when you jump... it's like your hit box becomes next to non-existant.... SERIOUSLY?!?!?

I've just played at LEAST 25 matches and only won 2 of them.
And it's not because I'm bad, but because my attacks never seem to land.
I give this game a good 2/10 for Engine but a 7/10 for Gameplay.
Graphix are neat, 8/10 as for the sound, some of their music have been inspired by popular songs. Once you listen to them, you'll recognize some of the intros. So, lack of insipiration. 6/10.

review:
First of all, it's EARLY ACCESS... Therefore it's not completed and not perfect / polished version so don't expect to get most out of it (( Even though theres nothing game breaking, atleast i'vent found any problems))

Heres the review: If you like swords... or Dueling... Sword duels ??... Katanas or Longswords... scimitars ? It doesn't matter this game has it all and oh boy how i love EVERYTHING about this game already... little glitches or bugs here and there but knowing that the dev's are working on it makes you not even notice those

As for now I'd say the battle mechanic is just awesome and i've been looking for something like this for a long time ! Gladly i found it here

Players and community ingame ?: to be honest, i've yet never seen so nice+kind+helpful+ (( and what not )) community ingame ever... and trust me i've been into online gaming for a loooong time, and never stayed in one game since i love testing other games and discover great titles like this one for example

I'm not going to go with any sort of rating thing now since, yet again it's an early access and everythings subject to change (( Correct me if i'm wrong ))

Love, Strenght, hope and cheers for the Everyone who's working on this game and supporting it :) !

PS: Sorry for my bad english ^_^'

author: {'steamid': '76561198010135843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1503729135}
review:
Tl:dr Sword fighting: simple, deep, fun.

About six hours of playing this game so far. The gameplay is quick to pick up on the basic characters and weapons. Gameplay seems like it has a good amount of depth to it. Depending on who you are playing and how you are playing them you have to decide on timing, positioning yourself, etc.
I wish the blocking mechanic was a little more robust. Currently I see no significant advantage to blocking instead of sidestepping. This might be something I am missing, but if there is a way to use blocking effectively it is not apparent. Sidestepping is very satisfying though once you start to get the hang of it. Being able to doge out of the way of an oncoming attack and positioning yourself in a place to take advantage of their openness is quite the visceral delight. 

The characters have a wide range of styles to master. With my experience so far Ryoku the break-dancing fighter is the easiest to play. His sporadic moves cartwheel him around an opponent while dealing a surprising amount of damage. Button mashing with this character will carry you the furthest compared to other characters. Although you might have some problems when challenged by more experienced players.
The next tier of playing difficulty is filled by Phalanx and Judgement; a fencing style and Samurai style respectively. These characters depend on proper timing and positioning. Phalanx's quickness and small damage strikes are matched by Judgement's use of decisive powerful slashes.
By far the most difficult character to master is Pure. Her Wushu style is beautiful, but difficult to to land good strikes with. Most of her moves will deal less damage then I expected. I am not yet skilled enough to do well with her. 

Adding another layer of depth to the game are weapon classes. Certain sword styles will grant you various benefits. Although initially promising I quickly found that certain characters perform best with their matching class of sword and therefore there is not much reason to use another. There are a few exceptions, but overall it seems as though you are locked to a specific sword type, which is a little disappointing. 

With Blade Symphony you wont have to worry about memorizing complex button combinations. Its essential mechanics are easily learned, yet you will find the depth of combat is something not quickly mastered. The simple control scheme will enable you to always be searching for new ways to position yourself just out of the way of your opponent's strikes; yet just inside your range to exploit their open flanks. I have had lots of fun playing it and look forward to spending more time slashing, stabbing, dodging, and flipping my way to sword fighting mastery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029091488', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1387863512}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991530786', 'num_games_owned': 4438, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1427451613}
review:
Swords and fighting, only missing beers and babes.
[u][b]On a serious note:[/b][/u]
In my opinion this is probably my favorite fighting game (I don't like dueling/fighting games so much)
Gameplay is smooth.
Visuals are stunningly good.
Character customization is nice but currently lacking content (well this is early access so can't wait for more content)
Player made sword models is nice addon to the game.
9/10 would buy again (which I actually did for my friend ;>).

author: {'steamid': '76561198085227144', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1581, 'last_played': 1470002311}
review:
This game will entertain you like none other.
You'll soon be addicted, and you'll never want to stop playing Blade Symphony.
Just the other day, I was playing this game, and I was telling myself to go to sleep after one more duel. That obviously didn't happen. I found myself still playing at 5:00AM, and I didn't even realize that so much time had passed.

Buy it as soon as you get the chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961734608', 'num_games_owned': 682, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1388119460}
review: This game is excellent. A modern bushido blade that's looking sleek and rather fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012953727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1390815821}
review:
This game has an unexpected level of gameplay. Whether you're moving back, forth, left, right or jumping and running on walls or rolling around the floor, this game's unique swordplay combination makes your attacks completely unpredictible by the opponent. Being an online game with that level of playability is one thing, but it also comes with decent graphics and needs very little internet, making the game practically lag-free. What is more, it's only in beta phase (Steam Early Access game). Meaning what? Well it just means that this game is only going to get better!
This is one of the most well ("Playability-Graphics-Internet" triangle ) balanced game I've come cross by so far. Keep the good work up guys!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059566773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1392518754}
review: If you like fighting games, buy this. It's a really refreshing break from the normal button mashing style of fighting games, being that there is, in my opinion, more finesse to this game. There is no pay to win factor either, in game unlockables are purely cosmetic, and you can download more cosmetics from the workshop and use them in game. I really do recommend this game, and even though it is early access, I can't see this game going anywhere but up.

review: Awesome game, I love swords and sword fighting, and this game delivers just that, quite unique really, don't know of any other game where you can have online sword duels with other people on PC, it has a lot of fun characters and weapons as well as maps, great gameplay and modes, deserves more recognition, well worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993784349', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1387749391}
review:
i really like it and its style that its trying to show but at the end of the day all this game does is really makes me want an actual samurai showdown type game like this with much more customization options.

speaking of which the big dissapointment with this game is the customization options for your character in this game. i hope they put more in the game later on.

i do like this game but i'll prob just stick with Kingdoms Rise and come to this when i want something a bit more faster or i need a samurai fix (even tho the samurai is more of a cyborg cross with other things).

author: {'steamid': '76561198054592560', 'num_games_owned': 1020, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1418746926}
review: It's like your typical fighting game..only no where close. In most games like this, you instantly think you can run into PvP and win battles seemlessly easy. However, that's not the case with Blade Symphony. It's very fun, yet very hard to learn. You must know when to parry, when to attack, when to jump in the air and when to dodge. Skills are required, but if you don't have the patience to take a bunch of losses before you learn how to play, I wouldn't buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978810199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1452202285}
review: It's a game with a bit of a learning curve but definately fun when you get the basics down. Chivarly is a bad comparison, yes it's based on swings and counters but the third person and mobility feels a lot different. I can compare it more to PvP darksouls when it comes to just how the game plays. The controls are a lot different though.  At the moment for an early access game it's surpisingly balanced, based mostly on your personal skill and experience with a character/sword combo. Of course there are a few things that seem a bit out of place. What's neat Is all the unlocks are simply cosmetic, and if you can't afford a new sword yet there are plenty in the steam workshop that not only allow you to see the swod differently, but everyone else in the game sees the same model as you do.

review:
Yep this Game is Early Ac. BUT ...i never thougt it woud make so much Fun to play it.  If you get the Basics in the realy easy Tutorial and play a bit around with the 4 different classes and then get the Class that fits your Playstile the best... the 1on1 Fights will make so fuckn much FUN ! ^^ If this Game aproves more and more it can become easy one of my favorites ever :D!
Also you are driven by the Will to Win a Duell to get Coins to buy a new AWESOME looking Sword or Customisationpart...it rly gets you after the first Hour ^^ !

author: {'steamid': '76561198017272874', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1489045854}
review:
I have just been itching for a good sword fighting game lately, and BOOM here it is!
I absolutly love this game in every aspect.
It looks good, plays good, intense action and awesome classes, swords, and builds.
I can't wait to see what else they add.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics
Deep combat system
Classes and swords for different types of players
Beautiful Levels 

Cons:
Minor bugs
A few balancing issues (in my opinion)
Sometimes I don't respawn when I battle an AI
Lag can be the mother of all problmes and leave you feeling cheated

author: {'steamid': '76561198081660815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1451014670}
review:
Long story short, Blade Symphony is a fighting game and a good one at that.  But a review is a review, so I'll delve into it more.  
        
        Blade Symphony is a traditional fighting game except the main attraction of it is, as in the name, blades/swords.  Every match is a 2-out-of-3 match.  Your main weapon in this is a sword.  You can do the classic moves of any fighting game, such as grabbing, block-breacking, doing combos, etc.  Also, you do have a projectile, a smaller blade you could say.  But here is a main strength of the game: you cannot spam.  Instead, to throw you projectile, you have to charge the throw.  This is a good feature, especially for fighting game nuts like me since anybody who has played a fighting game online knows there are "annoying" experiances.  Not with Blade Symphony.

         Anyways, you have three techniques to your disposal: heavy, balanced, and fast.  Balanced is as it emplies, balanced.  This means you get a good mixture of some speed and some power.  It's a fundamental skill for not just the beginning of your experiance, but with every match you get into and your future experiance.  Heavy is soley based on raw power, meaning you can completely deplete your opponents health in only a few hits.  The downside is that you are extremely slow and any medicore-timed hit can have the opposition racking up combos and defeating you quickly.  You'll have to know your opponents moves and have good timing to use this technique to your advantage.  And last but not least is fast.  Fast is all about speed. Get a quick combo then move out of range, then strike again.  You'll have to play smart, because the disadvantage is that you have low damage.  Naturally, fast can, in most correctly used situations, dominate somebody who is using heavy.  Make sure that if you're using heavy and your enemy is using fast, switch to fast or balanced.  There are also four different characters to use, though they all depend on the user and how they use them.  You can also download swords of the workshop, non of them being overpowered.

       The key of every match is patcience and timing.  Wait for your opponent to get within range, then strike according to the situation and their placement on the field.  Blade Symphony is honestly a great sword fighting game that feels like you're actually in the heat of battle.  Use timing, the three techniques, and the character you are using's moveset and strike.  Picking up this game was a real treat, and hopefully it is for you.  Definetly recommended to anybody who has a few bucks on them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003927799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1673654278}
