author: {'steamid': '76561198040965837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1397279666}
review:
After watching Blade Symphony's trailer, I was very impressed by the environment's graphical presentation and fluid movements of the characters.  What's even better is it's not even out of Beta yet.  I had to try it out for myself so I immediately purchased this title.  Let me just say, it was even better playing it.  The graphics are heavenly, the gameplay is seemless, and the idea is great.  It's like playing a free-roam Soul Caliber game that allows you to challenge players on the fly.  Very easy to get a hang of the controls. A good amount a blade swing variations.  There are even different stances you can switch between while you are fighting in order to give you 2 slower, more powerful swings or 4 faster, less effective swings.  Brilliant arenas to fight in.  Great tutorial.  Very fun.

I can't wait to see the final version of the game.  I totally recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987816691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1418797510}
review: Wait for them to expand the tutorial or visual feedback mechanics of the game. There might be an elaborate and dynamic fighting system in here but it feels clunky and inorganic during this Early Access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051688992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1578000955}
review:
Really cool game. In my honest opinion, it should be a bit cheaper, but its worth every cent: the swordfighting is good, the community has a honor code (kinda cool if you want to keep the  blind swordsman roleplaying thing alive) AAAAND the sometimes really soothing and chilling music. 

If i had to say something bad about the game it is the fact that there is no real singleplayer experience, so you have to go on your own to perfect your technique. But hey, its not impossible, i have become a decent phalanx after a day, and i keep learning and learning from this.

Its just a matter of time that they release more classes and weapons, and I hope i get to see you over here!!

just a few things if you consider buying the game so you dont really lose your mind:

- Bear in mind that every character has 3 different sequences of combos, and each sequence can be exchanged by selecting the stances.
-Also, bear in mind the weapons used and their user. A phalanx doesnt do a lot of damage with say a jian, but give him a foil and he is deadly because of his fighting style. the same applies to judgement with the katana/longsword.
-Each weapon has a blocking mechanic. Katana has a standard block, jian has a intercept ability, foil has guard (weaker block, but ability to move)
- Bow with the B key, tease with the v key. 90% of the time i get a bow before a fight. Make sure you do that too to your oponent, it shows your respect. Also, dont throw shit at them when the battle starts, thats dishonorable.
- Keep your camera on the oponent AT ALL TIMES. watch his flaws, study quickly his openings. thats when you should strike with fast attacks.

Yeah, i hope to see you there, add me if this helped you decide to buy it and well play some rounds. See you at the dueling zone! ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976155871', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1419222189}
review:
If you like 1 v 1 dueling this is your game. 
If you played JK:II or Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy this is your updated graphics.

- Best of Three fights, even an option for 2 v 2 battles.
- Four characters to choose from with varying styles.
- Five different swords types to change up your attack mechanics.
- Watch three different active duels going on while you wait for your turn.

I've been searching for years for a replacement, and I'm pretty damn sure I found it. 

This game is Fantastic. Great community too if you're into honorable dueling.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993981654', 'num_games_owned': 636, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1390377676}
review:
Delightfully addictive sword fighting.

Get a real kick when you pull off a epic combo, i've only so far experimented with 1v1 dueling and its been freaking awesome.

I recommend if you're a fighting game fan and looking for something to have a bit of a play around in :)

review: If you like tactical melee 1 v 1 fighting, then you will fall for this game hard. author: {'steamid': '76561198028539184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1387636791}
review:
I understand the game is in early development but wow. The gameplay is so slow and uninspired. I played for a few minutes and I cannot bring myself to boot the game up again. The movements and detail and sound (other than the music which is actually not bad) just feel very sluggish and sloppy.

No way do I recommend putting money down now for it. Maybe in some time if they put more work into it, but right now it was not worth the $2 to play it in this early access form.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028584290', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1387984249}
review:
Un gioco incredibile. Per una manciata di euro ci si ritrova catapultati in un picchiaduro online dalla profondit√† inaspettata per il suo sistema di comandi. 
Ho giocato poco ma ho intravisto una grande potenzialit√†, bisogna aiutare questi sviluppatori e supportare il loro lavoro, stanno facendo un gran gioco, divertente, immediato e innovativo.
Non √® sicuramente chivalry(√® meno crudo) ma non √® detto che sia un difetto. 
Geniale che nelle istanze ci si ritrovi in un battle royale ma che basti lanciare una sfida per creare una istanza privata fra due combattenti. 
Per me promosso a pieni voti. Aspetto di giocare ancora per√≤ e mi riservo di riscrivere il commento.
Si, sono entusiasta! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198007023334', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1388442818}
review:
Keep in mind, at the time of me writing this, this is in it's Early Access stage, therefore, expect bugs.

If you ever longed for the glory days of Jedi Knight Outcast/Academy's lightsaber duels or the fast-paced, frantic action of GunZ, than Blade Symphony is definately for you. I've only played the game's Free-For-All mode thus far, where you can challenge other players to 1-on-1 duels, but so far, it's increadibly fun. The combat is deeper than it looks at first, and requires a sense of timing and skill to succeed.

This game is already looking good at it's beta-stage, therefore, I can only expect it to go up from here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028210641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1530139071}
review: It was on sale for 2.99$ USD, It seemed like a good time killer for maybe a bit.  This game like many alphas have promise, but it isn't well enough to be a good title.  Needs more work done with textures, animation, attack damage radius on opponents.  Etc. . .

author: {'steamid': '76561197986989697', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1403715121}
review:
Definitely worth the $15, but always nice to see it on sale. Swordplay is pretty damn nice considering this is early development stuff. I jumped right in thinking i might spend like 30 minutes, and ended up dueling so many people and doing rematches, that I ended up spending over 2 hours playing. 

There are plenty of indie games that are good, but this one is great and you don't wanna miss out on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077813631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1440958335}
review:
Amazing game so far. I feel like i'm playing Mortal Kombat but everyone gets to me a badass ninja. I've only played the game for an hour since I bought it, however I can tell it has many hours of play time in it. The graphics are great and the mechanics for the game are amazing. Being able to flip off walls, run on walls, etc is a great addition to the game. 

I fully suggest getting this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055630802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1403598642}
review: so much fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028017279', 'num_games_owned': 2306, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1452991541}
review:
Un simulatore di combattimento all'arma bianca come non se ne vedevano dai tempi di Bushido Blade.
Diversi personaggi e costumi sbloccabili (dal classico samurai e maschera da Oni giapponese a super samurai ninja spaziali, fino a gentiluomini in abbigliamento steampunk) e decine di spade diverse, da fioretti settecenteschi a vibrolame degne di Star Wars.
Il tutto mixato ad un combat fluidissimo e divertente che comprende anche vari stili e posizioni di attacco e difesa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047392834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1464518705}
review:
So far so good! The development team have done an excellent job so far, they have managed to create their own fighting/gameplay style which is very fun and strategic, allowing for your own tactics and methods to fight. 

The different characters and weapons are all very interesting and offer variety, spoling its players. 

While this is 100% multiplayer, I can imagine having a great time relaxing in an FFA server, talking and dueling people as I please. 

The music and graphics are fantastic, while each level/map is gorgeous and well designed.

For what they are trying to do, the developers succeed, very, very well! However, I am left hoping that something a little deeper can be integrated in the gameplay, to add some of the magic from jedi knight 2. However, I'm sure the current system is already very thorough and I look forward to getting into this game properly!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041476571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1523353155}
review: My first time playing this game and I did rather well. 2 wins, 3 losses. I felt like a lucky, lucky newb. I like this game, and I recommend it for the $15 if you can't snag it while it's on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069171672', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1432105213}
review:
Take games like Warframe and Mortal Kombat and throw in a little Final Fantasy. 
The game is the offspring of those titles- no joke! 
Better servers and more characters would be nice- but letting anyone in the workshop create their own map and weapons is great! And don't forget that this game is stil in early Alpha! 
This sword-simulator is a must have, and for only 3 buck during the Holiday Sale its worth it! 
This game does NOT have enough players.
This could be huge and ground breaking! Join the awesome communnity! (please...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001794713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 427, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1387620797}
review:
It is early access, but that doesnt mean a game can use this as an excuse.
This game is terrible and I totally dont recommend buying it.
No bots that seem to work. My keybindings always change and mess up without visiting the menu for it.
Overall the fights are messy, and not very fun to play. Game modes are so limited and not innovative at all. 
Bland level designs. All the swords and fighting stances feel the same.
Tutorial is a joke, I went into a fight right after and realized that you can do way more than in the tutorial, essential things like dodging and throwing weapons! How could they not adress that in the tutorial?!
There is no storymode or tournament single player mode. For 14‚Ç¨ I think they could include it. Think about other games with this price. They do have better and more content.
Just buy Chivalry if you are looking for real time combat. The execution and fun is way better than this crappy game. Stay away from Blade Symphony! Deinstall right after purchase

author: {'steamid': '76561198073262763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1433464724}
review: This game is amazing. If you played GunZ and loved the swordplay, this is that with a LOT a redoing so it ALL swordplay. Even the community is the same! Quieter, chat usually limited to GG -Good Game- or GF -Good Fight-, but the sense of respect is the same. From about 2 hours playing, I learned a few things. You can return that respect by Bowing Pre-Duel, Its just as fun to watch as it is to fight, Few games are as smooth as this, Workshop items dont need to be downloaded to be seen in game, and best of all you can beat the best when you just start as even they can fuck up majorly. And do, if you know how to abuse that. Over all, Worth the price, even for the upgrades possibly needed too

author: {'steamid': '76561198076343193', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1387862647}
review: Fluid and smooth combat leaves so much room for tactical fighting, you will instantly notice the depth of the combat as you approach each fighter in a diferent manner. A fun game that people will enjoy, I do not reccomend this for people looking for a smash and bash fighter. Realzing the fact that this is early release one should expect laggy servers on the huge FFA 30+ servers, and a few bugs here and there during hectic fighting, but for an early release and 3.00 USD right now? this is simply a must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045360280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1387835737}
review:
Regardless of the bugs, this game is pretty addictive.  Could use a much better AI trainer, wouldn't recognize an XBOX controller for me.  I went in thinking it would be like the Bushido Blade games of old, where it was one hit kills.  But it has health bars, and seemingly superhumanly sped up characters, there seems to be no weight to anything.  Its hard to tell whether you've been hit or not, and I personally spend a lot of time trying to track my opponents when they're jumping around.  But the challenge system is fun, and its still under work.  I'm glad I'm going to get to watch it get better.  I bought it on sale, and it was worth the 3 bucks.  Hopefully the game works out it quirks.

(2 game hours later)
After a few more hours I got a little bit better, and tracking opponents isn't quite the ordeal I was having initially.  I still lose a whole lot, but losing seems to be instructory and not so much shamefull.  Still having issues with telling whether you've been hit or not. But still, I stopped trying to use the jumpy quick characters which tend to be great for newbies in games, and tried using the tank with the longsword, and it has been working out great.  Now instead of swinging like mad spamming light attacks, I let them do it, and just smack em around when their backs are to me.  Great fun.    Also, I stopped going into the FFA games, and started dueling, its much less forgiving in the duels, but much more fun, as you get to learn different players styles, different characters stances and what not.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996004736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1438210874}
review:
I got this game for $3 during the Steam holiday sale, but it would have been worth every penny of $15. Learning your opponent and their devious ways in well-timed sword combat is extremely rewarding. This is coming from someone who dislikes both fighting games and competitive multiplayer. The tutorial isn't very in-depth, so I would almost say skip it until it gets expanded upon (remember: this is early access) and just learn by playing. The combat is very timing-oriented and button mashing is very unrewarding as your enemy will quickly get around you and remove half your health before you complete your button mashing combo. Learning how to trick your opponent is also key. The only real gripe is that latency feels like it can be an issue with some misses.

Get Blade Symphony. I give it 4/5 carboard rolls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014798018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1400039254}
review:
So I had no idea what I was getting into when I got this game on sale. But I really like this game. IT really reminds of bushido blade for the ps1 if you know that game but a little more fluid and taking more from the third person shooter genre. But the right moves do a ton of damage and there is a strong influence of fighting games. It has a very articulated block attack grab triangle that is core in the genre combined with plenty of strategy. Outside of a few weird instances I can't really find any complaints with the game. It is not entrirely fleshed out yet but so far I definitely like what I see.

Good Stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002570264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1680750063}
review: Skill. Patience. Strategy. Positioning. Things that are missing from other action games. This game is entirely skill based. The combat system is fluid, however it can suffer due to ping. just like any other game. I reccommend this to any person who would like to play a challenging skill based game. Dont be surprised if you get your ass handed to you many times before you get into your groove. It is worth looking into. Try it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966341176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1404411907}
review:
As a long, LONG time fan of jedi knight 2, i found this game quite amazing.

quite frankly, no other melee action game that i have played to date has captured the fun and intensity of personal melee dueling, for some people this is not what they want in a game, they want fast paced intense action with lots of powers;

you wont find that specifically here, 

what you will find is intense, thought provoking melee combat with visceral yet modern feel

you will find a game worth buying and allowing to develop,
it is already and can become something truly amazing like the game that clearly inspired it, jedi knight.

This game run greats at max settings and looks amazing for me and most newer games I have to turn down alot. One of the only problems really is that the servers are too full, which isn't really a bad thing at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988590367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1405198411}
review:
Deeply complex combat system; Lots of varying combos/ways to string different attacks together, without being too overwhelmingly complicated. Beautiful maps/environments. Extremely satisfying soundtrack (seems like a rarity these days)! Friendly, active developers (I actually played with Flux the very first game I played, he answered any dumb questions I had), and an extremely welcoming/friendly community, to boot. Coming from roots of Chivalry/Jedi Academy/Mount and Blade - this game combines every single aspect of each of them, into one extremely satisfying package.

Even if it looks like a little bit too much at first, get this - you won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987034936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 19434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1563387265}
review:
Phenomenal game, but sadly the Free To Play update released after the core community had already left the game due to an already low playerbase.

Nowadays very few people actually play the game, which is kind of a dealbreaker for a PvP focused fighting game.

If you have a small group of friends who like to PvP against each other, I would still recommend the game wholeheartedly.

I will never forget you, Blade Symphony. You didn't deserve this fate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014868525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1389412164}
review: Blade Symphony is as visually striking as it is challenging. With a community of players whose skill levels range from beginner to untouchable, the level of play is such that after a small amount of time you will be getting the hang of things, and even winning some duels. This game is still in development and the developers really are on a quest to make an evenly balanced sword fighting game. The complaints I have are few and I'm sure will be taken care of before the game is finalized. If you enjoy the 1 vs. 1 duels of Jedi Outcast/Academy, you will find Blade Symphony to have similarities but be it's own game. Try it it's worth the low price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015283658', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1486190525}
review:
From my short experience playing this game, I think I have played long enough to review this game as poorly as possible.

I bought Blade Symphony after looking for a swordfighting little duel game for a while ever since I did some dueling in Dark Souls. Blade Symphony isn't Dark Souls, and it shouldn't be. It's unique and I like it for that.

Pros:
-Fast paced sword-swinging gameplay.
-Jumpy trampoline action
-Plethora of things to stab people with
-Spectator view to remind you how good the other people playing are and how bad you are at this game.
-Twirly spinny dancing moves

Cons:
-Fast paced sword-swinging gameplay.
-Jumpy trampoline action
-I suck at it
-Lovable characters that can't make witty one liners
-Decent gameplay and community
-Nice music
-Too many weapons
-Not Dark Souls

Overall score: 7.5 Pure's out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025020204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5181, 'last_played': 1439060486}
review:
I absolutely love this game. I am enamoured by it, addicted to it, and appalled by it. I'm conflicted, because it is incredibly fun and incredibly flawed. It's fast-paced 1-on-1 sword fighting action that's neither realistic nor fantastical.

Before I say anything else, I will preface with this: you are buying into Early Access. This review is written pre-1.0 release. The game is inherently unfinished and has issues. I'm certain these will be addressed sooner or later.

Blade Symphony is a 3D directional fighter, taking cues from Soul Calibur, Jedi Knight Academy and GunZ. I've been told it's "like GunZ, without the guns." The (currently) four fighters have their own movesets and synergies with weapon types. It's up to the player to figure out the various stance chains (between Fast, Balanced, and Heavy), how to space them, and how to time them. Players will link these moves together, stabbing, slashing and bashing each other until one fighter loses. That's as simple as it gets.

If you're looking for a description of basic game mechanics, there are other reviews for that.

What I'm primarily writing about is where the game simultaneously fails and succeeds: its unintentional systems. These buried systems that new players will not be introduced to, and be simultaneously destroyed by, are my favourite and least favourite part of Blade Symphony. These tricks are similar to how K-Styling came to be in GunZ‚Äîhappy accidents that came about as a flaw in the mechanics. Air canceling, animation canceling and gliding are some of the tricks and mechanic abuses that have become what is the current meta of "advanced play" in Blade Symphony. While many lower ranked players will play it straight, advanced players will frequently dominate arenas against players that do not know how to leverage these unintentional mechanics. Many newcomers will not have the patience to learn how to play against or adopt these strategies and will be put off. At the same time, it adds options and extra layers to a game that would otherwise be fairly simple.

This is where I'm conflicted. I love the community teaching aspect. I feel accomplished knowing how to beat cheese strategies, how to beat spam, and how to execute these exploits. At the same time, is it a good thing that a game relies on the crutches of unintentional design to succeed? Maybe. Maybe not.

I'm in love with the game. You might hate it. I support this game to the fullest, but be wary of what you're getting into. Blade Symphony is one of the best $15 I've spent in a while. It might be your worst.

All I know is that my adrenaline is pumping and I am having one hell of a time.

review:
Volete comprarvi un fighter? Compratevene uno bello.
In poche ore di gioco,come potete vedere qui sopra, ho toccato il 300¬∞ posto in classificia mondiale o gi√π di li... Quindi capite la seriet√† di una ladder del genere; ma riprender√≤ questo punto in seguito.
Passerete l'80% del tempo a venire colpiti dallo spam di Salto+Attacco Caricato usato in qualsiasi tipo di fight e in qualsiasi frangente,non importa che tu sia in aria,no non lo puoi parare e non la puoi counterare. puoi solo prendertelo in faccia o passare ore e ore a imparare come schivare un'attacco che non ha minimamente senso,data la velocit√† di esecuzione - il danno causato e la facilit√† nell'attuazione.
Il restante 20% del tempo invece lo passerete a tentare di capire perch√® la gente in top 10 si diverte ad andare contro quelli di rank 2500+ farmandosi cos√¨ punti in ladder. Grinding sui player. mah.
Lo stile di combattimento dipende dal personaggio e non dall'arma.
Capiamoci. Se un tizio usa lo stile di combattimento che si adatta meglio al PUGNALE, ripeto : Pugnale, 20 cm di arma da taglio. 260 grammi se tutto va bene. basta un veloce click e BAM! Da oggi in poi il CQC viene adattato alle spade bostarde (N.B: Bostarde non √® un errore di battitura,√® voluto, altrimenti steam lo censura). alle Katane, AI FIORETTI o ai ferri da stiro.

Vabeh, Vabeh... sempre troppo critico. Ma 14 euro buttati. Se volete investire i vostri soldi: Ripiegate su qualcosa di meno sperimentale. Come l'accelleratore di particelle del cern o gli ornitorinchi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003586462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1613, 'last_played': 1386297659}
review:
Good concept, bad execution.


It tries to be a fighting game when it's in fact closer to a hack'n slash.

The entire system is loose and you don't get the feedback as you would from a regular fighting game.

It tries to incorporate a clunky combo system using an unintuitive interface. Stance changing should be done away with and replaced with dedicated light/med/heavy buttons.

Advertised breadth of fighting styles is exaggerated as only a few are viable, with the majority of them involving mashing M1 with a good deal of jumping around since the dodge mechanics are unreliable.

Hit detection is often suspect, as you will find yourself tapping your opponent with your sword and not being granted a hit as their sword registers before coming close to you. Air juggling opponents as you attack below their feet is common. You will be left wondering how your opponent hits you or you them, which leads to another point--

The system itself has many bugs that the veteran players pass off as actual systems, then abuse. Things like preforming an air attack right as you land will send certain classes gliding across the ground, and  grab attacks that skip animation frames thus not allowing a counter.

A good way to judge the competitiveness of a game is how consistent it is, and this is BS's biggest let down. You will see high ranked players loosing to new players often enough to realize that strategy doesn't mean as much as you would hope, unless the tactic happens to be spam m1 between light and medium stances while hopping around with a quick class, or charging attacks and jumping toward your opponent to fire them off as the heavy class.

Unlockables are cosmetic. A good choice for a game that presents itself as competitive.

Art style is whatever. A mix of Asian and future punk.

Game is still in development, so community is extremely small.

Being in development, all the negatives of this review might eventually be ironed out. However, with the dev time coming up on 2+ years, I don't hold out much hope. I can see its release being met with little recognition and quickly fading back into the Lobby-With-Side-Minigame that it is now.

In short, it tries to put forth a competitive ideal but the result ends up feeling shallow and often times random or unfair. If you are a fan of competitive fighting games (or even action games like Ninja Gaiden or DMC), you will quickly get annoyed with how loose the game feels and its inconsistencies. If you want to swing weightless, occasionally incorporeal swords at other people while hopping around, this might be a game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027161956', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 31566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7238, 'last_played': 1569409361}
review:
One of the best sword games I've played to date. Once you get over the frustration of getting your assed kicked repeatably trying to learn the basic concepts it becomes a really fun and challenging game. Has characters and swords that suit all types of playstyles ranging from cautious play to full on aggression. Loads of diffrent moves and combo's in order to mix up your gameplay. 

To top it all off the development team communicates well with the player base through the use of livestreams etc. If you like precision sword dueling this is the game for you pick this up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027749138', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1475210093}
review:
Blade Symphony is very technically interesting; as each character and sword offer different speeds, combos and timing windows. Some swords just make sense with other certain character choices, but if you have a basic understanding of what would make sense working together, you will be more than fine. There already is alot of customization options and the devs already having steam workshop compatability just adds so much more being that there is guaranteed to be a blade you can find somewhere that fits your playstyle and satisfies your eyes at the same time. 

Gameplay is heart-pounding and a definite adrenaline rush to say the least. Especially typical one-on-one duels can end in a variety of ways from being totally swept (happens to me more than I'd like to admit) to having both players dangerously close and the winner only being able to survive another hit before he would have been defeated. Needless to say, very fun and intense.

Even the community so far is great to each other and there is alot of respect after fights and funny things people have to say after winning by just that small amount of health. 

Do I recommend this game? Yes, yes I do. I'm not much of a fighting-game kind of person, especially competitive but the things that set Blade Symphony apart from other fighting games are it's most precious assets, and that is what makes it so engaging.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976741673', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1444521007}
review:
So, I'd figure I want to revise this review, since it wasn't really saying anything about the game besides my admiration for the game and it's awesome developers.

If you are looking for the game, where you can finally have those PvP sword fights, where skill (as in using your mouse and keyboard as efficient as possible), character and combat styles, you have dreamed of REALLY matter - this is it. This is on a par with e.g. Chivalry (or Age of Chivalry in the older source times), besides setting itself into a mix of cyberpunk, steampunk and classical knight themes and even goes beyond that. Some people even compare this to Knights of the Old Republic PvP - so there must be something about these rumours.
Have a look, because you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021204633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1386102842}

review: It's a very precise swordfighting game, which definitely feels unique. There a variety of characters and different sword types which allow you to customize the way your character fights and looks. It's got a steep learning curve and the community is fairly small, but if you're a fan of precise, competitive fighting games, you'll really enjoy Blade Symphony.

The system presented is fairly deep and, overall, it looks great, especially for an early access game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076280767', 'num_games_owned': 945, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1400974147}
review:
As a newcomer to the Blade Symphony scene, it is best to describe the first impressions as that is what most games hook you in with. That being said, Blade Symphony is not like most games - it is a special gem that is being developed as we speak and with time it shall be worth much more than it is now; this I am sure of.

Blade Symphony is a 3D sword-fighting games with an abundance of swords to use. It is a splice between arena based combat and arcade style fighting with a limited amount of characters to choose from but a large supply of weapons to pick. There are two servers included within the online component of the game (the 'chapters' for single player use are currently being expanded upon).

There is the 'Free For All' or 'FFA' server in which all players roam around the map to either make as many enemies as they want or challenge others to duels. A good addition to this is the lack of interference from other players during duels - while roaming you can see others duel and you cannot interfere with them. Not to say you can't fight without challenges - during FFA, you can potentially fight all other players on the map at once.

There is also the 'Duel' servers. These contain a series of fighting stages on a map that you scroll through and 'queue' for in an effort to fight. When a second player also signs up for the board you then duel them in a one on one battle. Who ever is hosting can change the dueling modes to support 2 v 2 battles - the possibilities are varied! 

On the single player side, a nice little tutorial is in place that, for now, is the only major showcase for AI in the single-player portion. Although I have not played with bots, they also exist for certain servers.

Combat is varied depending on the character chosen. In a similar fashion to Mortal Kombat, Tekken and Street Fighter, you have a choice of your character that you use (and in FFA you can switch when outside of battle). There are four characters each with their own fighting style. Pure, Phalanx, Ryoku and Judgement have different playstyles involved as well. While combat is usually high-paced among the visually lighter characters, don't be alarmed when fights take a slower pace. The ability to make your character 'walk' is as useful as the ability to 'run' on walls and manuever yourself.

Find yourself fighting an impatient 'fast' stance fighter? Switch to a 'heavy' or 'balanced' stance and take it slower by walking. Of course, using the fighter's to their best ability is done by using their innate techniques. It's better to take a heavy stance with Judgement than it is with Ryoku - but the game doesn't penalize you for taking it your own way. Finding your own technique among the four characters is part of the heart and challenge to this game. Don't be thrown off by the achievement statistics for winning one round. If you have the will to learn and the luck, you'll win your first round in no time.

A major part of the combat system to note is the combo system. Labeled as a 'multi-hit' the more attacks you link together in one string of movement adds to the counter; not taking damage helps. As you hit more than once the amount of damage dished out is increased, depending on the weapon. Characters don't have a set value for multi-hits but, because of the different speeds and styles, all can give out a different amount of comboed moves. Ryoku is a character that relies on the multi-hits when using weaker weapons because it increases the amount of damage he can give out. Judgement, however, relies less on this system, but, when a player uses it, it still benefits him in the same way it would Ryoku - it increases the output of his attack. With the fast paced battle taking place, it's imperative to complete multi-hits as necessary to win faster and mitigate the risk of losing.

The character design is hard to pinpoint - take sci-fi, steampunk, Eastern and Western influences and mash them together. That's a less eloquent way to describe the over-arching character costumes in appearence. It is harder to simply into a system when you get far enough to customize your character (described further down).

It's important to note that with so many factors involved, choosing from four characters is far from a simple game of rock-paper-scissors. Outcomes are reciprocated of player skill - at rare times is it up to your luck. If you learn from your mistakes quickly, this unforgiving dueling game can really shine and help.

This game is rewarding but such rewards are slow and take time and effort to attain them. You can customize and adorn your  four cool characters by adorning them with masks and skins - for a price. While there are NO MICROTRANSACTIONS in this game (a +), the system at which you gain the monetary units ('notes') can be seen as slow and tedious. No doubt, it's one of the minors in this upcoming game and it shouldn't deter you at all. The slow gain of 'notes' only impede character design and weapon unlocking. It rewards those who play the longest - or rather, the more you play, the more it pays. That said, it's a good way of differentiating the new comers from the more experienced sword masters. And while you can unlock more weapons, masks and skins you do not lose or gain an overbearing advantage over others. As long as you have control, the basic set of weapons are as deadly as the most brazen.

Capes, as of now, are also unlocked by completing special and secret objectives as you play. No doubt another rewarding factor for this game.

The characters?

Pure is a refined and acrobatic character - think Wushu fighting. With agile swordsman ship and experienced user skill she can be deadly - if you find yourself in a 2 v 2 against two skilled Pure users, you are definitely at a disadvantage. Pure is an offensive character that is best played by switching stances rapidly and soundly. Don't let up on your opponent lest they get the drop on you. Loosening the pressure is recommended however to open up the dueler's defenses when they lack an opening.

Ryoku is agile, fast but unrefined - he's great for stringing combos together and less useful at hitting hard. For him you'll want to build up your combos instead of vying for a one-hit kill. The fast paced action of this game suits him as you'll find yourself overcome if you fought these guys in a 2 v 2. The Scimitar is a fan-favorite for the Ryoku user as it allows them to (cheaply) build up 'multi-hits' and dole out punishment in the boss way the character defines.

Unless you are:

Phalanx. This guy. This guy is one I dislike - in a good way. He's a very plyable fencer that can strike from afar but will deal the necessary damage up close. He's also useful for stringing combos up and whipping an enemy into shape. With an experience player using him, he'll no doubt be the true challenge to beat. Watch out for Phalanx. They'll get you when you least expect it.

Judgement is a heavy hitting samurai. His default character, adorned in armor, has no trouble signifying how hard his experienced hand will come down upon his unlucky opponent. While he isn't as agile and swift as the other three, his recommended katana is useful for beating down the other. It's best to chalk Judgement up as one of the simpler to use. His slower speed allows for an easier string of combos if necessary by the less experienced player. He is, however, not a dominant combo chainer, his being the smaller out of all of them. Bulky and sluggish are in no way to describe him however. He is no doubt a tank and can take out a hit as well as dish them out - high damage with low speed if you look at it in technical terms.

 In the end, Blade Symphony is no doubt a game for those who like swords, arcade fighting-games and arena based combat. 

It is not a game for those who enjoy first person visuals, puzzle solving, platformers or role-playing games. Fast combat is not for slow players!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001088727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1406910119}
review: Probably the best competitive melee combat game available at the moment, with a deep combo system that encourages mixing up your approach. I found earning cash to buy new pieces slow, and half the time it didn't even seem to give them to me (and this was not in FFA mode, which is not supposed to generate any cash). Luckily you are provided with every gameplay relevant item there is; the only things you're missing are skins. It also features Workshop support, giving you access to a variety of skins for free, and if you have the know-how to model a sword, you could put your own skins into the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025012106', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 23947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13412, 'last_played': 1468258543}
review: This is a really good game. Sword fights feel solid and responsive (with a good framerate and better than 100 ping of course). Great futuristic-y design, sweet music, and really cool people. A lot of people compare the combat to Dark Souls and Soul Calibur but I really don't see the resemblance. It also sounds like it's inspired a fair bit by the Jedi Knight games, but i've never played those. You can live all your dreams of pointed and sharp weapons, from poking someone in the eye to cutting their shin. One of the best parts is that not all weapons are pointed and sharp, thanks to Steam Workshop integration. Overall great game, would recommended to anyone who's a fan of sword fights. i give it a good/10 much sword so indie (im sorry). also all the unlocks are cosmetic ok

review: Really cool game, the controls arent as smooth as they could be but the game isnt finished, its also in need of a bit of balance tweeking I find however super fun and no matter how much someone plays they only unlock skins so from day one you will only be facing people who are more skilled than you, not who outclass you in terms of gear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032398974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 875, 'last_played': 1381982830}
review:
The game's combat is its main draw but it won't hold you for long.

The characters have a little bit of customization (a few outfits and a color scheme) but nothing to write home about.

Combat adds a lot of complexity but the complexity doesn't get the game as much depth as you would think. In practice there are a few strategies that are very effective and most people just use those over and over. Combat in the game feels hindered by the game's complexity more than it is aided by it.

Not very many maps and the only thing really worth doing in the game is dueling. Right now the game is not worth your money but perhaps in the future that will change.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996901737', 'num_games_owned': 1122, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1387591505}
review:
Short version: I recommend despite not being a big fan of fighting games in general. That said, it might not keep you terribly entertained for any great lengths of time, but it has potential as long as more content is added by either the devs or by the community.

Long version:
Basically game plays similar to a fighting game. Two people, one arena, best out of three. The twist is in the combat system its self. Swords clash and deflect off each other, creating opening for light attacks and heavy stance attacks, when timed well, can do tonnes of damage to the people who dare give you an opening. Grabs, projectiles and charged attacks are thrown into the mixture as well to give you some more interesting options to play with.

To break it down there are four characters available in the game as it is now, each with their sword fighting style and speeds.
Sword lines project the path your sword is going to travel when you attack. To avoid taking damage from these attacks, you opponent can dart out of the way, roll to avoid the sword's path (yes, provided you can time it right, you can roll under a horizontal sword swing to avoid taking damage), block to take less damage or clash swords with an attack of their own.

That's just the basics of how the fights turn out. There are two types of server available as of now; Duel and Free For All.
The way duel servers work is quite neat. On each duel map, there are three different arenas to fight in. If all three are in use, you can queue up to join one of them and spectate the current dual as you wait. At any time, players in an arena and its queue can vote to make the arena they are in a 2v2. Free for all servers are quite different. Instead of the map being split up into three, all people are in one big space and can attack at random or challenge each other to private duels to avoid being interrupted by randomers.

As you fight, you gain a form of currency called 'notes'. These can be used to buy new swords, skins, capes and masks for your preferred characters. I'm interested to see how the workshop is integrated though. The workshop seemed to undermine the whole currency thing, letting you download free, visible-to-all swords. All the items off the workshop have been removed though, so they're probably addressing that now. The global ranking system is a neat idea too. With every win and loss (and apparently hit landed too) contributing to your rank which is on display and for everybody to see. Is a nice little touch to either give you a boost of confidence or a boot up the ass depending on whether you've been playing against a dev or not.

Speaking of which, the devs are friendly and very in-touch with the community. I've run into them a couple times in game, which I can't really say for anything else I've played.

Anyway, I would say this game is worth your money. It's a nice little idea, and I'm interested to see how the devs are gonna continue to add to this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995348415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1390088111}
review:
Insanely good - I had concerns about latency or hit registration, all gone after the first minute: it *is* solid.

There's really a tactical dimension in the fights, so doing the wrong move at the wrong moment can be punishing if the enemy react properly to your error - but you can always come back into the fight after a nasty beating, if you manage to surprise your opponent.

Playing with the expectations of your adversary is central to the gameplay, which mean even the beginners have a chance to land a good hit or even a victory.

The game already has a "ranking" system, so if you're still learning you can stick to the other beginners - but even the veterans will adapt their playstyle to your level: I wasn't stomped or crushed by them, they simply enjoyed trying more risky moves.

When Chivarly duelling is bashing medieval weapons at each others (all in good fun), Blade Symphony is dancing around your opponent to land accurate strike on their sides, back and front (when unguarded), swinging your sword to counter their attacks.

Ever managed a successful dodge with the Man-at-Arms, to strike your target on his sides or back, as his heavy sword/axe/pole misses you by an inch ? Blade Symphony is that, taken to whole new level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064523593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1548896088}
review:
Edit: About 90% of the community is gone, there really isn't much here anymore. DO NOT PURCHASE.

With such an elegant fighting system Blade Symphony can bring out plenty of "fight for your life" moments where everything shifts into full gear leaving you wanting to experience more. A small but nice selection of character and sword classes Blade Symphony feels elegant and classy when dualing others.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970673673', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 45415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45415, 'last_played': 1548528045}
review: The game brought a unique twist to fighting games in the indie sphere. It tried new things within the limitations of the source engine that were difficult to overcome. Animations and quality increased over time but its time has come and gone. It was an excellent ride for the height of its success but the team was not able to bring it further in the lifespan of the title. Very fun game for those of you who want to try some games against a friend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198104120145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1428883280}
review: This game requires that you be dedicated. The controls take a while to get used to and since it is still early release there are bugs to be fixed but its fairly fun. I say you have to be dedicated because it takes hours of gameplay (unless you happen to be naturally amazing) to get good. It takes hours because you have several characters to try out and several weapons to try out with each character to see which is the best fit for you. Then after all that you need to practice to that you can actually beat other people.

review: So pretty much it's yet another shitty Half Life 2‚Ñ¢ mod. In this budget game you play as futuristic knights. It's in the future so i dont know why they aren't using guns and shit so there's a plot hole already. Like Dark Souls, there is no story at all and they made the flippy katana shitters overpowered. I guess this is to appeal to the weeaboo target audience. Basically nobody plays this game either except the anime fans who end up meowing and try to have internet sex with you after every match.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003880852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 2506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1370, 'last_played': 1413983000}
review:
If you just want a short, quick oppinion: BUY.

For the details:
This is a 3D duelling simulation. I could say sword fighting, but that just isn't justified. The core of the game consists of 1on1 (or 2on2) duels with a best of 3 rounds system. The rounds itself are limited to 90 seconds, but often they can end in less then 20. Means each duel takes ~1-5 minutes.

The fighting itself is fast-paced, takes a lot of timing and precision, but is NOT the buttonmashing combospamfest you would know from other 'fighting games' (Street Fighter, Tekken, Mortal combat).

Graphic, Sound and Atmosphere wise you can easily call the game 'beautiful', because that's exactly the asthetic direction it tries to follow. Far-Eastern bells accompany your idle periods and fierce, but 'background-ish' war tunes accompany the duels. The graphics and maps are definitely influenced by eastern sword fighting movies and fit well into the game.

However, one of the best selling points of the game: The community. As of now, it got a large boost by the recent launch, but is still comparatively small. However, opposed to most other games, the communityin Blade Symphony is a POSITIVE surprise. On my first day I ran into the #5 ranked player worldwide, who wiped the ground with me and then spent the next 2 hours teaching me the in's and out's of my character. And when he was done with that, he went on and trained the next newbie.
Blade Symphony puts a lot of emphasis on that 'beautiful, honorable, gracious' style of duelling, adding a vide variety of emotes, most notable the bow, which is by now common etiquette at the start of ALL duels... and always obeyed. I think it's the atmosphere of the game, the example given by the good players and the way duels are presented that make people actually value the respectful tone of the duels.

Of course I must now as well mention it's downsides:
Whilst the overall appearance is nice, the graphics aren't completely up to current engines anymore. As well, the animations are not all fully perfect and there ARE animation glitches. Movement along walls (yes, the game permits wallrunning) isn't exactly smooth either (and is really more of a gimmick then an actual gameplay element). The ragdolls are usually horribly amusing, too.
Effectively, I could say the whole negative point of the game is that it's a budget game made by an indie developer who has nowhere near as much ressources as an AAA title.


Overall, Blade Symphony is, in my oppinion, the single most detailed duelling (/sword fighting) games on the market and well worth both money and time, even more so since it actually comes at a budget price.
Rating: 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198047517186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1422939050}
review:
Ever since A Long Time Ago BC, or maybe around the middle of the Qing Dynasty, people have wanted to use swords. But until now, they couldn't. Now, they can.
Introducing Blade Symphony, the very first game that allows you to use a sword. 
In this game, you take a sword, and you find opponents that are real people that  you probably wouldn't like, and then you challenge them to a duel, and then you get your arse handed to you on a pointy stick because you're bad at this. 
To be good at blade symphony, you need be good at the game. That involves using all the different attacks you can use, and knowing when to block, which sword type you like, which character you think is the superhottest, and how that character does good things and which good things are good to do at certain points of the duel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993511238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1242, 'last_played': 1392427931}
review:
For a game in alpha its good. Closer to Jedi Knight Academy than Mount and Blade.

My biggest issue is lag, player side compensation. You can't have that shit in fighting games / dueling games.

If i lost a duel in Mount and Blade, I knew why, and I felt like the other player is better.

When I lose a duel in Blade Symphony, sometimes I feel the same (other player is better) but other times... the lag is just -_-. The lag doesn't show both players stuttering or make you feel like youre playing underwater. Its smooth, but attacks that should hit... wont, your sword will go through your opponent and do 0 damage.

Theres no 4 directional blocking either, just be facing your opponent. 
Parrys are done when both players attack at the same time.
Feints can only be done with the longsword, and this replaces blocking.

Game is good, needs some work to make it great.

review: A very good Indie game. I acquired it while it was still Beta and loved it. Brings the real swordfights out from the real world to a competitive battle where precision, timing, position, stance and tactic really count. It also has only aesthetic upgrades instead of stat or equipment upgrades which is a very nice feature and very friendly torwards new players. I hope this game achieves success either with the players or the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036451825', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1467209525}
review:
Lo compre sin esperar mucho del juego, pero me ha acabado encantando. Es una especie de juego de lucha pero de "Mundo Abierto". Lo pongo entre comillas por que los mapas en realidad no son grandes.
Consiste en meterte en el servidor e ir retando a duelos a la gente que hay ahi. Cuando lo haces, los demas jugarores no pueden interferir en tu duelo y solo luchas con la persona que retaste.
Los graficos estan bien y la jugabilidad es bastante comoda. Hay alguna que otra personalizacion y Workshop.
Hay que tener en cuenta que es un Alpha y todavia faltan cosas que se iran a√±adiendo pero lo recomiendo totalmente.
9/10

review:
Simplesmente fenomenal. N√£o √© um jogo para todos: duelos hardcore, onde precis√£o, reflexos e medir bem tempo e dist√¢ncias s√£o essenciais. O tipo de jogo que se entra para apanhar muito at√© come√ßar a dominar, mas para quem gosta isso √© delicioso.
√â o mais pr√≥ximo que j√° vi do q seria o 'jogo de luta sobre esgrima'; h√° alguns combos e 3 posturas que fazem toda a diferen√ßa, mas √© menos sobre combinar bot√µes e muito mais sobre observar o advers√°rio e calcular seus ataques. √â bem perto do que o pvp em Dark Souls poderia/deveria ser- adicione mais movimentos e camadas de estrat√©gia e temos Blade Symphony.

H√° muitas mec√¢nicas n√£o aparentes rodando sob os panos, que postura usa, qual postura vence 'fintas' contra quais, como funciona a conex√£o de golpes e defesa com cada estilo- tudo faz diferen√ßa. author: {'steamid': '76561197996593537', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 9104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4995, 'last_played': 1534984260}
review:
Easy to pick up, hard to master, and stylsh as hell.  Don't let the trailer music fool you, the soundtrack is great.  Watch a duel on Youtube to get an idea of just how sexy this game is.

Unlike most other fighting games, Blade Symphony uses no button combinations to pull off moves - simply pick a stance and swing to get your different moves.  Footwork and knowing the movesets for both you and your opponent is the key to victory.

The game is still unfinished, but there are no gamebreaking balance issues at the moment.  Well worth the money if you want a more modern take on fighters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997118761', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 17821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2824, 'last_played': 1538780476}
review: A great slasher reliant on timing and positioning more than anything. Chivalry (and other slow melee game variant) players be warned; it is EXTREMELY fast paced. Nonetheless, it is still a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969592572', 'num_games_owned': 1954, 'num_reviews': 477, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1381357482}
review:
This game definitely has potential to be one hell of a fun online melee combat game. There should be some offline training down the road once the game is more completed.

But as of now, the game is limited since it is still in "Early Access" mode. There is some work to be done and I'm sure the developers already know that!

Still, if you're into Chivalry and War of the Roses, you should give Blade Symphony a shot... but, I would advice to wait it out until the game is in "gold" status.

RATING:
Pending until full release... although, I'd give it a solid 7.0 / 10 right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029053625', 'num_games_owned': 1714, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1588710237}
review:
Okay, I'm going to start by saying if you think any of the current modern games are beautifully designed...then you need to own this game. If you are a fan of any of the following things: Swords (Key thing), Tekken, Street Fighter, Customising Characters, Unlocking Things & Proving Yourself Online...then you need to own this game. Finally if you want to support a game that is an early access stage in which you can already play using three characters and an unlockable fourth alongside at least 20 different swords of varying styles and designs...then you need to own this game.

I've played this game for a day...I want to see this finished as I love swordfighting and this game keeps to every aspect of a swordfight that you can imagine, if you like Foils, it has them. Longswords, Yep. Katanas...You guessed it! :)

Seriously, each area is beautifully designed even when running on a low-end computer or even a Mac running Bootcamp for windows, this game is an elegant display of a way to solve a conflict that we have had around for hundreds of years.

Please support this game if you even think you'll enjoy playing it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198014691023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1405653225}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968428203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 88924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21598, 'last_played': 1692303871}
review:
I'm lucky enough to be apart of the development team for this amazing game. But I started out as fan playing the early builds of the game. Today the game is even more addictive and intense with very deep gameplay mechanics. The game offers a variety of game modes and plenty of cosmetic swords and items to earn in game from winning duels. 

For me this is one of the best dedicated sword dueling games out there, if not the best.

Buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029340980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 76470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24590, 'last_played': 1491790940}
review:
Blade Symphony is a 3rd person fighting game that throws button bashing out of the window...and like 3 continent's away.

In other words there is a lot of skill involved, but it's still very intuitive and quite easy to learn, though as you might expect, difficult to master.

Which brings me to my next and perhaps most important point, you guessed it, the community! The people playing this game are amongst the most helpful and fun to play with people I've ever played with in a multiplayer game. 

Servers like School of War are often full of people who are willing to help those who are new to the game or who need it. It can be a lot of fun when people organize events and people are just very diciplined when it comes to following the rules and not to mention often really polite. Almost every duel I've fought begun and sometimes ended with a bow, even though that isn't necessary.

The game itself is definitely brilliant as well. At the time of writing the game is still in beta and the developers are constantly adding things to and refining the game. From the beautiful visuals and music to the incredible depth of the fighting systems, how duels play out and the customization.

Overall it's a very enjoyable experience playing this game and becoming better at it through practice or through help from fellow players.
It's a work in progress, but definitely something to look forward to.
---------------------------
5 months later, all of the above still pretty much holds true imo. The game has progressed quite a lot though, some would argue for the worse, but I personally like where it is going. 

And on a little side note, for anyone who's interested, the developers of this game actually have a meeting every saturday at around 4 pm. PST or 12 pm. GMT, which they stream on youtube. Just search for 'punyhumangames' and perhaps subscribe if you want to get notified whenever they do one. I find it can be quite insightful and they will also answer any questions you post in the comments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036562461', 'num_games_owned': 1187, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1482, 'last_played': 1460746586}
review: OMFG GET EET NAO.... Oh and heres the review---->  First off its pure tactical, no button mashing here folks. Secondly the fluid movement makes fighting hell'a'lotta fun and knowing and predicting enemy movements and counteracting thier style with yours makes you feel like every hit counts. This game is purely unforgiving and any slip ups can mean certain failure so you need to concentrate on the enemys every movement and play tacticaly based on it. If he opens himself up after an attack jump in and smash him, but dont stay in too long or you will get sliced up by his come back slashes. All-in-all this game deserves a 9/10 in its current condition. Of course its still in beta and there are some minor balancing issues but all will be buffed out for final release, so in short i reapeat "OMFG GET EET NAO!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197991503698', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 14047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1445, 'last_played': 1705996929}
review:
Blade Symphony currently in beta (May 2013) offers a fun, strategic and intense sword fighting experience very reminescent to the Jedi Academy saber fighting.

The developers are constantly watching and communicating with players to tweak the game in order to provide the most satisfying experience possible.  

It has been a very long time where I've wanted to commit the time and effort to play something that actually feels like it pays off.  

This game can be enjoyed through long periods of time or short bursts. 

Get Blade Sympony, support this community, watch it grow, watch it live it it's fullest potential.  This is a real gem that's risen from the underground, and it's not even officially out yet.  

Get your swords ready, and get ready to dance until the death with the Blade Symphony.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009508198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3055, 'last_played': 1397515261}
review:
The closest thing to real life combat in a video game. The fun and thrills of a sword fight without the fear of an untimely death. Footwork, timing, anticipation, with a variety of moves from combos, charge attacks, dashes, jumpsm grabs and throwing knifes, This game embodies skilled one-on-one dueling where the better man truely wins.

I'm supprised at how complete it is for being a beta, there is no current meta despite there being 3 differant characters each with their own playstyle and sets of attacks, and four differant swords which have considerible differances in how you approach combat, everything feels fluent and natural, there is a viable counter to everything and every method of attack is just as viable. The game's unlockibles are purely asthetic, there are no items that change gameplay at all, so you can always be sure it's a fair fight.

Fantastic game, it really fulfills my pvp urge and leaves me feeling satisfied with my victories and humble in defeat, knowing that only my errors left me dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000437414', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1538339726}
review:
Such a fun game, I have been looking for a good game where I can "hop in and play" maybe for a few minutes, and this is really good at that!

I haven't been playing for a long while, but the stuff I have seen is amazing.
I have tried several sword styles, and been amazed every time I do a perfect combo, killing off the enemy without losing a single life point.

its pretty easy to learn the easy combinations, the hotkeys and "how to" in this game.

Also the community is great, everytime I stop to write something, they stop to attack me. Also everyone is really nice and gives you tips & tricks mid-game.

Buy it.
